DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (DIRECTIONS TO STOP INDUSTRIAL ACTION) AMENDMENT BILL 1989 [No. 2]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Lewis for Senator Chaney) agreed to:

That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Industrial Relations Act 1988 to empower the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to give directions to stop industrial action, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Lewis for Senator Chaney) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Chaney, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Opposition has decided to reintroduce this Bill to give the Government and the Australian Democrats another opportunity to ensure that there are effective sanctions for those who defy the orders and decisions of the Industrial Relations Commission. The current pilots dispute provides a perfect illustration of the powerlessness of the Industrial Relations Commission to enforce its directions. The only sanction available to the Commission was to cancel the pilots award-something which predictably did nothing to bring about a cessation of industrial action.

Two weeks ago, when this Bill was last brought before the Senate, I pointed out that no amount of jawboning by the Minister for Industrial Relations could hide the fact that the Government had deliberately and knowingly left itself virtually powerless in the face of a sustained campaign of industrial action such as that being pursued by the pilots. I pointed out that, given the lack of effective compliance provisions, there would be little else the Government could do other than seek to tough out the dispute, which I predicted would cause major disruption to the lives of thousands of Australians and seriously damage the Australian tourist industry. My prediction has been borne out totally by the events of the last two weeks. Tourism-this country's major earner of foreign exchange-has been dealt a massive blow by the dispute, a blow from which it may take years to recover. The senior analyst from Moody's, Roger Nye, in explaining why that agency has yet again downgraded Australia's credit rating, has referred to the current pilots dispute as an example of Australia's failure to achieve structural adjustment.

This Bill offers an alternative to the current debilitating dispute. It contains effective compliance provisions that would ensure that directions of the Industrial Relations Commission to stop industrial action, such as the one made earlier in the pilots dispute by Justice Coldham, are properly enforceable. The Bill is still very relevant to this dispute. The mere cancellation of the pilots award does not remove the jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Commission to deal with the industrial dispute.

The Bill would insert a new division into the Industrial Relations Act 1988. Under this division, the Commission would be empowered to issue directions to stop or prevent industrial action. Such a direction could be given to any party to the industrial dispute, a member, officer or employee of an organisation that is a party to the industrial dispute, or any other person engaged in industrial action in relation to the industrial dispute. Where, on the application of the Minister or a party to the industrial dispute, the Federal Court is satisfied that a person has breached or is intending to breach a direction of the Industrial Relations Commission, the Court may issue an injunction enforcing the direction.

Failure to comply with such an injunction would constitute contempt of court and would be punishable with the same power as is possessed by the High Court in respect of contempt of that Court. This would enable the Federal Court to issue heavy fines to any union or other body or person in breach of an injunction, and could lead to the eventual sequestration of assets, if the fines were not paid. The chief advantage of this approach is that it would provide a quick and effective remedy to unacceptable industrial action. Speed is of the essence in any effective sanctions procedure, as the primary aim should be to bring about the cessation of the conduct in question, not penalise those taking part in the action months or years later. Experience has shown repeatedly that when organisations which are acting illegally are faced with the reality of such heavy fines for defying court orders they quickly come to their senses.

In addition, any person who suffers loss or damage as a result of conduct in breach of a direction, may sue the person or organisa-tion concerned in the Federal Court. This could have obvious relevance to disputes such as the current airlines dispute, where many innocent third parties are caught up in a struggle between a union and an employer. Action taken in breach of a direction by an officer, employee, member or agent of an organisation is deemed to have been taken by the organisation, unless the organisation establishes that it took all reasonable steps to prevent the person from taking the action. These provisions would replace the existing bans clause provisions which were described by the former Minister for Industrial Relations, Ralph Willis, as having `fallen into disrepute' and as being `substantially moribund'. Two weeks ago I said that the Government had no real argument against the need for effective compliance provisions. I quoted Mr Willis, who pointed out when introducing the 1987 Industrial Relations Bill:

An essential element of any industrial relations system which provides benefits and protections to registered organisations and their members is that there should be an effective means of ensuring adherence to the principles on which the system is founded and compliance with the decisions of its institutions.
Since then the Government has openly backed the use of legal remedies against the pilots. Senator Aulich, who spoke in the debate two weeks ago will have to eat his words:
the worst possible thing to do to improve industrial relations in this country is to get people into the courts and the common law system.

Indeed, it is ironic that the Government has opposed the introduction of effective legal sanctions into the conciliation and arbitration system-yet supported the use of external remedies such as the common law and the Trade Practices Act-an astounding reversal from its position in 1987 when it took the view that there should be no sanctions available outside the system.

The truth is that any system of conciliation and arbitration whereby the decisions of the arbitrator effectively only bind one side of the employer-employee equation is clearly defective. The Government recognised this, and its 1987 legislation contained provisions that would have provided a directions/injunctions procedure along the lines contained in this Bill. Those provisions were flawed, containing as they did the potential for lengthy delay. And of course they were eventually withdrawn, under pressure from the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which would not accept any improvement in the compliance powers of the Industrial Relations Commission, that were not accompanied by the emasculation of common law and Trade Practices Act remedies. As a result the existing Act contains the `moribund' provisions referred to by Mr Willis. This Bill would provide Government, employers and the Commission real teeth to ensure that Commission decisions are adhered to and would provide real protection against those who try to pursue their ends through industrial blackmail.

The Government and the Australian Democrats in the debate on this Bill two weeks ago raised a number of issues concerning the detailed drafting of this Bill. The principle underlying this Bill is that there should be an effective directions and injunctions procedure which would provide a quick and effective remedy for those who are suffering from industrial action in defiance of the Industrial Relations Commission. If the Government or the Democrats have concerns about the detail of the Bill it would be proper to consider these in the committee stage, after the Bill has received a second reading. It would be quite inappropriate to throw out the principle underlying the Bill for the sake of details of the sort raised in particular by Senators Cooney and Maclean. I indicated, for example, during the debate on this Bill two weeks ago, that I would wish to consider some of the points raised by Senator Cooney, such as the breadth of penalties that would be imposed for contempt of court. It might be appropriate for example totally to exclude any question of possible imprisonment.

This Bill seeks to implement an important element of the Coalition's industrial relations policy. Our policy is based on the principle that where employers and their employees see a mutual benefit in doing so, they should be free to sign legally binding voluntary agreements on pay and conditions. Those agreements will have the force of awards and will contain a provision that no industrial action be engaged in during the course of the agreement. We believe this approach will enable pay and conditions to be related directly to the circumstances of the individual enterprise, something which is not possible under an across the board approach. It is not part of our policy to permit one side of the industrial fence to use industrial muscle to coerce the other into reaching an agreement against their own wishes and interests. That is why our policy is explicit in requiring effective legal sanctions when parties are abusing their industrial strength.

Where a mutually satisfactory agreement is not possible, employers and employees remain within the conciliation and arbitration system. We do not seek to dismantle that system, though we would expect that as the advantages of voluntary agreements come to be appreciated, more and more people will move in that direction. But it will not be an overnight change. Because the Industrial Relations Commission will remain and will continue to play a major role in wage determination and dispute settlement it is essential for it to have the power to enforce its decisions and directions. This Bill seeks to rectify a major defect in our industrial relations system. It is a defect that both the Government and the Democrats have been willing to acknowledge in the past. Both the Government and the Democrats can show they are serious about improving the operation of our industrial relations system by supporting this Bill.

Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Geneva Conventions Act 1957.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1989 is set out in identical terms to the bill of the same name introduced by the government in the House of Representatives earlier this year. The purpose of that bill was to amend the Geneva Conventions Act 1957 so as to enable Australia to ratify Protocols 1 and 2 additional to the Conventions. Before ratifying the Protocols, it was necessary to enact domestic legislation which created offences in regard to breaches.

On 7 March 1989, the Opposition announced that it would reject the legislation because the United States has not ratified the Protocol and `this has obvious and direct implications for the defence of Australia'. It was also claimed that ratification would unreasonably hamper the armed forces and that Mr Hawke's admittance-in his much publicized `my dear Ron' letter to ex-President Reagan-that ratifying the Protocols posed a number of `operational complexities' meant the legislation was flawed.

This Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1989 seeks to give legislative effect to recent advances in international humanitarian law. The Australian Democrats believe that, as such, it is supported by the general community. I am introducing this private member's Bill, therefore, to keep faith with the many groups and individuals in this country who have worked hard to have this Protocol established and to give Senators a chance to vote on an important bill which has been stalled in the House of Representatives.

International humanitarian law is concerned with the lives and welfare of individual human beings in peace as well as in war. The written law which deals with the fate of human beings during armed conflict has been developed over the last 120 years.

It began at the battle of Solferino in 1859, in which Austrian, French and Italian armies were engaged. More than 300,000 soldiers fought the battle and there were at least 40,000 killed and wounded. A young Swiss banker, Henry Dunant, saw what happened after the battle. He wrote a book titled `A memory of Solferino'-the theme of which was to urge his readers to, if not prevent, at least, alleviate the horrors of war.

His book shocked the world, led to the founding of the Red Cross and to the development of written international codes of conduct during armed conflicts. The first practical result of Dunant's efforts was an international conference which led to the formation of the International Red Cross.

The Swiss Government, urged on by Dunant and the international committee which later developed into the International Committee of the Red Cross invited other governments to attend an international diplomatic conference to draft an agreement. Diplomats from 15 European countries and an observer from the USA attended the conference in Geneva in 1864.

They drafted a convention which was the beginning of written international humanitarian law covering armed conflicts. The 1864 agreement, signed by the 12 European nations, provided that during future wars in which they were engaged they would care for all sick and wounded military personnel, regardless of nationality.

It was a modest enough beginning, but since 1864 there has been a series of international conferences to extend and develop humanitarian law. The most important was the Geneva conference of 1949 which resulted in four Conventions being adopted. These have since been ratified by 145 nations.

In 1977, at another Geneva conference, two Protocols were adopted and signed by 87 nations. The Protocols were developed after exacting work by many bodies, in particular the International Committee of the Red Cross, over an extended period from the early 1950s. Finally, a diplomatic Conference convened by the Swiss Federal Council held four sessions in Geneva from 1974 to 1977 to negotiate the final texts.

The Geneva Protocols deal in greater detail with matters such as civil defence, tackle questions of the means and methods of warfare which the framers of the Conventions had not felt themselves able to do, and extend the protections spelt out in the Conventions to non-international conflicts.

They were intended to extend the provisions of the four Conventions and to introduce new principles. These Protocols incorporated the new and important concept that the principles of the law governing armed conflicts between nations should apply also to conflicts between armed forces of a State and organised dissident forces within boundaries. Protocol 1 spells out that International Humanitarian Law applies to armed conflicts ``in which all peoples are fighting colonial domination and alien occupation and against racial regimes in the exercise of their right to self determination.''
The Conventions may be seen as an almost complete consolidation of written international humanitarian law applying to armed conflicts.

Protocol 1 covers international conflict and is concerned with the protection of victims of international armed conflicts. It requires the parties to such conflict to distinguish between the civil population and combatants, and between civil objects and military objectives, and to direct their operations only against enemy combatants and military objectives. Protocol 2, which is concerned with the protection of victims of non-international armed conflicts, will be ratified at the same time as Protocol 1. No additional legislation is required to enable ratification of Protocol 2.

This Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill is 73 pages in length and includes provisions relating to the wounded, sick and shipwrecked, the methods and means of warfare combatant and prisoner-of-war status, and the civilian population. The major change to the law is in Clause 5 of the bill which incorporates the obligation to punish `grave breaches', as defined in Protocol 1, into our domestic law. Examples of `grave breaches' include physical mutilations and medical experiments, attacks on civilian populations, and the unjustifiable delay in the repatriation of prisoners of war.

Other provisions confer jurisdiction on a court to determine the status of a person claiming to be a prisoner of war, and extend existing protection against misuse of emblems to such identity cards, signs, signals, insignia or uniforms as are prescribed for the purpose of giving effect to the Protocol.

Like the 1949 Geneva Conventions, the Protocols strike a balance between `military necessity' and `humanitarian considerations.' Rules of humanitarian law are always the result of a most complex process of compromise between exigencies of an effective national defence on the one hand and the common will to uphold certain human values even in war on the other.

The underlying principles can be simply stated: (a) the human dignity of all individuals must be respected at all times; and (b) everything possible must be done, without any kind of discrimination, to reduce the suffering of those who take direct part in the conflict or have been put out of action be sickness, wounds or captivity.

The Opposition's arguments against ratification of the Protocols are weak and meaningless. Their claim that ratification would hamper the armed forces conflicts with reported advice from the Chief of Defence Force Staff and the government's senior military adviser, General Peter Gration, that Australia's military could sign the Protocols and still successfully wage war. Hopefully the Opposition is not suggesting that Australia should condone military attacks on civilians and the other types of barbaric behaviour which this Bill seeks to outlaw.
Another trenchant critic of ratification has been Brigadier P. J. Greville. Brigadier Greville suggests that ratification of Protocol 1 would:
(a) jeopardise servicemen's present legal position;
(b) impose crippling restrictions upon our ability to wage war;
(c) may well prolong some conflicts;
(d) could jeopardise even further the lives of servicemen taken prisoner; and
(e) could put a defenceless Australian civilian population even more at risk.
I am totally unconvinced by the arguments advanced by Brigadier Greville. I am disturbed by his claim that Protocol 1 goes too far in that:
``it attempts to isolate the civil population from the effects of war, and this is wrong in principle, could have an adverse effect in practice.''
I find this a simply unsupportable and, indeed, an incredible assertion.
The Australian Democrats support the summary of Trevor Findlay, editor of Pacific Research of February 1989, who wrote:

Brigadier Greville has given a confused rationale for Australia not ratifying the protocols, but no sound reasons why Australian armed forces would want to conduct indiscriminate attacks against civilians or do any of the things the protocols attempt to outlaw-even if our enemies attempted them. Of course there will be marginal cases, instances in which international law will be unclear and mistakes made in the `fog of war'. But the dilemmas faced by military commanders regarding the use of force in the vicinity of civilians have always existed. For instance, Brigadier Greville asks, `how do you classify a teenage conscript soldier?' The protocols in fact attempt to clarify this by setting the minimum age for combatants at 18. Is the Brigadier suggesting that without the protocols the situation would be clearer? The protocols are a legitimate attempt by the International Red Cross to clarify the situation. Australia as a responsible member of the international community, should support these endeavours and ratify the protocols.

Australia has shown its concern for the fate of the civilian population in times of war. The Australian Democrats believe that Australia should now ratify both Protocols and thereby show to its own people, to its neighbours and to the world at large that this country is willing to accept binding obligations of a strictly humanitarian character. Other nation States of the region are examining the Protocols at present.

Despite the fact that the United States, the United Kingdom and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics have not signed the Protocols, global support for ratification grows and well over 70 nations have ratified Protocol 1 to date.

Rejection of the Protocols by Australia would discourage other States of the region from ratifying the Protocols. All governments take into account the attitude of other countries when deciding on ratification of treaties affecting national defence. Furthermore, a treaty will only be accepted by a growing number of States if there is a certain momentum. Non-ratification of the Protocols by Australia would certainly reduce that momentum.

The Government has introduced the Bill into Parliament on March 2nd of this year. The Opposition announced its rejection of the Bill on March 7th. Despite the fact that the Government had the numbers-with Australian Democrat support-in the Parliament, the Attorney-General who had stressed the importance that the Government placed on Australia's ratification of the Protocols simply adjourned debate on March 9th.

Mr Bowen stated in his press release that `the Bill's underlying principles were of such importance and self-evident value that any attempt to push the legislation through without bipartisan support would be highly inappropriate.' To this I ask why. On most of the major issues of the day in this country, bipartisan support is lacking but that has not prevented the Government from pushing ahead. The Government has to explain why it has given the Opposition veto power over the human rights of civilians caught up in bloody conflict?

The Australian Democrats response to this statement is that the Bill is, indeed, of such importance and of such self-evident value that it must be pushed forward in the face of ill-informed and anti-humanitarian attitudes.

It must be clearly understood that the government introduced this legislation and has thereby expressed its will and determination to ratify both Protocols. If Parliament now fails to approve my bill (or the government's original bill) then Australia would be seen as deliberately rejecting the Protocols-as distinct from simply not getting around to signing them. We would be the only country to set about such a high profile rejection and hence would be setting a deplorable precedent.
Surely the government must be aware that this would be the first time in history that a Red Cross humanitarian treaty was rejected by a democratically elected Parliament.
I commend this Bill to the Senate as a pledge of our regard for the continuation of humanitarian endeavour during the horrors of modern warfare.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to the Budget Statement and associated papers brought down in the Senate on 15 August this year. This Budget is best described as another Keating special. It has in it the same kind of misleading presentation we have now grown accustomed to receiving each year from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) when he brings down the Budget Speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The speech itself, of course, has become a travesty of what Budget speeches used to be. The television glossy, which is now what it has become, contains a minimum of information and certainly no information at all on matters which would be thought to be likely to have the slightest disadvantageous effect upon the Government's electoral prospects. That information has to be sought by members of the public to the extent that they can afford to purchase the Budget Papers and actually comb through them or rely upon the efforts of the media to assist them in that regard.

I have to say that the media-notwithstanding my often repeated criticism of some of its analytical reporting quality in this country-does do an extraordinary job on Budget night and in the days following the Budget in getting to the detail of the Budget Papers which have now assumed quite mammoth proportions. But none of that information is to be found in the Budget Speech. None of that is to be found in the television presentation. None of that is to be found in the series of what I think my colleague, Dr Hewson, has called the `dog and pony shows' being conducted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer around the country in the subsequent weeks.

This year the highlight of this misleading presentation of the Budget was to focus attention, or to seek to focus the attention, of the financial markets upon the bottom line figure for the $9.1 billion surplus. Let me make it quite clear that the Opposition is glad to see the Government budgeting for a large surplus. We would be even gladder if it were not for the fact that that surplus in this year was obtained in part by some interesting creative accounting, or what in previous years the Labor Party would have called `rubbery figures' when they were being produced by Treasurers on this side of the political spectrum. To the extent that there were rubbery figures in earlier Budgets-and there certainly were from time to time-they were not as elastic as those in Mr Keating's Budget.

It is necessary to elaborate on the point a little in order to address the question of whether we have had from Mr Keating what he desperately wants the financial markets to believe, namely, a Budget this year which produces an additional degree of fiscal or budgetary restraint upon the economy. I would have to say that when one has examined all the appropriate entrails of the Budget Papers, one cannot accept that judgment. At best, one would say that the degree of fiscal restraint emanating from this Budget is unchanged from 1988-89. If one were to take a somewhat less generous interpretation of some aspects of the figures, one would say, as have some commentators, that, if anything, on balance the Budget this year slightly relaxes the degree of fiscal restraint apparent last year. But I do not regard that as a matter particularly worth debating.

There are many more key points than I have time to produce. My judgment that the Budget this year, on balance, shows about the same level of fiscal restraint as last year is based on two key aspects of the Budget figures. The first is that, quite interestingly, in the dying months of 1988-89 the Commissioner of Taxation simply did not collect about $1.25 billion of provisional tax which it had been estimated he would collect. The result of that is that he will collect it this year. That has two effects. First, last year's Budget surplus finished up at $5.9 billion instead of $7.1 billion. That is the first bit of sleight of hand that we have seen in the Budget figuring this year.

The second instance of a similar sleight of hand is that Mr Keating has decided to bring forward into this year's Budget receipts two items of taxation which otherwise would not have been received until next year. First, by a very significant change-one which has much more far reaching implications than the point I am now speaking about; and I hope to come back to that-Mr Keating has decided to bring forward very considerably the timing of company tax payments. Companies will now be required to pay within 15 days of the end of the year 85 per cent of what they estimate to have been their tax assessments for the year just ended. Without spending further time discussing that measure, the result will be to bring into Consolidated Revenue in 1989-90 $885m which normally would have been brought in next year.

Secondly, the Treasurer has decided that companies with large payrolls-payrolls over $5m per annum-will now be required to remit to the Tax Commissioner twice a month instead of once a month the pay as you earn (PAYE) deductions that they make each fortnight from their employees' payrolls. The effect again of that one-off change will be to increase this year's Budget revenues by $550m. It will not affect next year's Budget revenues because, of course, it is a once-off change. The result of those two measures is to increase this year's revenues by $1,435m-call it $1.4 billion, for the sake of the rounding of the figures. So we have had $1 1/4 billion of last year's revenue being allowed to float over into this year; we have had $1.4 billion of either next year's revenue or a once-off revenue effect brought into this year.

Without those two bits of creative accounting-to use a kindly phrase-Mr Keating's Budget this year would have been not $9.1 billion, but about $6.5 billion. If that revenue float had not been allowed to move out of last year into this year, last year's surplus would have been just over $7 billion. We have actually gone, on what would have been, shall I say, a normal basis of approaching the budgetary position, from a surplus of about $7 billion to a surplus of $6.5 billion. I do not want to spend too much time saying one is smaller than the other and therefore this year's fiscal restraint has been relaxed, but when one actually looks into the figures, as I have just tried to do in brief, one certainly cannot say that the degree of budgetary restraint has been increased. There is no basis for that. Mr Keating knows that perfectly well because, of course, his Department would have told him so. That has not, of course, stopped him from going around the country saying that it has been increased.

Why is that particularly important? It is particularly important because it had been the hope, now sadly dashed, of people in the lead-up to the Budget, when we were getting these stories, that the Budget surplus would be considerably bigger this year than last year, that there was going to be a genuine increase in fiscal restraint from the Government and that that would have allowed the Government to relax somewhat the monetary screws that Mr Keating has been tightening ever since April last year-for the last 16 months now. Not at all: because the budgetary restraint now, in reality, is no different from what it has been all along, there is no basis for Mr Keating to relax interest rates in the near future. He has reluctantly been forced to face up to that conclusion on a number of occasions under questioning at various luncheons, dinners and other media occasions in the days succeeding the Budget. The $9.1 billion bottom line figure was the big thing that Mr Keating was selling on Budget night and that the Government has tried to sell ever since.

The other big thing-if I may say so, equally duplicitous-that the Treasurer tried to sell on Budget night and since was that he has actually addressed this country's savings problem by his measures in the fields of retirement income policy and of superannuation arrangements, the incentives for providing more savings by way of superannuation. What a joke! What a totally duplicitous joke! Indeed, quite by coincidence, the views I am about to state in this regard have been re- inforced only this morning in the feature article in the Sydney Morning Herald by Ross Gittins, which points out, I think I may say in extremely cogent terms, just how duplicitous this attempt by Mr Keating to tell us that he has solved our savings problem has been.

Let me say something about the elements of that piece of duplicity. First of all, on retirement income policy I think we have very little to say by way of criticism about what Mr Keating has done. What he has largely done, in fact, is to pick up the Opposition's retirement income policy, which was launched about a year ago. He has picked it up and taken over quite a number of elements of it-and good on him for doing so; we are totally happy with that. I only wish he would pick up more of our ideas on economic policy. The country would not be in the shambles it is if he were to do so. On the retirement incomes aspect of this particular piece of Mr Keating's other pea and thimble trick, I have no more to add.

It is on the other side, on the so-called superannuation incentives, that the real duplicity exists. What Mr Keating has actually done here is to say that in five years' time there will be some improved arrangements for superannuation. How is that supposed to solve our savings problem today? How is that supposed to solve our balance of payments problem today? How is that supposed to address our foreign debt problem today?

It is interesting also to ask oneself why, apart from the attempt to once again hoodwink the Australian public about the national interest so far as the Budget is concerned, Mr Keating has moved yet again into the superannuation policy field-a field which, I may say, he has been tilling assiduously almost every year since he has been in office, but always in the other direction. In every previous year he has increased the taxation burden on the superannuation industry or, if one prefers, diminished the taxation incentives for people to save through superannuation. This year he has gone in the other direction. One has to ask oneself why that is, apart from, as I say, trying to pull a major confidence trick upon the Australian people. The magnitude of that confidence trick is, incidentally, well demonstrated if one simply reflects that in the measures introduced only in last year's Budget in this area-leaving aside the previous ones-Mr Keating pulled in, and is this year collecting, an additional billion dollars in revenue from changing the superannuation arrangements. Now he is promising the savers of Australia that he might give a little of that back in five years' time. They might even get a small amount of it back in the next few years, but even in five years' time it will be of the order of $200m a year. Meanwhile, Mr Keating will have gone on picking up his billion dollars a year. So much for the incentive to save.

In addition, let us be quite clear that the other reason why Mr Keating has gone back, so to speak, on his tracks in this area is simply that he has found out that in the wake of his decisions last year-the decisions, remember, which were not going to cost anybody one cent-those measures, on the contrary, have had the most deleterious effects upon the superannuation industry, particularly as they affect the position of lower income and lower to middle income people. Under the arrangements which Mr Keating put in place last year it was still advantageous for upper middle income and high income people to take advantage of the taxation incentives for saving through superannuation. But it became very much a marginal calculation as to whether it was still advantageous for lower income people to do so, or even for lower middle income people to do so. Suddenly, Mr Keating's own constituency in the trade union movement found out it was not so easy to get people interested in getting into the superannuation area, which would have been one of the selling points that Mr Keating had agreed with Mr Kelty they would have to bolster the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), and the trade unions' position in the scheme of things, not to mention putting them in the position of putting their hands around the windpipe of the economy some years down the track.

I have spoken to this point about the two major aspects which Mr Keating has tried to use to sell this Budget as yet, once more, the latest answer to this country's problems. We have had this every year from Mr Keating and the country's problems have gone on getting worse and worse and worse, as we have just seen in the foreign debt figures issued yesterday and in the further turning down of thumbs by international credit rating agencies as was shown on the Moody's announcement yesterday. We will come to that later today.

But leaving aside those two aspects of Mr Keating's Budget, let us look at the fundamentals which that Budget should have been addressing. Let us see how well it addresses them. What are the fundamentals of our economic problems in this country today? Everyone would acknowledge that the Budget has now been brought back into surplus-as I say, not in a manner which we would have judged as best for that purpose; by not cutting spending but by way of raising taxes-to a point where, once again, this year taxes will run at a record proportion of the national product. Indeed, 25.2 per cent of GDP will once again, on the Government's own estimates, be collected this year and that is a record.

As I say, let us concede that we are glad to see the Budget in surplus and let us not spend further time, therefore, in debating as to whether it should have been better brought into surplus by cutting spending rather than by putting up taxes. Let us look, however, at the other aspects of the economic fundamentals which are much more sadly lacking-foreign debt and the rising level of foreign ownership of Australia. The thing which underlies both of those phenomena is our continuing deficit on the balance of payments, our continuing incapacity to live within our means. Inflation is endemic in Australia and that was what honourable senators will recall Mr Keating called in his Budget last year Australia's No. 1 economic disease. There is not much sign in this year's Budget of addressing that No. 1 economic disease.

Because of those fundamental things that are wrong with the Australian economy today, we have the crushingly high level of interest rates with first home owner mortgage interest rates stuck at 17 per cent and, in some ways even more importantly, I would have to say, overdraft rates for the 750,000 small businesses around this country at 21 to 25 per cent, depending on the individual credit ratings of farmers and other business people. In turn, because of those very high levels of interest rates and the fact that they sit there looking attractive to overseas lenders, we have a very high level for our exchange rate; that is, very high in terms of the underlying quality of economic performance of the country whose currency is involved. We have, in other words, an exchange rate that on the basis of this Government's policies-I emphasise that phrase-is clearly overvalued. Why is it overvalued? It is overvalued because Australia has become a haven for hot money. With 90-day bank bill rates still touching 17.9 per cent, having been at one stage well over 18 per cent, how can we be surprised?

Because our exchange rate is up where it is, imports are much cheaper-in Australian dollar terms-than they would otherwise be and our exports bring in less to our export producers in Australian dollar terms than they otherwise would. For that and other reasons we have a massive balance of payments deficit. Yesterday the Australian Statistician published new figures for foreign debt-indeed, not just foreign debt but for what the Statistician now calls our international investment position, taking account of both foreign debt and other forms of liabilities to foreign owners. The figures are, frankly, quite intimidating. As of 30 June this year, foreigners owned nearly $70 billion of Australian corporate equities; we owed $137 billion in debts to foreigners; and with other investments, which I do not have time to go into, the total of our overseas liabilities amounted to $221 billion.

It is true that on the other side of the ledger we do have some foreign assets. Australians own nearly $43 billion of corporate equities. They would be principally owned by those very same superannuation funds that the Treasurer is now going to make the linchpin of our savings policies. I can confidently predict that when he does the investors will continue to invest overseas just as much, just as high a proportion, as they are now doing, given the retrospective prospects of doing so overseas as opposed to investing at home.

There are some foreign borrowers from Australians-$8 billion. Our Reserve Bank has assets of $20 billion which the Government continues to claim belong to it. I would like to hear the views of the Governor of the Reserve Bank on that matter. Adding all those amounts together, we have foreign assets of about $80 billion. When we wash up those figures together our net position at 30 June this year was net foreign liabilities of $140 billion, including $108 billion in net debts. How did the Budget address that situation? It did not.

Mr Keating has tried to con the Press Gallery in this place by saying that he is doing something about our foreign debt position because the Commonwealth Government is paying off some of its debt. That is certainly true. It is paying some of its debt. That is like saying that a man who is in debt with three different bankers pays off banker A by borrowing from banker B. That is what Mr Keating is doing. He will be paying off banker A-that is, Commonwealth debts. In order to do so, as long as we have the reality of that underlying balance of payments deficit, some other Australian will have to borrow exactly the same amount from banker B. It is about time that the media stopped repeating this stuff from the Treasurer which is designed in the most cynical way to throw dust in their eyes. I am surprised that the media continue to accommodate this situation and continue to repeat material which is so cynically calculated to deceive them. Were I a member of the media I would be a bit indignant about that process. I might go out after the Treasurer and ask him an awkward question or two. I would look forward to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a long time since that happened.

—I think the media are beginning to catch up with Mr Keating. I look forward with great optimism to their doing so at a greater pace than they have done up to this time. The reason we have this continually increasing level of foreign debt and this continually increasing sale of Australian assets to foreigners is that we continue to live beyond our international means. We had last year a deficit on our balance of payments of $17.4 billion. Mr Keating predicts in the Budget Papers that we will have $18.5 billion this year. No improvement! Stuck at over 5 per cent of the gross domestic product-an extraordinarily high figure.

SPEECH.PARA: In the same sense inflation is stuck. Mr Keating is predicting that we will have an increase of 7 1/2 per cent this year in the consumer price index. That is virtually unchanged from the 7.4 per cent last year and the 7.3 per cent-or was it 7.1 per cent?-of the previous year. It is virtually stuck. There is no change in the disastrous policies which have produced, I repeat, a net foreign debt of $108 billion and a total net foreign investment liability position on our national balance sheet of over $140 billion. Because we have this apparently endemic, apparently unchanging level-certainly not an improving level of inflation-and this continual running into the red in our external account, we will continue to have very high interest rates, or something like them, for a long time yet.

Mr Keating conceded in a remark last week that he expects that we will have to suffer high interest rates-perhaps not quite as high as the present levels-for two or three years yet. While I welcome that concession to reality under this Government's policies, there are no policies in place which will mean that that period will be confined to the next two or three years. On the contrary, there are no policies in place which will prevent that continuing even into the distant future-the really distant future. Three years is distant enough, after all, for most people to be contemplating interest rates anything like we have at present.

To add to all this, the Government-particularly in the person of the Prime Minister-has now aggravated, and virtually helped to bring on, a disastrous dispute between the air pilots and the companies that employ them. That dispute will not merely produce the greatest difficulties for the travelling public of Australia-which it is already doing-and the greatest financial difficulties for the major airlines concerned but, what is much more important than either of those things in terms of magnitude, it will produce, if it continues, the gravest economic crisis for Australia because of the effects it will have on our tourism industry.

Our tourism industry has now become our single most important export or foreign exchange earner. Last year alone it earned $6.5m in foreign exchange-even more than wool. Last weekend the front pages of the Japanese newspapers were filled with-guess what?-news of the airline pilots dispute in Australia! This week our travel agencies, our major hotels and so on have been receiving communications from Japanese travel agents-I have heard of about 20 to date-who are saying, `Sorry, we are cancelling all future tourist trips to Australia'. I do not have time to elaborate on that theme now. We said something about it yesterday. But I ask: Where is the Government's policy taking us?

Mr Keating says that he is going to crush demand by using crushingly high interest rates. Let us assume, without arguing it for the present, that that is right. It is not right, but let us assume that it is. What will Mr Keating do then? When demand has been crushed, when interest rates start to come down a little because there is no longer any demand for credit because people have nothing worth borrowing for, where do we go then? If imports do start to fall off and the balance of payments starts to look a bit better, if Mr Keating starts to rev up the economy at all, we will go straight back into another balance of payments crisis and interest rates will go back up again. We will continue to have, because the accord has determined that we will have, 7 1/2 per cent inflation, or something pretty close to it. We will have the classic situation of stagflation.

Do honourable senators remember stagflation? Stagflation equals high inflation and economic stagnation. That is what this Government is delivering to us. I believe that Mr Keating's Budget of 15 August, because it failed to address any of these problems, has totally failed to meet the economic needs of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably fair to say that in many respects I agree with the comments of Senator Stone on this Budget in that it is very largely a con trick that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) produced with a great flourish. It is probably also fair to say that on those grounds-and at least on first inspection-it is one of the least controversial Budgets to be presented to the Australian people for many years. The Budget looks good on the surface. As Senator Stone said, it is only when one starts to delve below the surface that one realises that there is very little substance, very little improvement and very little benefit offered in the words, allegedly of wisdom, that the Treasurer offered to the Parliament and to the Australian people when he brought down this Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, small and staggered benefits have been offered to pensioners, although there is yet again no relief in sight for home buyers. The changes to annual rather than quarterly payment of provisional tax will assist many small businesses, but the proposal to bring forward company tax payments, while being only a temporary measure for this year, in that this year is the only year on which it will have a significant impact, may well offset much of the benefits to many organisations.

Extra money is being directed to alleviating the problem of youth homelessness, but the sources of that problem, that is, family poverty and youth joblessness, have not been given much attention at all in this Budget. The Government is looking at some superficial ways in which to pull back criticism and offset some of the popularity slump it has suffered in the last few years. Public sector borrowing is now down to zero and the Government has pledged its full $9.1 billion surplus to pay back outstanding domestic and foreign debt. Yet there is nothing in this Budget to address the problem of burgeoning private sector debt, which is, and has been for decades in Australia, the major component of our foreign debt, encouraged by a taxation system for companies which is amongst the most generous in the world and which has led, as a consequence, to a plethora of debt based, rather than equity based, financing systems in Australia.

What has the Government responded to in this Budget? Basically, it has responded to three issues. Firstly, it has responded to the need to encourage long term saving-something which has been talked about a lot in this country but which has rarely seen any active involvement by the Government.

Secondly, it has responded to the need to placate its traditional supporters by, as I said, appearing to offer additional benefits to welfare recipients, or at least to those welfare recipients who are represented by some fairly well organised groups in the community. Thirdly, it has responded to the demand from a variety of economic gurus for a domestic surplus, despite the fact that very few other countries have, in the past, had a significant domestic surplus. As I have said, excluded from the Budget, therefore, are things such as benefits for sole parents, benefits for families living in poverty, and benefits for homeless young people under the age of 16 years. What is more significantly missing is a general attempt to prevent child poverty, as distinct from patching up the worst of it when an election is approaching.

As I have said, no attention has been paid to the problems facing mortgage holders. In this, Australia remains significantly different from similar countries which place a high value on home ownership, namely, the United States and the United Kingdom. Australia still does not offer targeted tax relief to people who are paying off a mortgage in order to buy their own home. In Australia, we limit that benefit to only those people who are investing in the market. What is worse, we allow them not only a tax benefit but also a negatively geared tax benefit, so they get double the benefit. As a consequence, they are able to compete for borrowings at a beneficial rate because they know that, although they are borrowing at 18 per cent or 19 per cent, when it is written off against their tax liability they may be paying as little as 11 per cent or 12 per cent. Of course, they could also afford to borrow more, thereby feeling able to bid more at auction or to pay more for homes. Generally, this is pushing up housing prices, not at the $4m mansion level, but in the ordinary domestic home market.

One needs to ask why the Government is doing all this. The answer lies largely in the fact that for the last few decades Australian governments have operated on several economic theories which, if they were ever relevant to this country, most certainly are no longer relevant. Most of them can be detected in this year's budgetary planning, including that most favourite of all theories held dear by economic theorists, the trickle down effect. This argument has been pursued for decades by such international economic luminaries as Enoch Powell, when he was Minister of Housing in Britain. It is based on the theory that if governments encourage only the wealthy to become more wealthy, by giving them all sorts of tax concessions, by deregulating or by letting them go their own way with little hindrance, sooner or later the benefits of that will trickle down, will seep down, will flow down, to the less economically well off. If that happens at all, it certainly happens later rather than sooner. In the meantime, a lot of people are left in significant poverty.

The trickle down effect did not work for Britain in the 1960s when people like Powell were pushing the argument in health, housing and other welfare areas, and it certainly will not work for Australia in the 1980s. Yet, we have in power at the moment a government which sets its priorities in favour of those who are already able to look after themselves. In 1988, for example, the Government, with the enthusiastic support of the Opposition, offered a $2 billion benefit to Australian companies-some of the biggest of which were already paying no tax-by cutting further company taxes. A 20 per cent tax cut was given to Australia's companies by cutting the company tax rate from 49c in the dollar to 39c in the dollar at a time when some of the biggest companies in the country were working the system, to an extent that no ordinary family can, so that they were paying no tax at all. What this means is that in coming years these companies will be in the negative tax bracket and the Government, that is the taxpayers, will be returning to them large amounts of money.

In this year's Budget all that the Government could offer to pensioners was a $2 a week increase. This goes only some small way to helping them catch up on some fairly disastrous 1986 budgetary decisions which also went through with the support of the Liberal and National parties, namely, delaying the consumer price index (CPI) increases for pensioners, discounting the ex-serviceman's pension increases, telling 45-year-old women on class B widows' pensions that once their youngest child reaches the age of 16 he or she has to get a job or get unemployment benefits, and cutting Austudy for 15-year-olds in their last two years of school. None of these decisions hurt those on high incomes and all of them significantly disadvantaged the worst off in the country.

I suspect that the reason for this odd set of priorities lies in the myths that surround and support the economic debate in Australia, myths which among other things have people believing that Australia is a country which is excessively taxed, which is a welfare state and overpays its workers, thereby making us non-competitive on international markets. Newspapers, for example, give headlines to a petulant American rating agency like Moody's Investors Service Inc. when it arbitrarily drops Australia's credit rating but ignores comments by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) questioning the validity of this reduction. The media runs stories from business leaders claiming that Australia's wages are ridiculously high but do not ever ask: In comparison to whom? They publish unchallenged statements from other businessmen that Australia has to get in line with the rest of the world as far as welfare payments and wages are concerned without asking: Which countries of the rest of the world? I suspect that in the case of people like John Elliott we know the answer to that question: he means the Philippines. Those sorts of people who are writing those sorts of stories, with very few exceptions, write about company executives threatening to go overseas unless Australia's tax and welfare payments are lowered without asking where those companies can go in the world to get a better tax break or to pay lower wages other than to Third World countries.

We hear in Parliament and elsewhere that Australia is going down the economic gurgler because we have a current account deficit and, until recently, a domestic deficit. Why? As a senior official from the OECD pointed out this morning on AM, Australia is almost unique in the world only in that it has a domestic surplus. So why the criticism of Australia as being worst off compared to the rest of the world? Britain, the United States of America, most European countries and Japan all have gross public debts higher than Australia's. The answer to our record current account deficit is, therefore, not to be found in further cuts to public expenditure, despite what the Opposition and its spokespeople out in the business community would have us believe. The problem for Australia lies in the fact that successive governments have encouraged private foreign borrowings and have failed to encourage savings. In this way, of course, they could not be more different from a country such as Japan which recognised two things after World War II: firstly, that it had to move from being a rural based economy to an industrial-based economy and, secondly, that this required cheap money for investment and that in turn required the Government to encourage savings by not taxing the interest on those savings. That was based on yet another decision taken by the Japanese Government which has never been taken by any government in this country and that is that is has to look beyond the next election for solutions and results. In this country, if governments and the business community cannot come up with a scheme for building the world's best mouse-trap by tomorrow, they do not make any attempt to build one at all. It is quite different from countries such as Japan and West Germany which faced huge restructuring problems of the sort I hope Australia never has to face and which made a determined attempt to solve those problems over a 30 to 50 year period. It did it by establishing management-worker relationships that most people in this country would give their right arm for.

The fact is that despite Moody's, despite comments from the knockers, Australia has exhibited very high rates of economic growth by comparison to other western world countries. Employment has grown at almost twice the OECD average and private domestic consumption is well down. We also spend less on social welfare as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) than any other industrialised nation, and have a lower tax than almost all of them. In addition, Australia's wages system and its system of other benefits to workers are less than those in most other countries.

I think it is worth while looking at a comparison between some of Australia's workers and workers in a country against which we compete, from which we import goods, to which we try to export goods and the culture of which is somewhat similar to ours. If we look at a country such as West Germany, which had a restructuring problem after the War and which produces goods similar to those which we produce here, we will see that the facts are quite different from those which the myth pushers would have us believe. If we look at salaries, for example, we will see that a worker in the automotive industry in Australia earns $US14,300. A car worker in Frankfurt earns $US22,600-nearly a third more. Workers in West Germany do not work longer hours than their Australian counterparts. They get more holidays-five weeks in comparison to Australia's four. They get an additional five days leave each year in order to care for a child under the age of 8. They get a 47 per cent leave loading on their five weeks annual leave. Australia gets 17 1/2 per cent. In West Germany maternity leave is paid in the private sector and it is looking at paternity leave. In addition, a woman who comes back to work after taking maternity leave is given time off for nursing. So let us not pretend that our wages system in this country makes us non-competitive with similar countries. Let us not pretend that we are not productive enough because we have four weeks annual leave and that we have 10 public holidays a year. West Germany, I point out, has more than that. Let us not pretend that we coddle our workers by giving them a 17 1/2 per cent leave loading and that no other country in the world does. This is simply not the case. If we want increases in productivity in Australia we need to take a leaf out of the books of those countries which have good management-worker relations, hence worker loyalty and high productivity. The alternative for Australia, of course, is to engineer a huge pool of unemployed of the sort that allows Third World countries to keep wages low and workers in a constant state of fear of losing their jobs, hence in a constant state of stress. I hope that nobody seriously considers that that is an option for Australia.

Far more attention should be paid not to the perceived or alleged high level of wages in this country but to the high levels of interest rates which are currently crippling both home buyers and many businesses, and to the fact that our private sector foreign debt continues to rise. Senator Stone mentioned during his speech the whole issue of high interest rates and criticised the Government, as indeed I did yesterday, for not doing anything to reduce that. I think it is important to recognise that there is a connection between a current account deficit, between our trade deficit, between the encouragement which we are deliberately undertaking as a country for increased foreign investment in Australia and the high interest rates that are currently facing Australian families and forcing many of them out of their homes.

In our haste to achieve a bigger surplus we also forget that a surplus is achieved at somebody's expense. Either somebody pays more in tax or someone else gets less of a particular service so the Government can cut expenditure. While everybody is always happy to point out who should be paying more tax or who does not deserve a particular service very few people are prepared to make that sacrifice themselves. So by urging a government to produce a bigger surplus, as many in the business community have, people are in effect leaving it up to the Government to decide where the money will come from, and, of course, in the last few years it has come from cuts to social security, health and education; areas that impact most significantly on people in low income areas.

The Treasurer now is bringing forward into this financial year some of the tax remittances that some companies would be paying in the next financial year so that he can brag, as Senator Stone said, about the size of his surplus. In doing so, he will achieve the surplus. Of that there is no doubt at all. We will get at least a $9.1 billion surplus but what has the Government done in all of this about the other problems we face in the economy-inflation, the current account deficit and the foreign debt?

I think it is also worth remembering that a Budget surplus represents opportunities forgone. Some of the $9.1 billion could have been used to provide a better education system, a better health system, mortgage relief to home buyers or assistance to our exporters who are competing against subsidised goods from the United States and the European Economic Community and, of course, to protect them in some way from the trade barriers erected by so-called free trading nations such as the United States and Japan. Australia at the moment is trying to go it alone in what it is trying to argue ought to be a free market global economy. It is trying to remove the protection that we have traditionally offered to our traditional money earners in this country, that is the rural sector, as our major exporting unit, and it is doing it in the face of no decrease at all in the protections offered by the United States and by European countries to their exporters. Maybe we ought to be looking at some of the non-tariff barriers that those other countries are raising against our goods and undertaking a little bit of retribution. While that may not sound like the polite thing to do it is unquestionably the economically sensible one.

Perhaps the most important initiatives outlined in the Budget Speech were in the retirement incomes area. We are, of course, still waiting for specific details of how the changes to the reasonable benefits limits and the new rules on vesting and preservation will affect the plans of people who are about to retire as well as, of course, future retirees. However, it seems that in this area at least the Government has finally decided to implement policies designed to encourage Australians to save for their retirement. In this way, of course, we can reduce the burden of supporting an ageing population through the social security system, although I have to point out again that it is not excessive in global terms. The Government's proposal to encourage saving is a tax driven one which means less money will be going into Consolidated Revenue and this in itself is only the other side of the outlays coin. The Australian Democrats are certainly attracted to the broad thrust of the changes to encourage private pensions, that is annuities, to integrate the tax and social welfare system and to encourage more savings through superannuation. But I think it is important that nobody gets too enthusiastic about this until we have seen the proposals.

The Treasurer has also foreshadowed the possibility of wage increases being paid as superannuation along the lines of the 1986 productivity award. Again, it is worthwhile pointing out here that in most other countries, particularly European countries, there is a much more significant contribution to superannuation by both employers and employees than has ever applied in this country. Paying increases in the form of superannuation of course contributes to national savings, reduces the inflationary impact of direct wage increases and gives Australian workers the possibility of some degree of self-sufficiency in their retirement, just as long as, of course, some other government down the track does not decide to do what the Menzies Government did in the early 1950s after a wartime Labor Government tried to institute through the tax system a national form of superannuation and undo the whole lot, simply absorbing it into Consolidated Revenue.

There is some prospect of longer term savings through superannuation savings and planning in this country. This may just bring us in line with some other countries. As I said a moment ago, most other Western countries have had in existence for decades a much more extensive self-funding superannuation system. In France, for example, employees contribute over 12 per cent of GDP to the social security system and in that country a person is entitled to a pension at 80 per cent of his last year's salary once he turns 60. This compares considerably more than favourably with what Australia gives it retirees at the age of 65, and I might point out that in France, as in most other European countries, this amount is indexed for inflation. In Japan workers contribute 4.4 per cent of gross domestic product into the social security system and this helps that country fund a retirement system whereby a Japanese worker retiring at the age of 60 is entitled to a pension equal to average weekly earnings. In this country we are still struggling to bring pension levels above 25 per cent of average weekly earnings.

Again, I remind honourable senators that Japanese wages and salaries are higher, as they are in West Germany and in most other countries, than in Australia which brings me back to the point about the myths that abound in the media and the community regarding the Australian economy and, in particular, our competitiveness on world markets. We frequently hear from those who consider themselves to be captains of industry that Australia ought, as I said earlier, to get with the rest of the world on things like wages and working conditions, that we are a welfare state, that our public debt is crippling us, that our economic growth is too low, our trade deficit is too high, job creation is limited, and we are overtaxed. In fact, none of those things are correct. Our major problems do not lie in any of these areas. Instead they can be linked to four other problems. All decisions made in this country are short term ones; whether they are made by government or the private sector, everybody blames everybody else for whatever goes wrong; as a nation we are simply not saving enough and hence investing enough local money for cheaper borrowings by developers; and fourthly, the foreign investment profit outflow cycle is hitting new and ever more wondrous heights each year.

Both the myths and the actualities have been reflected in the 1989-90 Budget. The first has resulted in the extraordinary efforts that the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) have made to record yet again a significant surplus. The second is reflected in the long overdue proposal to encourage long term savings and, hence, to reduce domestic consumption by providing incentives for people to plan for their own retirement income. As both Senator Stone and I have already said, the surplus is in many ways a cosmetic benefit. It will impress those people who believe that a government is a competent, good economic manager if it has a domestic surplus. Mind you, where this leaves other countries in the world such as the United States, the United Kingdom and most European countries, which regularly have economic deficits, is anybody's guess. However, it is good news for surplus worshippers and may put an end, if only temporarily, to some of the gloom and doom stories about Australia's economic position in comparison to our major trading partners.

I return to Senator Stone's comments about high interest rates hurting ordinary Australians and keeping the dollar high. It is worth while pointing out that, while he criticises this, he failed to point out that this policy of the Government is a deliberate response to demands from economic rationalists for increased foreign investment in Australia to offset private sector foreign borrowings. To the Australian Democrats, a more preferable option would be to pull back or inhibit private sector foreign borrowings by removing negative gearing on overseas financed investment. The effect of lower interest rates would be beneficial to our trade problems. As I tried to explain to Senator Button yesterday during Question Time, the higher the dollar, the lower the price of imported goods, with the result that there is more likely to be high domestic consumption of imported goods. Also, of course, the higher the dollar, the higher the cost of our exports on overseas markets. Bringing down the dollar reduces private sector foreign borrowings and, miraculously, will see a drop in our current account deficit, because our foreign debt will fall and export income will better balance import payouts.

In addition, the Government failed in this Budget to offer incentives to our exporters competing, as I said, with subsidised European Economic Community and United States products. We cannot continue to pretend that this is a free market that we are operating in; it is not, and every year the United States Farm Bill makes matters worse. All in all, this Budget is best described as a trick, a con and a continued kowtowing to economic rationalists which will prolong most of our economic problems and will not improve in any real way at all the financial situation of most Australians.
Debate (on motion by Senator Cook) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 August, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week we were debating in some detail the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill. As I mentioned a week last Friday when I first started to speak on this legislation, it is a shame that the Government has rammed this through the House of Representatives without due consideration, because it is a very important Bill concerning the restructuring of Aboriginal administration. Unfortunately, I believe the Bill is fundamentally flawed. Apart from a number of other reasons, it confuses advocacy with administration, and welfare with self-help. Aboriginal Australians will have to adapt to the structure as opposed to the reverse. To me, this Bill is an exercise in political self-indulgence and could well and truly open the door to racial divisions upheld by the legal force.

SPEECH.PARA: It is right and proper that Australians should strive to enable disadvantaged fellow Australians to attain basic levels of health, education and self-management. It is quite another thing to surrender to a guilt industry denigrating our Western heritage that made possible the development of this country and, like it or not, that provides the wherewithal to assist Aboriginal Australians. The neurotic guilt finds expression in calls not for freely given help, but for compensation, and in such puerile actions as the boycott of Bicentennial functions by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). It does nothing to raise Aboriginal living standards, and is inimical to creating better understanding.

I take strong issue with the statement contained in the preamble that, as a consequence of these and subsequent deprivations, Aboriginals have become the most disadvantaged group in our society, dispossessed without compensation. I do take strong issue with that, and I am sure most Australians would join with me in that. It is highly arguable that the Western concept of land ownership should be applied to Aboriginals' links with land, and certainly unjust that the divisive question of land rights should be intruded into legislation that is supposedly-and I emphasise the word `supposedly'-concerned with the delivery of services to Aboriginal Australians.

The Opposition remains to be satisfied that a preamble to an Act of Parliament can somehow have no possible legal force, and cannot foreseeably be used to give legal standing to claims for land, or any other form of unspecified compensation for one group of Australians on the basis of race. While the Government maintains that the preamble lacks legal force, it does not provide legal opinions to this effect. It would stretch credibility to imagine that, in some future High Court challenge to obtain Aboriginal land rights, the present Minister for Aboriginal Affairs would deny that his preamble was meaningless in law.

I must reiterate the gross irresponsibility of intruding into the preamble the term `self-determination', which is either meaningless and a fraud or actually connotes the right of a group of Australians to attain the fantasy dreamed up by Mansell and his cohorts of a self-governing Aboriginal state. That is of great concern. It should never be allowed to come to pass. Yet this Government is actually condoning what Mansell has advocated. The intentions of this Labor Government may be one thing, but the effects of this Bill may be another. It may be too late before Australians realise the reality of that.

It is not alarmist to canvass these possibilities when we look across the Tasman and see how Maori extremists, and their well-paid lawyers, use the ramshackle 1840 Treaty of Waitangi as the basis for demands for vast tracts of Crown land, for rights over the billion dollar New Zealand fishing industry, and for other privileges in a spirit of inverted racism. When one talks to New Zealanders they universally now express concern at how far the Government has gone with the Maori community and on what basis they have gone to those extremes.

This mischief, threatening racial harmony, has been powerfully assisted by the action of the New Zealand Labour Government in passing the Waitangi Tribunal Amendment Act in 1985, opening up the possibility of massive retrospective claims. I have been speaking in the past few months to New Zealanders who now live in Perth and who have expressed that concern at how powerful the Maoris have now become and been condoned by the Government to the exclusion of the rest of the New Zealand community. This Parliament should, therefore, exercise extreme caution before incorporating generalised and emotive language into practical legislation. Either it achieves nothing or it does all Australians harm. That is the choice with which we are confronted with this legislation.

I am proud to support the Aboriginal affairs policy of the coalition that has as its aim the promotion of Aboriginal self-sufficiency in place of dependence, and their participation in the mainstream of national life. It is very much our intention to increase the proportion of funds that actually reach those Aboriginal Australians in need and, through our underlying policy of cooperative federalism, end the duplication of services, which not only costs the Aboriginal community an enormous amount of money but also costs the taxpayers generally a lot of money. To this end, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs will play a reduced coordinating role and a revised Aboriginal Development Commission will work to achieve self-management and enterprise, and this is all a far cry from what we are seeing in this Bill before the Senate today.

We will encourage better consultative mechanisms so that Aborigines can advise service providers as to their local needs, but we also believe that representation is best achieved through participation in the mainstream democratic system. For these reasons, as a Liberal I cannot support a Bill establishing an unworkable bureaucratic hybrid, dressed up in the language of guilt and division, foisted upon Australian Aborigines by devious and cynical means, and likely to leave effective power with a government and a Minister who have demonstrated both authoritarianism and irresponsibility.

Mr Acting Deputy President, this Bill is fundamentally flawed. There has been insufficient consultation with the Aboriginal communities. The Minister has been quite determined to ensure that this does not happen in terms of the consultation, and I think it is time that this Senate rejected this piece of legislation and accepted it for what it is worth in that rejection, because it is not going to benefit the Aboriginal community at all. I would respectfully suggest that some of those who have made a contribution from the Government side actually get out there into the Aboriginal communities, talk with some of the Aboriginal people and see what it is they want, because it is certainly not this Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill and it is certainly not what is going to be foisted upon them as a result of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989 is one of the most important proposals for change in Aboriginal affairs that we have seen in this Parliament. I believe that it is misconstrued and that it is an unwise change, and I am totally opposed to it. I do not trust the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and I do not believe that his deception in the construction of this Bill has been sufficiently widely perceived by the Aboriginal communities of Australia, nor by the public of Australia, nor even by his own colleagues in the Government.
