What is the relationship between the Tribunal and the Government? What has been the Government's response to the Tribunal's decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday of this week, 28 August, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal delivered a final judgment on the levels of remuneration for pharmacists under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). The PBRT has called for a major restructuring of the PBS and the way in which pharmacists are remunerated. This is not a Government decision. Nor does the Government have the power under the legislation to overturn or alter the decision.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Walters ought to understand that, because she has been obfuscating this point. It is an independent tribunal and, by sullying its independence, I believe Senator Walters is indeed committing a libel. Most pharmacists, unfortunately, and some journalists, do not understand the independence of the body.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Stone interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop prattling away, Senator Stone. The PBRT reached its decision after a two-year inquiry and 600 submissions. Contrary to some reports, the Government submission did not suggest any preferred fee level but rather concentrated on the need for structural reform. The proposal is entirely the PBRT's affair. It is effectively the umpire's decision. The Tribunal recommended substantial changes to the system of payments because the subsidies now provided to pharmacists to cover the costs of providing PBS drugs were not supported by the data supplied to the Tribunal. In other words, the PBRT has found that the payment system to cover the costs of dispensing PBS drugs was excessive. As a result, the payment per service will be reduced by a total of $1.05 per item in three stages over 12 months. The abolition of the 25 per cent mark-up on PBS items is included in this figure.

ANSWER.PARA: Earlier this year the Minister, Peter Staples, and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia were on the point of finalising negotiations to present a united submission to the Tribunal. However, at literally the last minute, the Guild broke off negotiations and decided to go it alone. This is the result of that. Had the Guild accepted the Government's offer to reach a negotiated agreement, there would have been scope for overcoming several of the major structural problems in the PBS. Unfortunately, the Guild strategy to go it alone has backfired badly for its members.

I remind the Senate that the PBRT was established under the Fraser Liberal Government. In fact, this very independent body was a key element in the former Liberal Government's thinking when it set up the PBRT. As Mr MacKellar said when introducing the PBRT legislation in 1981:

The Government believes that there are a number of advantages to be gained by establishing a public tribunal. First, it will remove from the political arena the question of the level of fees paid to chemists and for dispensing of pharmaceutical benefits. Both the chemists and the Government will be bound by the tribunal's decision. Secondly it will provide a forum in which all interested parties may publicly argue their case whilst ensuring that the levels of chemists' remuneration are determined by an independent body. Thirdly, it will remove the need for the Government to finance cumbersome and costly inquiries of the sort that have been conducted since 1964-1965.

I conclude by saying that the door remains open to pharmacists to resume useful negotiations with the Government at any time. In fact, it is my understanding that the Minister responsible, my colleague Peter Staples, is meeting the Pharmacy Guild of Australia tomorrow. If there is a postscript to my concluding comment, it is the report of the Tribunal. Last night we saw a senator in this place from the Opposition ranks, who had not read this report, leap to comment and editorialise about it. This inquiry has lasted a long time and taken a lot of submissions. The very least the critics can do is actually read what the inquiry found.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to media reports indicating that the Government has stopped processing applications for refugee status made by Chinese students in Australia in the wake of the crushing of the pro-democracy movement in Beijing. What does this decision mean for Chinese students in Australia? Given that they are not refugees and not residents, what rights and privileges will they enjoy until their visas expire in July 1990? For example, what is their standing with respect to Medicare treatment in Australia. Does it mean that graduate students will be ineligible for Austudy? I refer the Minister to a letter I wrote to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training in which I suggested that the Government assist students to complete a diploma of education while they are here so that they may fill the many available positions for Asian language teachers in Australia. What is the Government's attitude to these types of proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it would not surprise Senator Macklin that many of the reports he reads are often not the truth. The ones that Senator Macklin has read in this case certainly are a long way from the mark. Most senators would be aware, of course, that all Chinese nationals legally in Australia on 4 June were permitted to extend their entry permits to 31 July 1990. Those who are here illegally, whilst not permitted to extend their permits, are not being required to leave at this time. I think these arrangements were very generous for the People's Republic of China (PRC) nationals, because they were granted irrespective of their circumstances. To the extent that some PRC nationals may wish to seek refugee status in Australia, these provisions at least afford a temporary protection for those individuals.

ANSWER.PARA: As of 18 August, almost 5,500 Chinese had extended their entry permits under the special provisions. At the same time some 9,500 changed to resident status applications and some 5,700 refugee status applications had been distributed. The number of applications so far lodged is some 270 and 100 respectively. We as a Department are not encouraging people to rush in at the moment with these applications until the situation in China becomes more clear cut. But it should not be taken that because people do not apply immediately that in any way lessens their long term claims. The honourable senator asks what sort of privileges do these individuals have, for instance, on the question of the right to work. All PRC nationals have been given the right to work. The only restriction is those who are currently undergoing a course. They may be limited to 20 hours a week. Otherwise they have the right to work whether they are here legally or illegally. Normal eligibility conditions apply for special benefits. My colleague the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, through his powers under the Health Insurance Act, has declared that PRC nationals in Australia temporarily on 4 June who have chosen not to return to the PRC at present will be covered by Medicare from that time until the entry permits cease.

On the final matter, which is not a matter for my portfolio again-the question of eligibility for Austudy-the honourable senator would, of course, be aware that at this stage it is only available for those people who are Australian citizens or permanent residents in Australia. Nevertheless, I am advised that Mr Dawkins has undertaken to give the honourable senator a response to his letter which raises these matters. No doubt it is somewhat delayed because he is on sick leave at the moment, but at some stage in the near future I hope he can get back to the honourable senator with a full answer on the question of Austudy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Walsh as the Minister representing the Treasurer. If an individual accepts bribes consisting of items or services such as the provision of an aircraft hanger, the refurbishment of a tip truck, or maintenance of major items of earthworking equipment such as a D9 bulldozer, are those items or services assessable as income for taxation purposes? If so, would the tax liability fall on a family company if the items or services were transferred to it? If an individual or family company failed to declare such tax liabilities would that constitute a breach of the Income Tax Assessment Act for which the individual or directors of the company would be liable for prosecution? Is the Australian Taxation Office pursuing the taxation ramifications of allegations of bribery made on last Monday night's program of Channel Nine's A Current Affair?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last part of the question, the secrecy provisions in section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act preclude the Commissioner of Taxation from disclosing any information about what investigations or assessments are being issued to individuals. So I cannot, therefore, answer that part of the question which asked whether the Taxation Office was following this matter up or what is it going to do about it, or words to that effect.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the other parts of the questions I have with me a private sector publication called the Australian Master Tax Guide. This is a private sector publication and not a publication of the Australian Tax Office. Nevertheless, it is regarded as being reputable and reliable, I think, by the Tax Office and by almost everybody else. On pages 307 and 309 of that publication, the matters raised by Senator Schacht are dealt with. In general-again, without commenting on these specific items to which Senator Schacht referred-bribes are, for income tax purposes, taken as assessable income. Whether a family company would be liable for the tax would depend on the relationship of the individual to the company and the nature of the transfer of items and services to it. Failure to declare as taxable income such bribes of that nature would be an offence under the Income Tax Act. I do not want to say anything in relation to the matters which were telecast by Channel Nine on Monday night. Indeed, I believe it would be quite improper for me to comment on those matters because it might prejudice somebody or other getting a fair trial. I believe that Mr Ahern acted very properly in referring those matters to the appropriate authorities in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations. Will the Minister give an undertaking to support the use of legal sanctions against any Australian Council of Trade Unions affiliate which might engage in conduct similar to that of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, such as the recent shutdown of the Melbourne waterfront?
—The answer to that question is no, and there are a variety of reasons for that. The first reason is that--
—You haven't got permission from Kelty; that is why.

—That is what Senator Puplick may think, but that is not necessarily relevant. The answer to the question is simply that the parties involved in the waterfront dispute are subject to the jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Commission. They are organisations of employers and employees and are subject to that jurisdiction. You cannot draw an analogy with the pilots dispute-what Senator Lewis calls the pilots strike-because the pilots are not subject to the jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Commission. They have taken themselves outside that jurisdiction. Therefore, the only remedies available are not ones of formal conciliation; they are not ones of formal processes of reconciliation; they are ones which are available at common law or available in terms of the provisions of the trade practices legislation. Those are the remedies which are being used by the airlines in connection with the pilots dispute. That is a different matter from the issue which the honourable senator raised.

—Has the Minister for Consumer Affairs seen recent reports which demonstrate the valuable counselling and advocacy work which is conducted by financial counsellors? Can the Minister indicate whether the Federal Government is in a position to offer support for financial counselling services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have in fact seen some reports, I think more particularly arising out of Melbourne, in recent weeks where financial counsellors and financial counselling organisations have been at the forefront of protecting and asserting the rights of individuals in their relationships with credit organisations. That advocacy work is one part of the work that they conduct which is quite valuable. Senator Zakharov also mentioned counselling work, which is important.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the other area of work that they undertake, which is also vitally important, is research work. As part of the Government's general concern and commitment in this area we did amend the Bankruptcy Act to the extent that there will now be an obligation on registrars to ensure that debtors have been referred to sources of financial advice before they formally and irrevocably go bankrupt. That particular role of financial counsellors in that situation is also one that was acknowledged by the Parliament.

Having acknowledged the importance of these services, we also feel that there is a commitment to assist organisations and counsellors, and more particularly individuals, who need to rely on the services of such personnel. The Budget provided an allocation of $1m for a financial counselling program. It is a program which has been jointly developed by me and the Minister for Social Security, Mr Brian Howe, particularly to address the problems of low income families and other social security clients and recipients. There is very much an area of need-one that the Government has recognised-that should be a priority for Government consideration. That need is recognised as being exacerbated and heightened when there are deaths. In that respect, older social security clients and recipients are the ones we are looking at helping with the financial counselling program. Those people need greater assistance in traumatic situations such as when there is a death in the family. That circumstance leads to more expense, and greater assistance in the management of their financial affairs is required.

The problem that we have federally is that this responsibility has been met by the States and some States have met it in a much more comprehensive way than others. Some States do not provide enough, if any, assistance. Financial counselling services are particularly required in rural areas; in capital cities those services may be supplied by government. With the $1m allocation we will isolate the areas of need; we will locate them and address the need. In doing so, we will acknowledge the continuing role of the States and the continuing commitment and responsibility they need to have. We will examine ways of ensuring that the commitment can be maintained, if not developed.

The other part of the Government's response is in cooperation with the credit industry and credit providers. Some time ago I announced the formation of a task force, consisting of representatives of consumer and industry groups. The task of that task force will be to prepare detailed guidelines for a credit education and research foundation. I anticipate, as, I think, do all involved in the task force, that the foundation will provide assistance to financial counselling networks and to the industry along the lines of education and research material. That task force is still meeting. I anticipate that by the end of the year it should have provided us with some guidelines.

In conclusion, in response to Senator Zakharov's question, the Government recognises the need for and the valuable role played by financial counselling organisations and we are addressing particular and diverse ways of assisting them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce that in attempting to defend the Government's punitive Budget decision concerning accelerated payment of company tax he quoted one line from a Business Council of Australia publication. That line states:

QUESTION.PARA: A number of options are available to further spread out PAYE, company and provisional tax receipts.

Senator Button claimed that the Business Council must have fully comprehended that the Budget decision was one of the options available. Now that I have had time to examine the Business Council document, I ask the Minister: is he aware that the option of forcing early payment of company tax was not even mentioned-except in that one line-in the options canvassed by the Council, let alone anything as specific as the Budget decision to require 85 per cent payment within 15 days of the end of the financial year? Why did the Minister in his answer so blatantly misrepresent the Business Council's position? Is the Minister aware that Mr Brian Loton, speaking on behalf of the Council, has strongly criticised the decision and the massive impact it will have on both the corporate sector and the financial markets? Given the continuing level of alarm within the business community at this new measure, coming so soon after the recent change to quarterly tax collections for corporations, will the Government now consider amending this harsh and impractical decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will certainly take on board the last part of Senator Watson's question. All these issues are always examined. I do not promise Senator Watson any joy in terms of the solution, but there is always a willingness to examine these decisions. I took the Thespian burden of Senator Watson's question to be the suggestion that in some way I misled Parliament. I am aware that the honourable senator phoned the Business Council about this question. The Council phoned me and we had a discussion about it. I am quite aware of all that. But what I said on the relevant day was that the Business Council had said:

ANSWER.PARA: A number of options are available to further spread out PAYE, company and provisional tax receipts.
That can be found in Hansard of 18 August. It is precisely what the Business Council said. I went on to say:
That statement by the Business Council must have fully comprehended that this was one of the options available.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—In the context of that same answer-if I might give this one without interruption-I referred to a number of other countries where the burden on companies in terms of early payment of company tax is still considerably more severe than it is here.
—Just be careful on that.

—I am being very careful, as I was the last time I answered this question from the honourable senator and as he was not in seeking histrionically to misrepresent the position in his question a minute or so ago. I said that it must have been one of the options comprehended by the Business Council. An officer of the Business Council told me this morning that the Council had meant provisional tax when it made the comment, but it said:

ANSWER.PARA: A number of options are available to further spread out PAYE, company and provisional tax receipts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then it went on to list the options, didn't it?
—It did not go to list the options. Senator Watson should understand the English language, even though he comes from Tasmania. The Council did not put the options.
—Apologise to the Tasmanians. What about Coates? Apologise to Coates.
—Order!

—Mr President, I refer only to the indigenous dialect in Tasmania. Senator Watson should understand the English language and realise that the word `including' is different from the word `options'. The `including' gave examples.
—Which didn't include companies.

—Quite; it did not include companies. Why would the Business Council, representing the 80 largest companies in Australia, lead with its chin and put companies in its examples? But it did say, as I quoted, that the spread of taxes could be handled in respect of PAYE, company and provisional tax receipts. That is quite clear. We will look at the last part of the question. I would not get too excited about the first part.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AUTHORITY

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories been drawn to a press report of a tourist vessel being seized in north Queensland? Is it true that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority seized a tourist vessel from Sunlover Cruises, a company that operates from Cairns? If so, how long will the boat be held and why did the Authority refuse permission for Sunlover Cruises to visit Green Island?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority seized a tourist boat from Sunlover Cruises. I am not sure of the actual day, but it happened some time in the last week. I can report that it has already been returned to its owners. Obviously, seizing a boat is a pretty tough action for the Authority to take, but it had to be taken because Sunlover Cruises had chosen to disregard the Authority by sending without a permit a number of boats to Green Island. The difficulty is that Green Island has been under rather intense tourist pressure now for some time. In fact, something like 250,000 people visit it each year. That has put great pressure on facilities such as sewerage. It is interesting to note that the Queensland Department of Conservation, with the Authority, has called for a moratorium on any future visits being agreed to. Until we can resolve some of the difficulties on Green Island with the pressure that 250,000 people are putting on it, both the Queensland Government and the Federal Government are as one on the question.

ANSWER.PARA: Sunlover Cruises has now accepted that it cannot continue operating to Green Island. The boat has been given back on condition that it abides by the permits that the Authority has given it. They include other places within the Marine Park but certainly not Green Island. Hopefully, we can, with the Queensland Government, resolve to do something about the environment on Green Island as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer him to Table C.1 on page 4.56 of Budget Paper No. 1. In that table the Minister will note that taxation on superannuation this year will amount to a massive $885m, whereas last year the Government's tax on superannuation was only $7m. This represents an increase in tax from this source alone of over 12,540 per cent or to be precise, 12,542.86 per cent in just one year. How does this enormous increase in Government revenue encourage working Australians to save through superannuation?

—The Leader of the Opposition asserted a couple of weeks ago-in fact, I think it is in his so-called Budget reply speech-that the Government had increased tax on superannuation by 100 per cent. Senator Walters has got that up to 12,542 per cent-I have forgotten what the decimal point was.
—Point 6.
—Point 6, was it? We know, of course, that the Leader of the Opposition, on his own admission, does not bring an accountant's mind to bear on preparing Budgets. Out of his own mouth he said that.
—At least he has got a mind.

—That is a good comment from Senator Ray. At least the Leader of the Opposition is not so innumerate that he has produced a figure of 12,542.6 per cent. The item to which Senator Walters referred comes principally from a decision to leave the total level of taxation on funded superannuation schemes as it was before but to change the timing of the collection of the tax. In other words, the funds will be taxed as the money comes in and taxed at a lower rate than previously as the money goes out. The net effect of that is, of course, neutral.
—Not entirely.

—Senator Watson is quite right; the net effect is actually slightly in favour of the person who ultimately is the beneficiary because one is effectively 15 per cent of 100 per cent and the other is 15 per cent of 85 per cent. What comes out at the other end is 85 per cent and it pays only a 15 per cent tax whereas previously it would have been a 30 per cent tax on 100 per cent. But that is getting much too complicated for Senator Walters to understand, I am sure. Senator Watson is quite right, however-of course it is well known that he is one of the few numerate people in the Opposition-in that the new arrangements ultimately slightly favour the people who are the beneficiaries of such schemes but they change the timing of the tax payments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I preface my question by referring the Minister to a statement which the Prime Minister made last year when he launched the National Agenda for Women. In that statement the Prime Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: A major time-use survey which would provide sound statistical data on women's multiple responsibilities would be carried out.

Although I do acknowledge that a preliminary pilot study of 700 households was carried out in Sydney last year to test the feasibility and methodology required for the major survey, this project appears to have come to a standstill since then. Does the Prime Minister intend to fulfil his promise to the women of Australia, particularly those women whose primary work focuses on the unpaid work force, and carry out this survey? If he does, when will the survey be undertaken? When the results of this survey are known, will the Government take the necessary steps to include the value of women's unpaid work, estimated recently by Melbourne University's Centre for Applied Research on the Future, to be $140 billion annually, for the purposes of calculating gross domestic product?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Powell is right. A trial survey was done in Sydney commencing in June 1987. The results were released in May 1988. Those trial results have been very useful in preparing for a fuller survey. The Prime Minister stands by his promise that a major time use survey will be undertaken and the Australian Bureau of Statistics is preparing its work schedule for 1990-91 to 1992-93-these things are always done substantially in advance-and that work program will include further work on time use.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the second part of the question, the Australian national accounts are compiled in accordance with recommendations in the United Nations document, a system of national accounts called SNA, which does not include unpaid household work in gross domestic product. The SNA has been developed to facilitate economic comparisons between different countries. It can do so only to the extent that countries follow its recommendations and, in line with this, Australia's national accounts do not include unpaid household work.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce? The Hughes report on Australian exports states:

QUESTION.PARA: The price of foreign exchange is the main policy determinant of the level of exports . . .

In view of the unsustainable level of our currency on a trade weighted index (TWI) basis, or as is demonstrated by the huge deficit between imports and exports, what measures in the Budget will work towards restoring our international competitiveness and our exporting capacity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to answer this question in much the same way as I did an earlier question today which relates more to the strategy of the Budget than particular measures. Of course, the strategy of the Budget is to continue the process of fiscal discipline for the time being, to continue present monetary policy with a view to reducing demand in the Australian economy and a range of measures which have been debated and discussed in the course of the Senate program since the Budget. Certainly Professor Hughes, in her review of the export market development grants scheme, touched on a number of issues which affect export propensity. She referred to a number of macro-economic issues of which the more fundamental ones, as I recall it, were monetary policy, the level of savings in the community and, of course, the issue to which Senator Archer refers, the level of the currency.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know-I do not think anybody does-whether a particular Australian dollar rate can be described as the optimum rate in terms of export activity. Of course, the currency has depreciated by some 12 per cent since earlier this year, having been a year or two ago at a considerably lower level. Senator Archer couches his question in terms of the trade weighted index. Although the Australian dollar is generally measured against the United States dollar, except for a period in 1985-86, the currency has been pretty stable as against the trade weighted index.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of our contracts are written in United States dollars.
—I understand that, but Senator Archer knows what he is talking about. He asked his question in terms of the TWI and I am answering it.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne's learning is vicarious here. Senator Archer asked the question.
—It is a very subjective judgment.

—I think the currency has been relatively stable in terms of the TWI. I think the discussion in the Hughes Review of Export Market Development Assistance on the export culture of this country is an interesting one and should be followed by other senators.

—I have a short supplementary question. In view of the fact that New Zealand is able to produce a trading surplus and has a currency value which is advantageous when trading with us and other countries in the world and intends to increase this, does it make it any easier for us to release the strings on our dollars a little bit to the point where we may be able to increase our trade, particularly our export trade, without running too much risk, as someone was bleating, to the unemployment question?
—It is important to remember that such successes, as the New Zealand economy has had, have been accompanied by enormous disruptions, distortions and difficulties for the New Zealand people.
—The OECD thinks it is good stuff.
—The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development commented on our economy this morning, and thought it was pretty good too.
—They think New Zealand is a lot better.

—I do not think the OECD has actually said that. The point is that I cannot speculate, on the basis of this question, as I said in my earlier answer, on what the appropriate dollar value would be. I do not think one can use the example of New Zealand very successfully here and say it is a success because this year it has a trade surplus and that is the be-all and end-all of the problem.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Recent media reports indicate that there has been a poor response to the affirmative action program stage 2. Is the Minister able to confirm whether these reports are correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been speculation in the media about the success of the affirmative action legislation and the reporting procedures. I am pleased to be able to report that the Affirmative Act Agency has advised that 90 per cent of all organisations have already--
—You answered it yesterday.
—You got the wrong file out.

—I am surprised that honourable senators on the other side of the chamber do not know the difference between the Affirmative Action Agency and equal employment opportunity in the Public Service. We are talking about the Affirmative Action Agency. Of 489 organisations identified as relevant employers for reporting, 450 have already lodged their reports, which is indicative of the success with which affirmative action is working. This figure includes 68 higher education institutions, all of which have reported.

ANSWER.PARA: All of the companies which have not yet complied with the legislation have been contacted by the Agency and letters advising them that they have 28 days in which to comply were posted on 14 August. The Affirmative Action Agency anticipates that at least half of all companies which receive these notices will produce reports. No one industry sector stands out among the late reports. I would like to make it quite clear that at this stage there is everything to be said for being satisfied with the rate of reporting. Certainly some are overdue, but I think there is every indication, on the experience of last year, that those companies which are currently outstanding will respond, given the 28 days notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the Minister to his reply yesterday to a question from a member of his own back bench regarding live sheep shipments to Saudi Arabia in which he told the Senate that rejected shipments have been taken by Kuwait and others. I ask the Minister: firstly, were the shipments sold to these other countries at the same price that was originally agreed to by Saudi Arabia, or was there a discount involved, and has he any idea where the sheep finally finished up? Secondly, what measures is the Government looking at, if any, in conjunction with our customers for live sheep, to do final testing before the shipments leave Australia so as to avoid the sorts of difficulties experienced by previous shipments on arrival at those ports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position, off the top of my head, to reply to the honourable senator on the question of price or whether there was a discount, but I will find out that information and reply to him. The significant point about my reply to that part of the question yesterday was that the sheep that had been turned away from the Saudi Arabian ports because of allegations of sheep pox and a number of other sheep disorders were accepted in other Arab ports free of those diseases after the veterinarians in those ports had inspected them. That was the particular point I wanted to make.
—We all know that. The question is: What are you doing about the problem in Saudi Arabia?

—Why does the honourable senator not contain himself for a few minutes? The element which is very important is that of the health and welfare of Australian sheep being presented to that market and the quality of the product we present to that market. That is the point I want to make. I will find out about the price and any discount in trading the sheep over there into other markets in the Persian Gulf.

ANSWER.PARA: Concerning the second part of the question, the sheep that leave Australia are inspected by veterinarians who are qualified to carry out that responsibility. All sheep that leave here are given a clean bill of health by them. In some cases, but not all, veterinarians have travelled on sheep ships. Indeed, one ship that was turned away from one of the ports in Saudi Arabia contained Australian veterinarians who could not, with their experience, find evidence of the disease that it was later alleged those sheep had.

I do not know of a way in which we are more able to guarantee the quality and disease-free status of sheep that leave this country than the inspection service that is in place now. I have read criticisms of that service, but I think those critics may well be operating on the basis of information which applied in their day, and not information that applies now, because there have been a number of procedural changes since some of those critics who have achieved notoriety were in the service of the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. If the Minister is not able to give me a method which can be put in place and by which sheep can be cleared out of Australia so that they will be accepted, why is he not at least working on the basis that sheep should be inspected on the ships when they get to port, at destination and not five days after they have been in the feed lot, where they could pick up local diseases?

—This is a fairly obscure issue that is being raised, because the way in which the sheep are inspected now and the quality of the delivery of the sheep that have gone to these markets, as accepted by other ports in other countries in the Persian Gulf, confirm our belief about their disease-free status. As far as the second element of that question is concerned, we have yet to see-because the Saudi Arabian authorities have not made it available-the evidence of their testing upon which they base the allegations of disease status. In view of that, I do not accept that the case of disease as alleged by the Saudi authorities is necessarily proven, and I do not think the honourable senator should accept it either. I do not know the reason for the refusal of those sheep, and I think that has been a view expressed by Mr Kerin and Mr Duffy. We are mystified and puzzled as to why they are rejected. The honourable senator seems to ask how we can ensure that the sheep get into those markets and are not rejected. That is a mystery question that I cannot answer. I do not think the honourable senator can answer it and neither, I think, can anyone else from his side.
—I asked you whether they were tested five days after they were in the sheep lot.

—In terms of the procedures we have, which we have re-examined in view of this incident, we are entirely satisfied that the procedures we put our sheep through ought to guarantee their acceptance in those markets. Until we can see the results of the Saudi investigations and until we can make a complete evaluation, I think it is wrong to start making allegations that we are somehow at fault. Having looked at our procedures, we are satisfied that we are not at fault. I suggest that the honourable senator should ask himself, if he gives rise to such allegations, what damage he is doing to Australian agricultural trade overseas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, on 29 August, Senator Chapman asked me a question about the proportion of wool purchased at auction in the financial year 1988-89 by the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC). I undertook to obtain an answer to the honourable senator's question as quickly as possible. The proportion of wool purchased at auction by the Australian Wool Corporation in1988-89 was 5.2 per cent of the total offering. The rate of AWC purchases was 16.4 per cent in June 1989 and 39.2 per cent in July 1989, and amounts to approximately 45.3 per cent so far this month. That tallies with some of the figures in the honourable senator's question. But the annual wool selling season commences in July each year and tends to follow a seasonal pattern. Traditionally, demand is weaker in the earlier months of each selling season because overseas buyers are not normally as active then, with many processors being closed during the height of the northern summer season.

ANSWER.PARA: So far this season the trade has purchased approximately the same quantity of wool as at the same stage of the season last year. However, increased production of wool, coupled with delays in shearing because of wet weather at the end of last season, has resulted in an increased volume of wool being put on the market in recent weeks. Buyers therefore have greater choice in their purchases. In addition, high overseas stockpiles, notably in Japan, have resulted in reduced activity by Japanese buyers. China and Russia are also not active in the market at present, primarily because of foreign currency shortages. However, the Australian Wool Corporation expects both China and Russia to re-enter the market in the coming months, and as overseas stockpiles are reduced other overseas buyers will become more active, which is expected to result in the market moving more in the seller's favour.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HMAS PERTH: DISPOSAL OF WASTE OIL

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Puplick asked me a question about the dumping of waste oil in Sydney. I was asked first whether I was aware that 15,000 litres of waste oil was illegally dumped into the Sydney sewerage system by a contractor to the Garden Island naval dockyard. The actual figure is 5,000 litres of oily waste from HMAS Perth. It was a normal activity, carried out under a legal contract with a licensed contractor in accordance with New South Wales State regulation. The contract is with the Department of Defence and not with the Garden Island dockyard. Next I was asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that this contractor has been under investigation by the Sydney Water Board and the New South Wales waste management authority for previous illegal dumping activities?

The Royal Australian Navy is not aware of any previous illegal dumping activity by this contractor. However, the Navy was aware that the Metropolitan Waste Disposal Authority was investigating the activities of this contractor and other contractors and the Navy had been cooperating fully with the Metropolitan Waste Disposal Authority in that investigation since May. That entailed the Navy providing full details of the quantities and type of waste removal from ships and establishments. Using that data, the Metropolitan Waste Disposal Authority then found discrepancies with its disposal data, which caused it to investigate further. The Navy did not receive a letter dated 7 June from the New South Wales Government on this question, and the Defence regional office has no record of the letter either.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a copy of the letter here.

—Yes, we got a copy of it this morning. We asked the New South Wales Government for it, so I have a copy. What I am saying is that neither the Navy nor Defence has any record of receiving it at the time.
—Oh!
—That is very interesting, I agree. I wonder whose fault it is, though. Next I was asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister also aware that the contractor operated a system that did not use the required reporting arrangement, and that this continued with the full knowledge of the management of the Garden Island dockyard?

I get back to the point that the contract is not with the dockyard management, but with Defence via the Navy. In the Navy's monitoring of the contractor activities the Navy was happy that the full reporting system required by the Metropolitan Water Board, known as the four-docket system, appeared to be operating in compliance with the contract. Waste disposal contracts for the Navy in Sydney are arranged by the Commonwealth Defence Contracting Organisation and include a specific clause calling for the proper disposal of wastes at licensed tips in accordance with State legislation.

Next I was asked whether I was aware that, had these illegal dumping activities been initiated by a private company, under New South Wales laws that company could have been liable to fines of up to $1m and its directors liable for gaol terms of up to seven years. Certainly, I was aware that penalties in New South Wales had been increased. I take Senator Puplick's word that they are to be the new penalties. I was next asked:
Is the Minister aware that this is yet another example of the Commonwealth activity being carried out with total disregard for State pollution control laws?
It was not Commonwealth activity; it was activity by a contractor. That contractor will be subject to the full force of whatever New South Wales laws apply in this case. I was asked finally:

. . . will the Minister give an undertaking that if the New South Wales Government proceeds with a prosecution of the management of the Garden Island Dockyard the Commonwealth will not claim crown immunity . . .

In the light of the responsible attitude taken by the Navy and the full cooperation it has given the New South Wales Government from the inception of the investigations into this case, the prospect of action against the Navy does not arise, nor therefore does the issue of crown immunity. The Navy has suspended the use of the contractor and is reverting to last year's successful contractor, who is fully licensed to continue waste disposal operations from Navy ships. Pending the outcome of prosecution proceedings, Defence will look to drawing up a new contract. There is nothing at all to stop New South Wales prosecuting the offender.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Senator Stone) proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The further blow to Australia's standing in the world arising from the further down-grading of our international credit rating by Moody's Investors Service.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Two events yesterday stood out like advertising billboards along that road to Argentina on which Senator Walsh warned us some two years ago the Government was placing Australia's feet. The first was the downgrading by Moody's Investors Service Inc. of Australia's international credit rating from AA1 to AA2. The second event was the bulletin from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on foreign investment which revealed that at 30 June last Australia's net foreign debt has risen to $108 billion. Both events delivered in their different ways their verdict upon the Government's 1989 Budget. Yesterday, in a succinct 2 1/2-page press release, Moody's laid out the chronic structural problem facing the Australian economy and, in doing so, highlighted the failure of this Government effectively to tackle that problem. But before we examine the whys and wherefores of the Moody's downgrading statement, I first want to address myself to the reaction of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to that statement and his well-worn tactic of shooting this particular messenger. The Treasurer's reported reaction to yesterday's announcement was:

SPEECH.PARA: The Moody's judgment is ill-founded and vindicates the Government's decision to put Australia's reputation and independence above that of a New York company.

What a petty, mean spirited and, above all, ill-judged response to this particular verdict by an internationally reputable and internationally respected credit rating agency. Let us, however, note that the Treasurer's language yesterday was very mild compared with what I can only describe as his hysterical reaction to Moody's initial downgrading of our credit rating in September 1986, not quite three years ago. At that time he called Moody's judgment an incompetent judgment. Later he called it a lightweight and illogical judgment. It is nothing compared with the Treasurer's incredibly petty and churlish decision to black-ban Moody's Investors Service by denying it access to Government officials, including those of the Treasury and the Reserve Bank of Australia, during a visit to Australia in recent months to conduct its latest ratings review. This sort of behaviour is typical of this Treasurer's approach to problems-the approach of the New South Wales right wing of the Labor Party. It is this type of arrogant disregard that has led him continually and consistently over the last few years to deny the vulnerable state of the Australian economy.

Let us also note the inconsistency in the Labor Party's position in regard to Moody's. It was after all less than a year ago, on 27 September last year, that Mr John Dawkins in his capacity at that time as Acting Treasurer, in a matter of public importance debate in the other place and just prior-as it happened-to the Victorian election said that Moody's Investors Service Inc., a major international credit rating agency, had:

. . . awarded Victoria the highest credit rating that any State can achieve. Do honourable members really think that Moody's, relied on around the world by lending agencies to establish the credit rating of a State government or other government, would give Victoria the highest credit rating if it were in such a parlous position . . .

That is what Mr Dawkins said last year about Moody's Investors Service. What has changed in less than 12 months about the standing of this particular agency? The only thing that Moody's has done since last September for it now to be considered by our Treasurer incompetent, unprofessional, one of a bunch of monkeys-these are all the Treasurer's usual flowery expressions-is to have dared to draw attention to the policy failings of the `world's greatest Treasurer' and his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Ironically-and I think justifiably-the Treasurer's puerile denial to Moody's of access to government sources, his intemperate language in describing Moody's verdict upon his failed policies has merely served, as it was predictable that it would do, to highlight Moody's decision and has put the Treasurer, his Government and the policies for which they are responsible under closer scrutiny than otherwise would be the case.

It is the Treasurer who can be accused of incompetence by his own colleagues by having highlighted, through his own intemperate actions, the decision that was announced by Moody's yesterday. The fact, as everyone in this chamber-including honourable senators on the other side-are well aware, is that Moody's is a highly respected international credit rating agency. Its ratings are highly valued by customers, especially those in the United States, in assessing the risk of investing money in listed securities. Indeed, in some US debt markets, if companies do not have a credit rating they cannot get a loan. They cannot issue.

It is also instructive to recall that three months after Moody's first downgrading of Australia's credit rating, Standard and Poor's, that other highly respected credit rating agency, also downgraded its credit rating for Australia. The Government is making much of the possibility that it might not follow Moody's decision this time. It might not. Let us wait and see. So what? It will not in any way diminish the standing of Moody's or of its rating in the eyes of those customers who wish to place a greater weight upon one than upon the other.

Putting aside Mr Keating's vitriol, the only other response that he has made to Moody's decision is to say that the Federal Government has no net overseas debt and has not borrowed in the market for more than two years and that therefore Moody's decision is quite irrelevant. The first claim, that the Federal Government has no net overseas debt, is questionable. The Reserve Bank's assets, which the Treasurer is using as a base for that claim, are not the assets of the Commonwealth Government, legally speaking. And in any case it is an interesting concept to think that we might spend up our reserves in order to pay off Commonwealth or, for that matter, any other debt. After all, what are reserves for?

The second claim, that the Commonwealth Government has not borrowed in the market for more than two years, is correct, as a matter of fact. However, the Treasurer is neglecting to mention-I consider he is doing this both wilfully and mischievously-that the Moody's decision does not affect the debt of the Commonwealth Government only. The release by Moody's yesterday made it quite clear that its decision also affects five Commonwealth authorities, including such bodies as the Australian Industry Development Corporation, Qantas Airways Ltd and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia; nine State government authorities; and five private sector institutions-all of which are active borrowers in overseas markets. All of them, to the extent that they want to borrow tomorrow, will have to pay somewhat more for such borrowings than they would have had to pay three months ago.

I do not say that those borrowers would have had to pay more the day before yesterday because during three months to yesterday the markets had been prepared for the further downgrading of our credit rating. That is why, as the Prime Minister said with such a flourish yesterday-and no doubt as Senator Walsh will say shortly with, to give him credit, a lesser flourish-the markets received the downgrading yesterday as a `yawn'. The disgraceful impression which the Government is trying to present to the Australian people as a result of that market-based yawn is that it does not matter. In fact, the yawn derived from the fact that the markets have, to all intents and purposes, known for weeks that this downgrading would happen and they have already adjusted to it. When the downgrading was actually confirmed the markets made no further flicker of interest. They simply said, `We knew that yesterday'.

Let us be quite clear, to be more specific, that this ratings exercise affects the debts of bodies such as the Australian Industry Development Corporation; the Australian Resources Development Bank; the Australian Wheat Board-the Australian wheat growers' agency will have to pay slightly more in future if it wants to borrow abroad than it did before; the Commonwealth Bank; National Australia Bank Ltd, Westpac, National Mutual Group Finance Ltd, Queensland Treasury Corporation, State Bank of New South Wales and about 10 other similar enterprises. What Moody's did yesterday-what it always does in these circumstances-was in effect to rate the sovereign risk of Australia as a nation, not just the debt of the Commonwealth Government. It is, however, the Commonwealth Government's economic policies that have led to this downgrading of the debt of most of our issuers in foreign bond markets.

In 1986, when Moody's first downgraded Australia's credit rating, when we first lost our AAA rating, it was possible for the Government to plead the excuse-as Senator Button did to some extent today, when he began to respond to Senator Lewis's question-that there had been a major fall in our terms of trade and that that was the reason why our balance of payments had gone into such a deficit, why our debts had begun to balloon and why we are in such a mess at this time. In other words, it was not our fault that we were being downgraded. No such excuse is open to the Government now for the further downgrading of our credit rating that was announced yesterday.

In the last 2 1/2 years our international terms of trade have been dramatically improving. In 1987-88, they improved by over 9 per cent. In 1988-89 they improved by over 15 per cent. The fact is that the Australian economy has been riding high on a commodity price boom. What are the problems? I quote directly from Moody's press release of yesterday:

The factors that Moody's considers crucial to its rating action include the following: (1) the government's inability to control excessive domestic demand growth-(2) insufficient progress in generating additional export-earning capacity and in restructuring industry to achieve productivity gains-and (3) the continued slow pace of structural adjustment, which makes Australia ill-positioned to weather the next downturn in the global business cycle without further large increases in foreign-currency debt.
Later in its press release, Moody's notes:

Moreover, the current Labor government has been unable to rein in domestic demand in an overheated economy, despite the opportunities provided by the recent upswing in the business cycle. The Commonwealth government has achieved a growing fiscal surplus on its own account-
that point is fully acknowledged; that is why Moody's waited for the Budget to be released-

but political and social factors have prevented the application of a total policy mix that is sufficiently rigorous to balance the external accounts. The government has relied primarily on a tight monetary policy-
or, at any rate, high interest rates-
which has bolstered the Australian dollar, thereby stimulating imports and discouraging exports.

That is not a new analysis. The Opposition has been putting forward that analysis in this place and elsewhere for, I was going to say months but I should almost say, years. It is, however, worth remembering that only two weeks ago the Reserve Bank of Australia expressed very similar sentiments in its annual report. Those sentiments have already been the subject of debate in this chamber and I do not propose to repeat them this afternoon.

That is not all. On Monday of this week, the Government's Committee for Review of Export Market Development Assistance, chaired by Professor Helen Hughes, who is a very distinguished economist, who has served the World Bank and other bodies of that kind for many years and who is now back in Australia, noted in its report:

. . . the Government's response to the current situation of high demand and inflation coupled with labour shortages and a growth of imports that has far outstripped that of exports, has been to continually tighten monetary policy.
Interest rates have been driven up in an attempt to slow domestic demand and import growth.
But this has created serious problems for exporters, both through increasing costs and reduced prices as the exchange rate rose and eroded competitiveness.
Moody's makes a special reference to the Treasurer's oft repeated references to the Budget surplus. It says:

Moody's noted that the recent federal budget covering the current 1989-90 fiscal year generates an even larger surplus and contributes to the needed growth in national savings. Nonetheless, the rating agency believes that the budget fails to decisively address the issues of external imbalance and productivity.

This is precisely the position which was taken by the Opposition in our Budget response in the House of Representatives on the Thursday following the Budget, and again by me this morning. What Moody's is saying is that the Government has failed on micro-economic reform. Micro-economic reform was to be the so-called hallmark of the third Hawke Government. What type of micro-economic reform is Moody's talking about? Again, a quote from its press release makes it clear. On the type of considerations it looked at for the downgrading, Moody's notes:

The first is a persistence of structural weaknesses embedded in Australia's domestic and international position, such as intransigent rigidities in the local labour and transport markets. These constrain international competitiveness.

What could be more apposite than that comment at this time when we are seeing, perhaps, the worst example in Australia's history of `intransigent rigidities in the local labour and transport markets', both combined in the form of the airline pilots dispute? The airline pilots dispute was, I will not say brought on, but it was certainly greatly exacerbated, reinforced and, indeed, has now been held in place, by the actions of this foolish Prime Minister, this vain man, who sees himself propping up the power of this ex-colleague in the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the man who used to be called his apprentice, Mr Bill Kelty, and the power of the trade union movement against the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and its members.

In the course of doing so, the Government is not merely dragging down the airline industry; it is not merely disrupting the travel plans of thousands of Australians. It will also bring the Australian economy to a state of crisis if the dispute continues for much longer. The Australian tourism industry will sink to its knees under the weight of this Government's and this Prime Minister's-I repeat it-inspired, enforced and reinforced support for this course of action.

Of course, these are the areas that the Opposition identified long ago as crucial areas in need of immediate reform. But the Labor Party, hamstrung by its affiliation with the trade union bosses, as exemplified by the airline pilots dispute that I have just been referring to, simply cannot act in these areas of what Moody's rightly calls `intransigent rigidities in the local labour and transport markets'. The fact is that, when all is said and done, the Moody's decision yesterday was clear-cut and unremarkable. If anything, the mild reaction to it in our markets, as I said earlier, illustrates that this was exactly what the markets were expecting it to do. That is why they were not surprised. That is why it has been described as a yawn.

I conclude by referring to only one of the many comments in this morning's press which take the Government-surprisingly strongly, given the quality of much of our press analysis of these matters-to task for its reaction yesterday. I refer to the article in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald by Mr Ross Gittins. Mr Gittins begins by saying:
The Treasurer claimed yesterday that the downgrading of Australia's credit rating by Moody's Investors Service is unjustified. Don't be bamboozled.
If you want to know why we were downgraded, look no further than the separate announcement that Australia's net foreign debt climbed by $18 billion last financial year to $108 billion.
During a year in which the prices we received for our commodity exports were high and rising, our balance of payments should have improved. Instead, it got worse.
Moody's action is, as the Opposition claims, a vote of no confidence in the Government's management-
or rather mismanagement-
of the economy.
I could not have put it better myself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it very difficult to take this debate seriously because it is based upon the notion that Australia-an entity known as Australia-can in any realistic way be assessed as a credit risk. I think that stands somewhere between the absurd and the ridiculous, because implicit in it is a belief that the Commonwealth Government is qualitatively the same sort of borrower as the shakiest paper entrepreneur. I do not think Senator Stone would argue that it is somewhere between absurd and ridiculous to take that position, but he himself said that Moody's assessment is an assessment of what Australia is worth, or the soundness of Australia as a borrower. It is based on a ridiculous presumption.

SPEECH.PARA: No wonder Reuters-not only the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-said that the Moody's report was a yawn. However, it does seem to have been taken somewhat seriously by Senator Stone. If one looks at the terms in which his motion is framed, one will see that he refers to the effect on Australia's standing in the world, implying that he is more interested in the symbolism than in the underlying reality. Indeed, he is obsessed with the symbolism. There is less excuse for Senator Stone to be obsessed by the symbolism than there is for the more simple people who have not had Senator Stone's years of experience in the Department of the Treasury and so on. No wonder he thinks that the Moody's report, which really is of hardly any relevance, is important.

If it is to be claimed that this Moody's assessment has anything at all meaningful to say about the quality of the Commonwealth Government as a borrower, let us note firstly that the Commonwealth Government has no net foreign debt at all and has not had for some time. On a net basis, the Commonwealth Government owes nothing overseas. There have been major reductions in the Commonwealth Government's domestic debt. If we produce another four Budgets the same as this Budget, the Commonwealth Government will have no debt whatsoever, no gross debt even, either overseas or in Australia. There will be no gross debt at all. In another four Budgets like the present one, we will be in that position. Even in this year, if we, the Government, chose to do so, we could almost entirely wipe out the gross foreign debt that we now have. We could do it with this year's Budget surplus. The Government has decided not to do that because, principally, foreigners who are holding Australian government securities will not part with them except at extraordinarily good prices.

In other words, we could redeem the gross foreign debt that the Commonwealth owes but it is not good business to do so because the foreigners who hold Australian government securities do not really want to get rid of them. They want to hold them to maturity. That is what the foreigners who hold Australian government securities want to do. They have not taken much notice of Moody's in the past, and there is a good reason for that, which I am coming to. The following comments are made on page 10 of today's Australian Financial Review:
Foreign investors who took Moody's last downgrading of Australia's credit rating to heart and kept out of the Australian fixed-interest market have given up the chance to almost double their money.

A 10-year Commonwealth bond purchased by a US investor just before Moody's downgraded Australia to AA1 in September 1986 would have returned 91.4 per cent over the past three years-or 24 per cent a year . . .

People who followed Moody's advice just three years ago and got rid of Australian bonds sacrificed that sort of return, a return that they would hardly have got anywhere else in the world. Even with extremely risky investments, they would not have got that sort of return. Now that they know that they should not have acted on the Moody's assessment of 1986, they have no intention of getting rid of their Commonwealth government securities. The experience of the last three years has taught them that Moody's assessment, however relevant it may or may not have been to the most marginal Australian corporate borrower, has absolutely no relevance to the Commonwealth Government.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) made the point in his press release that the reason we were retiring only a moderate amount of foreign debt this year is that foreigners do not want to part with their Australian government securities. They may have taken some notice of Moody's in 1986 and because of that experience they will not take any notice, or much notice, of Moody's this year. Senator Stone said-and this is further evidence which demonstrates the absurdity of the proposition that whatever Moody's says ought to be regarded seriously-that the Australian Wheat Board will be affected by this Moody's evaluation. If that is true-and I do not believe it is-what Senator Stone is saying is that an organisation totally hedged with an internationally tradable commodity is not a good credit risk for an overseas borrower. If one believes that the Wheat Board will be affected by the evaluation, one also has to believe that the Wheat Board, totally hedged with a commodity which is saleable on an overseas market, is not a sound borrower for some foreign institution from which the Wheat Board may be seeking funds to pay growers in advance of the actual sale of the wheat crop.

Even though one develops a fairly thick hide in politics, I find it pretty offensive that this Government should be berated by the Opposition on matters like government debt. This Opposition, which was in government for 30 years between 1949 and 1983, did not produce one Budget surplus in any of those 30 years. It did not repay one cent of Commonwealth debt; it did not produce one Budget surplus. Yet, it has the audacity to berate the present Government which has produced three Budget surpluses in a row-$2.2 billion, rising to $5.5 billion and to $9 billion this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you ought to ask yourself why that is not improving our foreign debt position. Doesn't it suggest to you that there is something wrong with the strategy?

—I will come to that later on. It requires a great deal of chutzpah on the part of the Opposition to berate this Government for its record on fiscal responsibility when one looks at its record. I might add that there is absolutely no indication to date that should the coalition get into government it would be any more responsible in the future. The Opposition has lightweights like Senator Newman-non-entities, admittedly-still on the front bench who passionately supported a motion a couple of months ago to buy two aircraft carriers which cost $6 billion and to blow another $3.5 billion a year on defence alone on a recurring basis-$6 billion capital and $3.5 billion recurring. That is the sort of twaddle that comes out of the mouths of some of the lightweights who sit on the Opposition front bench. I know that Senator Stone and probably Dr Hewson would not do that. Indeed, should there be a coalition government I believe that for the first 18 months or maybe even two years there would be a deliberate attempt to drive the economy into a recession in the belief that, having done that, it could smash the unions or, as it would prefer to put it, fully deregulate the labour market. If all of those things happened half way through the term, Senator Stone and Dr Hewson would get rolled by the lightweights and the opportunists in a Peacock government in a desperate attempt to refloat the economy prior to an election. That is the sort of thing which would happen if the Opposition succeeded in winning an election.

SPEECH.PARA: I make one final comment about the financial institutions in New York-a generalised comment which does not apply to all of them but, in this context, a comment which is worth repeating. I visited New York just under a year ago and spoke to a number of people who could be described reasonably as merchant bankers or merchant banker types. Naturally, we discussed the state of the United States budget deficit and the US current account deficit. With one or two exceptions, those people did not seem to believe that the US had any problems. I then went to Washington and spoke to some senior members of Congress and some senior public servants who, firstly, did believe that the US had a problem but did not expect anything much to be done about it. Secondly, they were not at all surprised to learn that the people in New York did not seem to think the United States had a problem anyway, which is another way of saying, really, that some of these people at least in New York are not particularly good judges of anything, a point which I suppose Moody's demonstrated very clearly to those who were naive enough to take Moody's advice three years ago and got rid of their Australian Government securities and thereby forwent returns of 24 per cent on those securities.

The fact is that on a net basis, as I mentioned before, the Commonwealth Government is an external creditor, not a debtor. Some Commonwealth Government authorities do have debts, State government authorities have net debts and State governments have net debts. However, the bulk of the borrowing or of the money owed externally by Australia is private debt incurred by individuals or by corporations. I will refer here to fixed income research done by First Boston Australia Ltd. I cannot give the name of the publication; my copy does not have the front page. However, on page 8 there is a listing of both the foreign debt and the market values of a number of Australian companies. They are the three largest both in terms of their foreign debt and of their overseas market values. The financial institutions are the ANZ Bank, the National Australia Bank and Westpac with debts and assets varying from $15 billion to $30 billion. Because they are financial institutions they are qualitatively different and I will not say any more about them.

But there are trading companies: foreign debt of the Bond Corporation is $3,900m; the market value of its overseas assets is $3 billion. Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd has foreign debt just over $4 billion; the book value-for some reason the table does not include a market value of BHP's foreign assets-is nearly $5 billion. Elders-IXL has foreign debts of nearly $4 billion and market value of foreign assets nearly $7 billion. I will give the figures for one or two of the other large ones: News Corporation has foreign debts of just over $5 billion and the market value of its foreign assets is of the order of $14 billion.

Senator Haines will probably say it is a dreadful thing that this has happened but, leaving that aside, the fact is that a number of large Australian companies have borrowed very heavily overseas and they have used that money to purchase overseas assets. Indeed, if I remember correctly, in the period of about three or four years leading up to mid-1988, Australians acquired additional equity investments abroad of the order of 5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). Leaving aside again the question of whether it is a good thing that it has happened, the fact that it happened of course was to overstate the size of Australia's net foreign debt because extra debts had been incurred to buy additional equities overseas.

I return to what some other people think about Moody's. I am sure that most members of the Senate and the public would have heard some of the broadcast I am about to quote this morning on the ABC's AM program. Hardly anybody could deny that fact and still retain any credibility at all, but we need to ask why we have a foreign debt problem. And the answer is because successive governments have encouraged private sector overseas borrowings by allowing companies which borrow on the international money market to write the interest costs off against their Australian tax liability, reducing it in some cases to zero. What organisation is not going to take advantage of such a wonderful way of reducing its tax liability? What company is not going to move to debt rather than equity financing, given that sort of incentive? Of course, that is precisely what happened.

We could argue that the aim of allowing this sort of tax deductability was justified, at least in the beginning. The strategy was allegedly to encourage investment and development by Australian businesses, thereby creating employment and increasing productivity. That was then supposed to lead to an increase in export items and an increase in import replacement items, thereby reducing our trade deficit. Instead, what has happened is that a series of taxpayer-subsidised, overseas-funded and non-productive takeovers have occurred as Australian businessmen play monopoly with each other's shares. Few extra jobs have resulted. Since the same businessmen that are taking advantage of negative gearing on their overseas borrowings are frequently complaining about Australia's low level of productivity, one can safely assume that there have been no benefits there either. Indeed, I venture to say that very few new products, either for export or as import replacements, have resulted as a consequence of businesses taking advantage of what is now little more than a tax rort. Where are all the new export goods that were supposed to come from this new investment that is taxpayer-subsidised? Where are the new import replacement goods that were supposed to come from this investment funded by overseas borrowings? The answer is that, by and large, there are none. That is the increase in both our gross and net debts over the last three months. Allegedly on those grounds but, I suggest, more likely through a rather unpleasant form of truculence-given that, although Moody's has downgraded us, we have not been attacked by Standard and Poor's, the other major ratings agency-Moody's decided to downgrade Australia from AA1 to AA2. That was a move that puzzled commentators, not least of whom was a senior official from the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development who noted on the radio this morning what many of us already knew: that Australia is not the only country in the world with a high foreign debt. Both the United States and the United Kingdom have high foreign debts. Nor are we the only country in the world with a high trade deficit. Both the United States and the United Kingdom have a high trade deficit. Indeed, where Australia differs from those two countries is that we have a domestic surplus while the others run at a domestic deficit.

However, all of this seemed to be irrelevant to Moody's, who decided to rate Australia just below Belgium, just above Ireland and on the same level as Spain in the scheme of things as far as risk for investors is concerned. That is really all the ratings are about. Essentially, Moody's is saying to overseas investors, `Go ahead and invest in Australia if you like, but demand from them higher interest rates because there is a risk you might not get your money back'. One is compelled to ask: What difference will this make since it has been both Labor and coalition policy to keep interest rates high in Australia in any event in order to lure foreign money into the country to offset in particular last year's high levels of Australian business borrowings from overseas? What difference will it really make in the scheme of things?

The other solution put forward by the other major parties in this country to the problem we are currently facing is to sell off as much of Australia as businesses or individuals from the United Kingdom, the United States, Saudi Arabia, West Germany, New Zealand, Hong Kong, Singapore and Japan will buy. Their response to what is a very real problem was: do not worry about the long term problems that may come from that; sell it for the short term benefits that this may have. But this is a response with its own attendant problems. Australia's high foreign debt means that 25 per cent of export income is eaten up by servicing that debt. What a waste. It means that our current account deficit will continue to reflect interest repayments on past borrowings as well as the rent and dividends paid to foreign owners of Australian assets, all of which goes out of the country.

I recall some months ago sitting in the chamber and listening to National Party senator after National Party senator complaining that our beef industry in both Tasmania and Queensland is almost totally owned by the Japanese at all levels.
