Treasury predicted last year that the current account deficit for 1988-89 would be $9.5 billion; it was in fact $17.7 billion, and about two-thirds of that-that is, $12.6 billion-came from repaying past foreign debt. We are caught in a vicious circle caused and now continued by outmoded, discredited economic theories that have meant that Australia has now lost control of its own economy. This means that the Hawke Government and the Liberal and National parties will continue to make it easier for foreign investors to buy Australian property, land and enterprises. In the short run, the more foreign currency we can get by flogging off Australia, the less we have to borrow. But in the long run, by selling off Australia, we further lose control of the economy and saddle future Australians with the problem of paying off the rent, profits and dividends to foreign owners. It means that Australians will continue to suffer high interest rates and the effects of expenditure cuts, despite the fact that most of the foreign debt has been borrowed by the private sector for financing takeovers that add little or nothing to our export or import replacement capacity.

What is worse, the private sector borrowers get a taxpayer-funded subsidy for those borrowings while ordinary Australians are suffering a further reduction in their living standards because private Australian companies have gorged themselves on those foreign borrowings and created this massive foreign debt. In an article in the current Australian Business, entitled `Who Really Owes the Foreign Debt', we discover, as Senator Walsh has already mentioned, that the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd owes $20.3 billion, Westpac Banking Corporation $28 billion and the National Australia Bank Limited $15.5 billion. I wonder how much of their record profits-because we know they are making record profits-is going to repay any of this debt each year. I suggest very little. Their priority is their shareholders, not the state of Australia's foreign debt. We know that Bond Corporation owes $3.9 billion overseas; BHP, $4.1 billion; Elders, almost $4 billion; and News Corporation, $5.1 billion. Again, I wonder how much of this is due to borrowings used to buy shares in each other's companies and to limit tax payments through negative gearing and, I suggest, a large amount of it.

Failure of successive governments to act in these areas means that neither the Hawke Government nor the Liberal-National alternative has a solution to our economic problem. They both stand for high interest rates, expenditure cuts, privatisation and deregulation, and we have already had a good dose of all of those theories with no noticeable effect of any benefit to this country. Australians continue to import more than we can pay for. I remind Senator Stone that more of this Government's legislative program has got through this Parliament because he and his colleagues support it than has got through because we do. I listed a few of those pieces of legislation this morning-predominantly legislation that hits low income earners. The fact of the matter is that Australians continue to import more than we can pay for, the current account deficits set ever-increasing records and the foreign debt continues to grow.

What is the solution? First of all, we need to reduce our reliance on imports. We could learn a lesson, for example, from the Menzies Government when it experienced a balance of payments crisis in the early 1950s. As the value of exports fell when the price of wool fell after the Korean War the Government realised we had to import less. The then coalition Government did the sensible thing, something which is apparently anathema to the modern Liberal and national parties and this Labor Government: it cut imports. (Extension of time granted) The Menzies Government did not rely on mega surpluses and mega interest rates perhaps to cut imports some day a bit down the track; it did it by imposing import restrictions. It is essential that this Government take similar action. We are not living in a free trading world. Every other country in the world imposes restrictions of some sort. They may not be tariff barriers but they are quite frequently non-tariff barriers that have quite the same effect. If we are not going to increase our export market or make the increase in the exports of any value because of the size of our dollar, we have to cut imports through a variety of measures-for example, by putting a tax on luxury imports and imposing quantitative restrictions on imported goods that can and should be produced in Australia. Anybody who looks at the figures knows that in the single category of food, beverages and tobacco in excess of $2.2 billion was contributed to our balance of trade deficit: Brazilian oranges, French champagne, American cigarettes, imported cheeses, dried fruit, biscuits-you name it-in this category contributed over $2.2 billion to our deficit. They can all either be done without since they compete with Australian products or bear a luxury tax, and the users would be none the worse off. The only thing that is wrong with that suggestion is that it is unfashionable to the market-worshipping deregulators who pass for economists today. One thing is certain: some different action has to be taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we needed any proof of the adage that the quality of language used by this Government in order to camouflage unpleasant truths usually falls in inverse proportion to its degree of desperation to hold on to office at any cost, we had it today when we heard Senator Walsh speak. That is the point-that is what is occurring and the situation is not being addressed by this Government. The Budget presented just recently and upon which no debate has yet occurred has done nothing to bring about change in those perceptions which we have just outlined. This contrasts very clearly with the Government's approach, which seems to be nothing more or less than, `Don't worry, just be happy'.

What does Moody's actually say in the course of its report? First of all, it surveys the debt problem and gives us some information about that. But the most significant thing to which it draws Australia's attention is Australia's capacity to service-that is, repay-the debt we are building up. The only way the debt can be repaid in net terms is from our overseas earnings.

What is the capacity of Australia to pay? When we look at the statistics in the Government's Budget Papers we see that interest and principal repayments in the year that the Government came into office, 1983, took 26.5 per cent of exports, but today, under the Hawke-Keating Labor Government, take no less than 63 per cent of export earnings. That means it has increased by almost 250 per cent in the period of this Government's tutelage. That demonstrates a lack of policy, a lack of direction, a lack of concern with the real interests of Australians. It is that which Moody's is looking at: the capacity of the Australian economy to get itself out of its problems, to develop more export growth so that it can repay that debt. That is the point of the exercise. That is what Moody's is saying to us and, if we are at all intelligent in governing the affairs of this nation, we must have regard to how those problems can be redressed and the situation improved.

Cleverly, in its usual way of a public relations exercise, the Government has sought to turn the debate away from the capacity of Australians to repay that debt by measuring it in terms of a proportion of exports towards another measure by telling us time and again that we are measuring our debt against the percentage of gross domestic product needed to repay it. Everybody knows that is a distorted way of displaying the capacity of this country to borrow. We must come back to the essential point about exports and how in net terms we can repay our debt from exports.

In some of its statements, Moody's has very clearly drawn attention to the lack of capacity of the Government. Senator Stone spelt it out very well. I first mention a statement referred to by Senator Stone, namely, the insufficient progress in generating additional export-earning capacity in restructuring industry to achieve productivity gains. That is quite clearly evident in the Budget Papers as well. We do not have to believe Moody's on that; all we have to do is look at the Budget Papers, which show the import penetration figures and the lack of competitiveness. Those factors mean that Australia is in a parlous position. We are talking about borrowing more and more overseas to improve our export earning capacity, yet we are failing to do that. In essence, that is the essential problem we face with our debt.

Moody's also referred to the continued slow pace of structural adjustment, which makes Australia ill-positioned to weather the next downturn in the global business cycle. That is possibly around the corner if the world economy goes into a recession in the next year or so and we remain exposed because of our huge foreign debts and our inability to service them. If exports turn down rather than up, our future will be gloomy indeed. When the time comes, it will hit us like a ton of bricks.

Other considerations are mentioned in the Moody's report, which refers to shortcomings in the Australian economy. The first is the structural weaknesses of the economy itself. There is also the domestic and international position and such matters as the intransigent rigidities in the local labour and transport markets. All those things are critical to an understanding of the problems in the Australian economy. But the Government has no policies to address them. It does not seem to want to take on its brothers in the Australian Council of Trade Unions by making changes in the labour market. It does not believe in the policies which have been outlined by the Liberal and National parties and which would take us into a new era of industrial relations, leading to joint and constructive results in the improvement of productivity and cost reduction.

Moody's also drew attention to our heavy reliance on commodity exports, which places our foreign exchange earnings at the mercy of fluctuating terms of trade. Since Mr Keating took over, these things have had quite a number of runs when we refer to terms of trade. First, they are bad; then they are good. They seem to move in opposite directions all the time. The point is that we are exposed to that fluctuation because of our heavy reliance on primary produce in our exports.

Senator Walsh said that the Commonwealth Government's debt was not at issue here. In saying that, he ignores entirely the point that the Government is responsible for the policy of the whole nation, not just that of the Commonwealth Government. It is not the question of the Commonwealth's debt itself which is at issue; it is the nation's debt and the nation's capacity to repay that debt that is the issue. That is the point. I do not care how many times we say that in the course of this debate. The national situation is at issue and it is very clever of Senator Walsh to try to turn the debate on to that ground in an attempt to blind the Australian people from the real issues. But we in the Liberal and National parties will not let the debate be diverted from that issue.

Moody's drew our attention to the poor policy mix, to the fact that high interest rate monetary policies have restricted our export capacity and enhanced our capacity to import more and so disadvantaged our current account deficit. All in all, we have to say that Moody's report is a devastating criticism of the Commonwealth Government's policies. It does not come on its own; it backs up the recent report of the Reserve Bank of Australia. As we have seen, it backs up only what the markets are already saying to Australia. We have already been given evidence that the markets have taken this in their stride because they know the real situation of Australia. The Government has no concern for the views of consumers, the small business community or home builders in its inappropriate mix of policies. But the market knows what the Government is doing wrong. Apparently, the Government will not admit its mistakes. How long can the Government's head in the sand attitude go on while we in the Parliament stand aside and watch the Government continue to say nothing and do nothing to change the situation? In the Government's eyes, apparently everything is wrong but the Government itself.

I conclude by returning to the essential point that Australia's ability to repay its debt is the issue. We need more investment in export earning industries. We are not doing well in that area because we are not putting enough investment into it. I give a final example of the problem that our debt brings to Australia. If in one payment we had to repay in gold all our debt-some $149 billion-we would have to load something like 8,204 tonnes of gold on to 410 semitrailers stretching head to tail for 8 1/2 kilometres from the vaults of the Reserve Bank in Martin Place to the Botany Bay container depot. If we wanted to use wheelbarrows, we would need 164,000 of them to cart the gold. Every month an extra 100 tones of gold, or another five semitrailer loads, is added to the debt. That illustration quite clearly demonstrates the nature of the repayment problem we are facing and how the Government stands condemned for not addressing the problems which Moody's has quite properly drawn to our attention.
