SPEECH.PARA: I want to mention quickly the fact that the Opposition has given no credit to this Government for a major structural change within the Government's fiscal policies and the impact of the Budget surpluses we now have. This year it is estimated that we will have a Budget surplus of about $9 billion. That means that in the three years to 30 June this year there will be a total surplus of $17 billion. It is said in the Budget Papers that all up the total Commonwealth debt-overwhelmingly domestic debt-totals $41 billion. That means that if that surplus is averaged out at about $6 billion over the three years to 30 June, at that rate we will be able to pay off the total Commonwealth debt. That would mean a significant structural change to the Budget in that the $7 billion now listed in the Budget for interest payments would no longer be required and, therefore, there would be money available on the outlays side to be given either as tax cuts or in some other area to which the Government may choose to give spending priority. That is a major structural change for which this Government should be given great credit.

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder you are in such trouble if that is all you can think about.
—That compares with the 30 years from 1949 when Senator Messner's Government had a deficit in some form or other in the Federal Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I return to the points made by Senator Stone. If he is so keen about Moody's Investors Service Inc. giving a credit rating for Australia, I suggest that, as a National Party senator from Queensland-the leader of the biggest number of National Party senators from any State-he invite Moody's to inspect the way in which Queensland manages its business. Why does he not ask Moody's to go to Queensland and have a look at the report on the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct? What sort of credit rating would the National Party Government in Queensland get after the findings of the Fitzgerald report on the rorting, corruption and tendering system of the National Party Government, a party of which Senator Stone is a member? That is a question, the answer to which we will not hear from Senator Stone-not one squeak. We should remember that he is only in this place because Joh Bjelke-Petersen put him here. Now we find he is running for the House of Representatives seat of Fairfax. Who got him the preselection for Fairfax? It was Sir Robert Sparkes, the head kicking, arm twisting thug of the Queensland National Party. I understand he only got up by one or two votes against the former member for that area, Mr Slipper.

Before Senator Stone starts criticising this Government's economic policies he ought to have a good look at the people he represents and is associated with in Queensland and their performance. The National Party in Queensland is the most corrupt in the history of Australia. There is no doubt about that; it is on the record. He is a member of the party in government that has set that record. If Moody's had a look at the Queensland Government its credit rating would be -ZZZ, as it deserves to be. Therefore, the matter for discussion as presented by Senator Stone can be rejected as a cynical piece of lightweight politics. We know that Senator Stone probably will not even win the seat of Fairfax. Senator Parer's party may have the opportunity to take that seat off him at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The concluding remarks made by the Government senator who has just resumed his seat demonstrate the lack of concern the Government has about the issues in this debate. This kind of personal nonsense across the chamber is taking place during a debate on a matter of immense significance. The matter presented for discussion by the Opposition deals with the further blow to Australia's standing in the world arising from the further downgrading of our international credit rating by Moody's Investors Service Inc.

SPEECH.PARA: There can be very few more serious matters before this chamber at this time, because it is this matter which hangs over this nation. It is destroying the fabric of our society. It threatens our economic future and the standard of living of all Australians. For this debate to be taken as lightly as this Government has taken it says an immense amount about this Government's failure to address the problems behind this crisis.

The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) went so far as to describe this matter as absurd, based on a ridiculous assumption, of hardly any relevance and said that the Moody's survey was inconsequential. That is not what all the other critics of this Government think about the issues raised by Moody's. It is certainly not what the Reserve Bank of Australia thinks. It is not what a leading economic advisory group, under Professor Hughes, apparently thinks, judging by the report that came out earlier this week. It is not what the major newspaper commentators think, judging by the editorials and the other comments in the major Australian newspapers that have come out since the disastrous news this week not only that Moody's has downgraded Australia yet again, but also that our foreign debt has risen yet again under this Government and will continue to rise, and our debt burden will continue to get worse, directly because-and this is the important point-of the policies and incompetence of this Government.

There is no point looking around, as the Government used to do in previous years, and saying, `It is not really our fault that we are having such a disastrous balance of payments figure. It is not really our fault that interest rates have gone up to the extent that people are being priced out of their homes. It is not really our fault that all these terrible things are happening to Australians and the standard of living is falling. It is not our fault because there were terrible terms of trade. We were not getting as much on the overseas markets for our exports and were having to pay more for our imports'. That has simply not been so in the last year. Our terms of trade have massively improved and our economy has gone down. Our balance of payments has worsened. All the key forecasts the Government made in its last Budget have been proved wrong. Now, of course, Moody's is being abused by this arrogant Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his equally arrogant partner the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for being the messenger-only the latest messenger-bringing the story of reality. That is the reality that Australia's economic policies are leading this nation more and more into economic disaster and more and more down the Argentinean road.

Today's debate was not helped much by the usual enormously intellectually curious approach of the Australian Democrats. Senator Janine Haines said that the trouble with our debt is that this stupid Government and previous stupid governments are allowing an enormous tax benefit so that greedy capitalists can keep borrowing from overseas. Let us put that nonsense to rest. The fact is that the great bulk of Australia's increasing debt is due to one thing only and that is the need to pay for our annual continuing and increasing deficit, because we keep having to pay overseas far more than we earn.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of it.
—No, not quite all of it.
—By definition.

—No, not necessarily. There are things like currency variations and other things. I thank the honourable senator for acknowledging the point. The fact is that the total current account deficits under the Hawke Government-they are the current account deficits that we have had to find the money to pay for-have totalled $75 billion. Our net external debt has risen by $85 billion. How, possibly, can Senator Haines find the intellectual capacity to argue that that is simply not so; that we have gone into debt not because we have had to pay our bills and we did not have the money to do it; we have gone into debt because some greedy Australian businessman has taken advantage of a tax deduction in order to borrow from overseas? What Senator Haines confuses is the make-up of the debt, not the reality of the debt itself.

SPEECH.PARA: We have politicians in this country, particularly from the Australian Democrats and the Government side, pretending that the facts do not exist, pretending that everything is fine, it is going on track, there is no need to worry and it does not matter if we have a massive overseas debt which is worsening. I must say that Senator Walsh does not share that view; he apparently regards any discussion of it, such as today's, as a matter of no consequence. When we have politicians in positions of power deceiving the Australian people into believing that this is not a matter of major moment, that this is not a matter which is of immense concern and which will affect and is affecting the living standards of all Australians, then we have, I believe, politicians who, for short term political gain, are seeking to mislead the Australian people. I believe that is totally dishonourable. The reality of what has happened-this is pointed out by Moody's and, as I said, Moody's is simply being supported by the very same thing being said by the Reserve Bank and by Professor Hughes-is the enormous increase in our indebtedness and the failure of this Government to do anything to bring an end to it.

This Budget has done nothing-and Moody's points it out-to correct the worsening trend. It has done nothing to stop us going more and more broke. It has done nothing to stop the enormous interest rates that we will continue to need simply to borrow the money to pay our bills overseas. We can see this very simply. The balance of payments figures that came out earlier this week showed that from the time this Government came in, back in 1983, our income debits-that is the amount we have to pay overseas-have jumped dreadfully from making up only 14 per cent of exports to 30 per cent of exports. In other words, we have to export twice as much now, simply to pay our interest bill, as we did before this Government came in. We have to run twice as hard simply to stand still and we are not achieving it. We are going further and further into debt with no real indication of when we are going to stop.

The Budget says we will go further into debt this year. There will be another major current account deficit. We are looking into the mid-1990s before we see any prospect of any kind of improvement. Yet this Government, in this Budget, has done nothing to resolve those problems. The Reserve Bank says inflation is the key. Under this Budget inflation does not improve at all. The Reserve Bank says micro-economic reform is essential. The Reserve Bank says nothing is being done about that. The Reserve Bank report clearly demonstrates, as does Moody's, what this Government should be doing and it is not doing it. The quotes are quite clear. Moody's says:
. . . Australia's relative external debt position will probably worsen before it stabilizes in the mid-1990s.
Who will pay for that? The Australian people will pay for that in lower standards of living and massively high interest rates as we have to borrow the money to meet our bill. Moody's continues:
The Budget fails to decisively address the issues of external imbalance and productivity.
It says it considers that the matters that are crucial to its rating action include the following:
(1) the government's inability to control excessive domestic demand growth . . .
(2) insufficient progress in generating additional export-earning capacity and in restructuring industry to achieve productivity gains . . . and

(3) the continued slow pace of structural adjustment, which makes Australia ill-positioned to weather the next downturn in the global business cycle without further large increases in foreign-currency debt.

The rating agency also pointed out that the downgrading reflects several other considerations such as the persistence of structural weaknesses embedded in Australia's domestic and international positions, such as intransigent rigidities in the local labour and transport markets, and stated that these constrain international competitiveness. That is almost word for word what the Reserve Bank said here last week. It is certainly what the media are saying, and it is no wonder then that Moody's has reduced our position to the bottom of the pile. Who are we with? We are now equal with Spain as a credit risk, according to Moody's. New Zealand is a little bit behind us-just a fraction behind us-and yet New Zealand at the moment has a far better set of basic economic statistics available than we have. All the current figures which are pointing so badly for us, so downhill for us, are in fact on the improve in New Zealand because they have bitten the bullet far more seriously than Australia has. Underneath us, all we have is Portugal, Hong Kong, India, South Korea, China, Malaysia, Venezuela, Brazil and Argentina. What a great collection of people we are now heading! And above us, of course, are all the really developed nations of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are in manana country.

—We are in banana company rather than manana company. This Government and this Treasurer have spent their time attacking the Moody's report because it is not the news they want to hear. They should be embracing it. They should be saying, `Look, this Moody's report demonstrates-as does the Reserve Bank-the seriousness of the situation we are in now'. This Government should be saying to the unions, `Look, Moody's has told us what a serious situation must be countered, and how it must be countered by serious measures'. The Australian Council of Trade Unions must abandon some of its more absurd objectives. There must be restructuring without the sort of nonsensical resistance from the Waterside Workers Federation, for example, to the Inter-State Commission's report on how to fix up the economics of our transport system-particularly our sea transport system.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government did not do that. It did not embrace this report and say, `Look, this is why there have to be tough measures.' Instead of that this Government spent its time Moody-bashing. It has no answers and it simply attacked Moody's in exactly the same way it has attacked every member of this Opposition who has pointed out the error of its economic ways and the consequences of this Government's continued economic failures. It is not only ridiculous for the Government to attack Moody's; it is disastrous. But by doing so it will give heart to those people who say Australia is not in such a bad position and let us go for the doctor; let us get what pay rises we can; let us make certain we do not improve productivity; and let us maintain our old work practices that are destroying this country. The Government, by its actions, is giving heart to those people; it is giving support to them. This Government has missed an opportunity here, not only of reforming itself and its policies but also of encouraging the rest of Australia to increase its productivity and make the great moves forward that are desperately needed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In discussing this matter of public importance in relation to Moody's Investors Service Inc. I want to give as much time as I can to dealing with the positive aspects of the situation-not to pretend that there is no problem but to talk about the circumstances in which we find ourselves and to provide some analysis of our economic situation. First of all, I think we have to deal with the continuing circumstance of an Opposition whose total fixation is seizing upon negatives. It has not been in opposition long enough to work out that not all it has to do is to say negative things. Its members need a lot more experience in opposition and I think we ought to be generous and give it to them.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) described it earlier, the Opposition is grabbing now at the Moody's straw, as happened with the Reserve Bank of Australia report when we debated it here on 18 August--

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't like bad news. Just wish it away.

—Senator Alston made economically illiterate interjections at that stage as well, but we are getting used to it. Opposition members' speeches then were characterised by selective quotation and enthusiastic interpretation. The Opposition ignores everything in every report that does not suit the argument it wants to put forward. I am not saying that there is no problem but that there are important issues to be discussed; there are positives and negatives. Let us give it reasonable, sober analysis. Opposition members ignore everything they do not like. They seize upon the negatives and they do everything they can to kick Australia's international reputation to death.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone tried tremendously hard in his speech to reinterpret Reuters very significant comment about the Moody's report. Reuters, in its comment on the screen going to the finance market this morning, said that Moody's downgrading was a big yawn. Of course it was, and of course it is. The Opposition-apart from, I must say to his credit, Senator Michael Baume, although I do not think he actually understood what he quoted-has ignored the fact that Moody's said some other things that are significantly worthy of comment. Senator Michael Baume quoted some of them and I appreciate that. The gentleman from Moody's said:

. . . the Labor Government's approach to reform has been responsible for some major change which would not otherwise have been possible in Australia . . . continued cooperation between government, business and labour would be a crucial element in making domestic industry more competitive.
I had not heard that bit of the report emphasised. It does not fit in with the categorisation which the Opposition wants to make. The report then went on to say:
. . . Australia should be able to stabilise its external debt in the 1990s . . .

Everybody wishes the world was different and that the debt would disappear. It is a significant problem but the processes are in train for it to stabilise, albeit not as quickly as we would all wish. I suspect that everbody knows that the situation with regard to the balance of payments-and Senator Michael Baume's correct assessment of its significance on the accumulation of debt which was ignored by Senator Haines in her economically illiterate contribution-will improve substantially in the second half of this year, not altogether for positive reasons. Demand will slow down; therefore the demand for imports will slow and the balance of payments situation will improve.

TALK.START.PARA: —So commodity prices will go down too?

—Not necessarily. Opposition senators also ignore-I will not duplicate the substantial comments made by Senator Schacht-the comments of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). The Opposition only picks up the comments about Australia that are negative. Anything positive it tries to sweep it under the carpet in the hope that nobody will notice. The senior OECD official today praised the Hawke Government for its economic management and said that the country's record debt was not a matter for great concern. Debt is a problem but let us get it in perspective. The OECD official went on to say that there were key issues that were not being debated publicly. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The key issues concern the direction which economic policy has been taking in Australia in recent years, and there I think, there's reason for the Australian people to think that things have been going rather well.

That means a big problem exists. The Government is tackling it. The essential policy formulation is heading in the right direction. It is not all finished. More needs to be done. Economic analysis needs to be continued to be applied. But let us not just preach gloom and doom about the Australian economy for short term political advantage to Australia's detriment.

The Opposition also ignores the critiques of Moody's assessment. When people criticise the Government's statements about Moody's they say, `You are shooting the messenger'. But there are serious people with no political vested interest who very profoundly criticise Moody's assessment. The Opposition ignores that because it is good for Australia and bad for the Opposition. The International Financing Review said:
. . . we agree totally with the criticisms raised by Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.

TALK.START.PARA: —And who are they? What is their standing?
—I will come to someone whose standing the honourable senator will not challenge-in just a moment. Let me continue this statement first:

SPEECH.PARA: If the ultimate risk in Australian Government or government-guaranteed debt is zero-and we believe this to be true-the country's credit rating should be AAA.

Now let us talk about Salomon Bros Inc. Salomon Bros has issued an article entitled `Moody's downgrading unjustified' which states that in the 1989-90 Federal Budget we have a large surplus and there is a retirement of public debt, Government debt is declining, the economy is in a stronger position than it was in 1986. It states that this downgrading was not justified.

There is a substantial body of alternative opinion. But it is ignored because it does not suit the conclusions that particular people want to draw. We have a problem with the debt which Australia faces. The Government does not deny it. All sorts of hyperbole were used, particularly when we debated this question two weeks ago with Senator Stone, about the Government's action to reduce the debt. The Prime Minister has said quite correctly that winding back Australia's current account deficit and our foreign debt is a fundamental Government objective. It has been made quite clear that this is a fundamental objective of the Government's economic strategy. It ought to be, and it would be of any responsible government's economic strategy. But there is no point in just wringing our hands. The situation with which we are confronted, difficult as it is, is not all bad.

There is a significant body of opinion-it is not a view which I share but it is a new body of economic opinion-that says that the Australian foreign debt problem is not a problem. I do not accept that private-public distinction as categorically as those people make it. They are not totally wrong. There is some point in what they are saying-I will refer back to it-but I am not in that school. Those who hold that opinion differentiate-I debated this last time with Senator Stone and I do not really want to do so again-between productive and unproductive debt. Debt is not all equal. Some countries have very big debt burdens arising from government borrowing. But the significance is not that it is government debt, but that the money is borrowed for recurrent expenditure. In other words, it is borrowing for consumption instead of borrowing for investment. That makes a very significant difference. It does not worry me whether it is Government which borrows for consumption or investment, or whether the private sector borrows for consumption or investment. The significance is the difference between productive and unproductive debt.

I regret to say that this is an issue that is not faced up to. There is just shock and horror that there should be a debt. Many of Australia's most successful, most profitable, most stable companies have very big debt. The fact is that they have simply borrowed money to build productive enterprise which can repay the debt. The debt in itself is not a problem, if we are borrowing to invest to generate returns to pay back that debt and to make a profit, irrespective of whether it is the Government or the private sector. That is the distinction that has not been mentioned at all in the Opposition's analysis of the situation.

We are having in Australia an investment phase which is transforming Australia and boosting our productive potential. Business investment growth has averaged 10.8 per cent per annum for the last five years. Regrettably that growth might not be sustainable. But it is a very positive contribution to our export effort. We all wish that lead times in economics were shorter, that when we pressed an investment decision the output would come immediately. Life would be a lot easier for investors and for economic managers. We would not have to deal with the vagaries of long lead times. Our debt is too high and while our current account deficit is too high, our debt is rising. However, it is important that most of our debt is private, not because there is something inherently irrelevant about private debt but because it is private debt borrowed for productive investment. It is earning a return. In the end, it is our ability to fund our debt on a sustainable basis that should be the issue. That tends to be ignored because we get mesmerised by the big numbers. We have to borrow to build a productive economy, to pay back that debt.

I think that substantially it is productive debt, but there is a concern that some of the money is borrowed for non-productive purposes. The distinction I am trying to make is that it should not be a private/public distinction; it should be a distinction between productive and unproductive. That is a very important point. It is where I have some sympathy with some of the academic economists. Private business investment has been increasing at a great rate-10.8 per cent on average over the last five years. Provided that the rate of return on these investments is enough to cover the interest costs, there is no reason why the fact that it is borrowed from overseas should be important. That point is made by Professor Harper and Dr Lim. I do not agree with their entire thesis-I do not agree with those who are saying that the foreign debt is not a problem-but they are making an important point, a point that has been ignored to date in this discussion.

It is a mixed blessing that the desired objective of monetary policy-the necessary outcome that will lead to the slowing down in the increase in our rate of debt that will fix the balance of payments problem-is a slowing of the economy, a slowing in demand which will reduce demand for imports. We have had, I believe, almost unequivocal evidence to this effect. The National Australia Bank review said in its summary:
Overall, the Survey suggests that a slowing in the economy's growth is in prospect, but that this slowdown should be limited.
Westpac has said:

Signs of an easing in the strong levels of demand which have driven the current account deficit and the debt build-up also came yesterday with the Westpac Melbourne Institute leading index of the economy falling by one per cent to 128.6.

Since the Reserve Bank's report we have seen a significant change in the June quarter national accounts. Gross national expenditure grew by only 0.6 per cent in the June quarter. After three-quarters of import volume growth in excess of 8 per cent, imports grew by only 1.2 per cent in the June quarter. Those new elements in the equation do not settle the question finally, but they tilt the balance in favour of saying that we are getting the slowing down that is required at the rate for which we were hoping; we are heading towards the soft landing we need.

I do not say all this to minimise the problem. I am simply saying: Let us get a sober and competent economic analysis. Let us not be startled by the figures. Debt in itself needs to be broken down, to be analysed, to be considered in relation to its potential productive contribution as well as being a proper cause for concern because of the interest repayment that it imposes on our economy.

As Senator Walsh correctly said, in Australia we have an excessively high rate of debt. We have a significant problem with the current account deficit, substantially caused by excessive demand and by the great investment boom we have had. For a number of years we have had a very tight fiscal policy to deal with that. We have had monetary policy to deal with it.

I believe that the responsibility of the Senate in dealing with this sort of question is not to seize on every negative statement that can be found and highlight it to Australia's detriment, but to make a sober economic analysis of the problem and to realise that Government policy is addressing the issue. We must all focus our attention on continuing to address the issue and, hopefully, contribute something to a proper economic analysis of the problem which Australia faces. That is our responsibility. The matter of public importance, as expressed by Senator Stone, does not contribute to that, but I hope that some part of the debate from this side of the House has.

TALK.START.PARA: —The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: SENATE COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 August, on motion by Senator Maguire:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is a blatant ruse. It attempts to give an illusion of protection from nuclear warship accidents to the Australian public but, in reality, it allows for increased nuclear hazards and the violation of the spirit of Australia's international legal obligations. The Committee made 39 recommendations-which sounds commendable- but 36 relate to visits by nuclear-powered warships. Some recommendations are for stricter safety measures to deal with reactor accidents, yet there have been no visits by nuclear-powered vessels to Australia since 30 December 1987, when the USS Long Beach left Hobart. This reflects a steady downward trend in nuclear-powered warship visits in the five years. There were 10 visits in 1985, five in 1986, two in 1987 and none since then. By contrast, there were 33 port calls by nuclear-armed vessels during the 1988 Bicentennial Naval Salute alone.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has created the impression that its recommendations will improve public safety, but they are virtually irrelevant to the present situation. We are getting more and more visits of nuclear-armed warships, yet the Committee did not recognise those dangers at all. In any case, if nuclear-powered warship visits were to recommence, the recommended changes would still be inadequate in the face of a major nuclear reactor accident. The fact remains that the only nuclear warship accident which could have endangered the Australian public in the last 20 months is one involving nuclear weapons. Yet, the Committee has given the green light for nuclear-armed ships to continue visiting our ports. It has denied the possibility of a nuclear weapons accident.

Recommendation No. 37 leaves open the possibility of dry docking ships with nuclear weapons on board. Not only does this recommendation violate the spirit of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty because we would have nuclear weapons on our soil if it took effect, but also it would violate the safety standards which we impose on our own ships. We do not dry dock our own conventionally armed naval vessels with their armaments on board, but the Committee says--

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolute nonsense.

—Perhaps in the past that was the case but I think the honourable senator will find that at present this technique is not used. When an Australian warship goes into dry dock all weapons are normally removed from that ship. This is to avoid an accidental detonation by a welder's spark. This comes out of recent literature and I do not think it can be refuted by former military officers. When an Australian warship goes into dry dock, the weapons are removed but we do not require the same removal of nuclear weapons from a nuclear-armed ship. This is entirely illogical. The consequences of a nuclear weapon accident would be much worse than the consequences of accidents involving a conventional weapon.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has produced a political document, one which panders to the interests of the United States, while disregarding the interests of the Australian public. The Committee's report, along with current Government planning, assumes that nuclear weapon accidents are not possible. Yet the United States has specific emergency procedures for dealing with nuclear weapons accidents in Australia. So, while we say that such accidents are not possible, the United States actually has emergency procedures in this country.

Using the United States Freedom of Information Act, New Zealand researcher Peter Wills has obtained an instruction from the Commander-In-Chief of United States (US) Pacific Forces to personnel under his command. It details the nuclear weapons safety rules, nuclear safety programs, nuclear weapon accident responses and the public affairs policy for such accidents. The United States CINCPAC-Commander-In-Chief Pacific-instruction, which is S8110.4C of 8 May 1984, notes:
`the tremendous destructive power of nuclear weapons and the disastrous consequences which would attend an accidental or unauthorised nuclear detonation';
It envisages lesser nuclear accidents involving:
`the scattering of nuclear material (plutonium or uranium) in the form of finely divided dust . . . near the accident site and downwind'.

The possible causes of the accidents are given as `fire or conventional high-explosive detonation of the (nuclear) weapon'. The CINCPAC document designates an area co- ordinator in Australia to coordinate nuclear weapon accident-significant incident efforts on behalf of CINCPAC. The other area coordinators are in Korea, Japan, Guam, the Philippines, Thailand, the Indian Ocean and Fiji. The Australian area coordinator is the Defence Attache at the US Embassy in Canberra, Colonel R. Dean Stickell. The report makes the ship's commander responsible for recovering as much of the damaged or dispersed nuclear material as possible. He can call on assistance from the Joint Nuclear Accident Coordinating Centre of the Defense Nuclear Agency in the United States, and the Pentagon and the US Department of Energy are authorised to attend the scene.

The CINCPAC document requires public statements to treat a nuclear weapons accident as `an incident involving high explosives'. The United States Navy is informing its personnel through this document to lie about the accident and call it `an incident involving high explosives' unless officials deem it necessary to reveal the presence of nuclear weapons to increase public safety or reduce public alarm. This demonstrates the official United States view that nuclear accidents, ranging to a full nuclear detonation, could happen in Australia, and that emergency preparations are required and, in fact, that the United States has made such emergency preparations.

The Australian Government, by contrast, has made no special arrangements whatsoever, despite the unique monitoring and evacuation procedures which would be needed and the onerous and costly task of decontaminating the affected areas. Yet the Government admitted only last year that it has received a unilateral declaration from the United States that the United States would meet claims arising from an accident involving a nuclear weapon on board a visiting warship. This is a clear acknowledgment that nuclear weapons accidents can happen here.

How could it happen in Australia? During a port visit by a nuclear-armed warship, a nuclear weapon accident could occur in a number of ways. Firstly, nuclear weapons could be incinerated by fire, leading to a cracking of the casing of the warhead and the release of breathable, wind-borne plutonium into the atmosphere. A widespread fire could result from a conventional ammunition explosion and/or the ignition of spilt fuel. Were this to happen in a major port, hundreds, even thousands, of Australians could contract lung cancer in later years from inhaled air-borne plutonium. One-millionth of a gram in the lungs can cause cancer. I think we can all remember the recent tragedy on the USS Iowa when a gun turret blew up. So even in peacetime these accidents can take place.

According to a study by Greenpeace and the Institute for Policy Studies, the United States Navy had 49 ordnance detonation accidents and hundreds of ordnance malfunctions on its surface vessels between 1985 and 1988. Statistics show that from 1973 to 1983 there were an average of 148 fires per year on United States ships or at shore bases. These fires are commonplace. As noted previously, a fire could have disastrous consequences. The fire on the USS Iowa killed 47 crewmen. It was an explosion of 300 kilograms of gunpowder. If the Tomahawk weapons on the USS Iowa-eight of which carry nuclear warheads-had been affected there would have been a major nuclear accident. The Tomahawk launcher on the Iowa was only 45 metres from the location of the fire. The Iowa is identical to the USS New Jersey and the USS Missouri, which are both battleships and which have both visited Australia in recent years.

Nuclear weapons could be lost with the sinking of a vessel during a collision in transit to or from port. There have been many documented sinkings of military ships, including documented loss of nuclear weapons from aircraft. The weapons would have had to be recovered to prevent their casings from corroding and leaking plutonium into the marine ecosystem. If this happened in a closed environment such as Sydney Harbour, in Hobart, or in any of the other Australian ports, it could cause great damage to the ecosystems.

Another potentially damaging effect of nuclear weapons on ships is the fact that nuclear weapons could be stolen or detonated by unbalanced naval personnel. The fire on the USS Iowa is said to have been started by a naval person who was mentally disturbed. There is nothing to stop such a person from stealing a nuclear weapon and using it for personal use or for terrorism. Having these weapons in our ports is adding to the hazard. What would Australian authorities do if in fact there was a nuclear--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no views whatsoever in common with Senator Sanders, who preceded me. He was not a member of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which reported on visits to Australia by nuclear powered or armed vessels. He touched only vaguely upon the findings of this important Senate report. His diatribe was a fiction, a tissue of irrelevancies. I am not impressed by his contribution in the Senate today. As to this important Senate report, after some hundreds of pages of transcript and a 4 1/2-year inquiry which involved 15 senators, the Committee brought down the most thorough study of safety plans for the visits to any ports in the world of nuclear powered or nuclear weapon carrying ships.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make it clear from the beginning that the 39 recommendations in the report, which were supported by both Government and Opposition members alike, led to the enhancement of the safety plans that are in place in the designated ports for such ship visits. The recommendations led to improvements so as to bring those safety plans into line assuredly with what the plans for those ports were intended to be. All of the recommendations that we have brought down, except one with regard to Hobart, can be achieved in a matter of months. The port that is most visited by nuclear powered ships is the harbour and anchorages off Perth in Western Australia. We found that they do not require any adjustment, that they are safe, that they do meet the requirements, and that these requirements are the most stringent of any in the world. So the Committee has given a clean bill of health to the anchorage off Perth. With regard to other ports, there are adjustments and checks to be made which can all be practically achieved in a short time, with the exception only of Hobart.

The report says on page 132 that in all of the years of nuclear ship visits-that is, since 1960-in a period of 29 years and 103 visits by nuclear powered ships there has been no radiation ever detected or in any way associated with the nuclear ship visits. The report states on page 132:

The radiation monitoring in place during nuclear powered warship visits to Australian ports since 1976 has never detected any release of radioactive mat- erial from the vessels. Nor was there any incident involving the release of radioactivity during the visits prior to 1976.

With regard to the wider remarks that some people might make about nuclear powered warships in other countries, let me cite the statements in the report on page 133. The report quoted a 1988 statement that said:

149 nuclear powered warships continue to have a remarkable record of safety and operational effectiveness. The safety record has been validated in over 75 million miles-3,200 years of reactor operation-without a reactor accident or any radioactivity release having a significant environmental effect.
That is a summary of the entire United States experience of nuclear powered warships. With regard to the safeguards that are in place in Australia, chapter 6 of the Senate report states on page 172:
Australian contingency plans are more stringent than the arrangements for warships thought necessary by the United Kingdom and the United States.

It is the finding of the Senate Committee that Australia has in place safety arrangements that are more exacting than any that we know of anywhere in the world. So not only have we got a clean bill of health with regard to the most visited port-a clean bill of health with regard to any testing of radiation in the entire experience of 29 years of nuclear ship visits-but also we have concluded that we have the most stringent and exacting safety requirements.

There were 14 visits of nuclear powered ships in the period 1960-71. Then there was a period of some six years of no visits. In the second period 1976 to 1988 there were 89 visits. So in all there have been 103 visits. With regard to my own State of South Australia, Port Adelaide is a designated port to receive a nuclear powered ship. But no such ship has ever visited my State of South Australia. Moreover, on pages 20 and 27 of the report it is stated that not one visit is planned for South Australia. It is a designated port, nevertheless, in the event that it should become necessary.

On page 250 we concluded that Port Adelaide-and by the way Townsville as well-should be checked with regard to recent land use changes in the vicinity of the port so that the intended safety measures in the plans for those two ports can be guaranteed to be up to date. The only permanent restriction that we have recommended relates to Hobart and it is on these grounds: there is an area around the ship that is berthed called `zone two' which envisages the need for safety requirements in the event of the wind blowing a particular way. In the case of Hobart, the distance involved is 1,200 metres. The 1,200 metres in zone two is a radius defined when the ship needs to be moved from its docked position within 3 1/2 hours. Because there is a hospital 900 metres away from the berth at the Hobart port, we have found it impractical to be sure that that hospital could be evacuated. Yet that may be the advised action if the wind is blowing from an accident involving a nuclear powered ship that is berthed at Hobart.

However, let me foreshadow that if that 3 1/2-hour removal time was reduced to, say, two hours and it could be guaranteed that the ship could be removed within two hours, then that 900 metres may be an acceptable radius for zone two designation. It is up to the government of the day to determine whether that is a fair reaction to the one restrictive recommendation that we have made. With regard to Darwin, Brisbane and Jervis Bay we needed to ensure that the evacuation proposals in the safety plan were operable. As soon as they are shown to be operable, then those ports would be cleared to have entirely acceptable safety plans.

All the recommendations, with the exception possibly of the one with regard to Hobart, are achievable, are practical and can be put in place within a matter of months. What the Senate Committee has found is that some adjustments need to be made to ensure that the safety plans are operable in the designated ports. We believe that these can be achieved so that all of the designated ports for such ship visits are operable and ready to receive ships in a matter of months.

There is also nothing to hide in this area of visiting nuclear powered warships or, indeed, any warships which may have weapons. We have unanimously urged that the safety plans be made public in all the ports. The plans are already public in Western Australia and we have expectations that the safety plans will be made public in the other designated ports. So I conclude by noting that this has been a sound inquiry of the Senate. It has given endorsement to the safety plans that are in place around Australia and I thank all of those associated with the inquiry such as our secretaries, research assistants, technical advisers and all those who have made submissions that have contributed to this successful inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One would think that after three years-that is what I thought it was, but Senator Teague has just said it is 4 1/2 years: a long time, anyway, in the making, 500 pages and 39 recommendations-the people of Australia could have expected a comprehensive and sensible report from this inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. However, this is not the case. A huge body of evidence which was presented to the Committee has been ignored, some of which Senator Sanders repeated when he referred to the plans which the United States Navy has in place to deal with nuclear weapons accidents. The Committee found that such accidents were unlikely to occur and that no contingency plan was necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it almost incredible that the members of the Committee could come to such a conclusion after the evidence that was presented. The report refers mostly to nuclear powered warships, as Senator Sanders said, and holds up the Western Australian port safety plan as the best one around the country and, as far as they knew, the first one that was made public. If that is the best there is around the country, heaven help the rest of the country in the unlikely event of a nuclear accident, either with a nuclear powered ship or a nuclear armed ship. By their own admission, information was denied to the committee by nuclear navies. Therefore, many assumptions are made.

For example, it is assumed that the United States (US) Navy would immediately notify Australian authorities if a nuclear accident occurred on board one of its ships either in a port or tied up in a safe anchorage outside a port. The US Government information which I submitted to the inquiry clearly suggests otherwise. The last thing that the US Navy would want to do is to admit that there had been an accident involving nuclear weapons, and in fact I want to table a document, with the permission of the Senate, entitled `Naval nuclear reactors' and read from that just a short piece about the Belknap disaster in November 1975. During night exercises the aircraft-carrier USS John F. Kennedy collided with the cruiser USS Belknap in rough seas 70 miles east of Sicily. It is stated:

The collision caused major damage to both ships, with the Belknap's superstructure wedged underneath the overhanging flight deck of the carrier. The carrier's fuel lines were ruptured, raining gasoline over the deck of the Belknap. A raging fire punctuated with explosions lasted for more than two hours.

The collision is one of the best-known naval accidents ever, but in all the documentation, no mention has ever been made of the nuclear weapons present aboard both ships, or the grave danger the Navy believed the nuclear warheads aboard the Belknap faced as a result of the fires.

Minutes after the incident occurred the commander of Carrier Striking Forces for the Sixth Fleet sent a secret nuclear weapons accident message ``a broken arrow'' to the Pentagon warning of the ``high probability that nuclear weapons aboard the Belknap were involved in fire and explosions''. He had good reason for concern. Much of the fire-fighting equipment aboard the Belknap was destroyed by the collision and aluminium superstructure of the ship actually caught fire, melting and running like ``hot butter'' in the words of one US Navy Journalist. Fortunately for a large area of Italy in the Mediterranean the fire was brought under control a scant 30 feet from the missile magazine.
This is the kind of information which that Committee has ignored and I am going to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Vallentine, are you seeking leave to table a document?
—Yes, I seek leave to table this document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Another grossly misleading assumption in the report is that the reference accident would not result in a containment breach should a nuclear reactor accident occur. It is a very optimistic scenario which fatally flaws the entire document. Nowhere does the Committee explain where the reference accident came from. I asked the Committee for information about that and I never got a reply from it after I presented my testimony. It is a very optimistic scenario which does not take into account what might happen in the real world.

SPEECH.PARA: The report is also contradictory. Chapter 12 repeatedly states that there is no need for contingency plans dealing with nuclear weapons accidents, but recommendation 38 advises the Department of Defence to continue work on its current unofficial draft plan to deal with such accidents. So what are we to believe? Is there a risk or is there not a risk from nuclear weapons accidents in Australian reports? The report is contradictory.

The Western Australian plan, as I have said, is considered by the Committee to be the best plan available, which is absolutely ridiculous, dealing as it does only with nuclear powered ships and in a totally inadequate manner. It does not deal with the possibility of nuclear weapons accidents at all. The section in the Western Australian plan about removal of a stricken vessel would be laughable if it were not so serious. How to remove a vessel with a damaged reactor is a huge problem. What constitutes a remote anchorage is quite insulting. The Committee members, with the exception of Senator Dunn, who submitted a substantial dissenting report, have made fools of themselves by expecting Western Australians to believe that the designated remote anchorages are safe. The plan recommends that a submarine or cruiser berthed at Garden Island should, after suffering a nuclear reactor accident, be moved three kilometres further north, closer to Perth. What on earth is the point of that? That is how ridiculous the Western Australian plan is. The so-called safe anchorages are closer to the heavily populated areas than the original berths.

Action on the long list of recommendations is entrusted by the Committee to the Visiting Ships Panel (Nuclear). This group failed miserably to oversee the job given to it in 1976 by the then Minister for Defence, Mr Sinclair, which was to ensure that port safety plans were drawn up for all the approved berths. It took 10 years for the Western Australian plan to be completed, and it was dragged out of a reluctant State government by community pressure, not due to any effort by the Visiting Ships Panel (Nuclear). Yet it is that Panel which is entrusted by the Committee to do all this nice paperwork that Senator Teague has referred to. Of course, most of the recommendations can be put in place, because they mostly amount to making public plans which need to be completed and upgraded to the level of the Western Australian plan, which is totally inadequate. The only real recommendation of any significance in the report is that Macquarie Wharf in Hobart will not receive nuclear powered warship visits any longer. But I have been told by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in a personal conversation that there is no need for Hobart people to think that they are going to be relieved of the burden of nuclear powered warship visits. They will merely find another berth out in the Derwent so that visits from such ships can continue.

The question of exercises is raised in recommendation 31, but there are no specifications for the type of exercise listed. For example, I have been told that the Fremantle fire station would be totally unprepared to deal with an accident involving either nuclear weapons or nuclear reactors. It has no contingency plans. It has not even discussed what to do in the event of a nuclear accident, let alone practised any procedures. In South Australia, Senator Teague's own State, fire fighters requested exercises so that they would be a little better prepared than their Western Australian counterparts. The exercises took place some time last year or the end of the year before and were a total fiasco. The Committee ought to have known about that, too. It was a massive exercise in people trying to contact other people and who would do what, but what was actually done in the end resulted in very little indeed. It was acknowledged by the fire fighters who had requested the exercise because their union was concerned about the risks to which fire fighters would be put without adequate training, without adequate safety material and so on, that the exercise itself was an absolute disaster. So one would wonder what nature these exercises would take. I bet they would not take the form of actually having people in place and working out a scenario. The exercises would probably involve phoning up all the people on the list to make sure the telephone numbers were still in the right order.

This report gives further justification to those who call on the Government to ban visits of all nuclear armed and nuclear powered warships. It gives no assurances of safety. Indeed, no report of this kind could be expected to do so. What is abundantly clear is that the Government it taking unnecessary risks, jeopardising the safety of Australian people and the Australian environment, to suit the flag-waving and rest and recreation requirements of foreign nuclear navies. Nuclear ship visits contribute nothing to Australia's defence. They pose risks which we do not have to take. It is about time that the people who defended the continuation of these nuclear warship visits acknowledged that this is an unnecessary risk being imposed on the people and the environment of Australia by a government whose job is being done by foreign nuclear navies having made available to them nice port calls which do not have anything to do with the defence of Australia. Of course, when these ships visit Australian ports, we are nuclear targets and are put at risk, in addition to the risk of accident, which is quite considerable.

How can Senator Teague say that the United States Navy has a perfect safety record? The record of the Soviet Navy is no better, of course. At the moment there are 50 nuclear warheads and nine nuclear reactors lying on the ocean floor. It could be said that the world's sixth largest nuclear power after the United States, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, France, the United Kingdom and China is the deep blue sea. How can nuclear navies proclaim a perfect safety record before the world community when these reactors are on the ocean floor? The nuclear reactor casings are bound to corrode in time. So we already have an enormous environmental problem on our hands. I do not know how people can continue to defend the safety records of navies in the light of the evidence. It is almost beyond comprehension. It does not do this Senate Committee any credit whatsoever to ignore the quality of evidence before it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment very briefly, because I think only a brief comment is warranted, on the contributions of Senator Sanders and Senator Vallentine, neither of whom, I hasten to say, was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which has produced the report entitled Visits to Australia by nuclear powered or armed vessels. I am fairly sure that Senator Sanders, for one, has not read the report. I thought his submission, where it was not irrelevant, was flagrant rubbish. I found it to be a very unsatisfactory and very unsavoury contribution, and totally irresponsible. Senator Vallentine, at least, was more responsible in her submission, but again I think her contribution was made up of misunderstandings, misrepresentations and internal contradictions. I think the kindest thing that I could say about it is that it self-destructed.

SPEECH.PARA: I will come in a moment to some of the type of evidence that Senator Vallentine presented to the Committee to show what techniques are used in this sort of presentation of unrealistic risks and unwarranted assumptions about these risks. First of all, I should make it quite clear that the way in which this report was presented in the media here and overseas misunderstood and misrepresented the nature of the report. The Committee looked at two things: whether nuclear reactor powered ships visiting Australian ports were a risk and, if so, whether the precautions we were taking were adequate; and, secondly, whether possibly nuclear armed ships in Australian ports were a potential risk to those ports. For instance, Senator Sanders kept on talking about events on the high seas, firing 16-inch guns. One does not do that in harbour. Senator Vallentine was talking about deep sea reactor accidents in submarines. One does not do that in harbour. When the remarks are not misunderstood, they are almost totally irrelevant.

The Committee found that the reference accident of a reactor, which is a contained meltdown, was a reasonable basis for a worst case scenario on which planning should be based. We also found that we could discern no risk from the presence of nuclear weapons. Nuclear weapons are, in fact, in their stowed harbour state the only totally safe explosive ever produced. They are much safer than TNT. The remarks about accidents at sea are quite irrelevant in considering the safety of weapons stowed in harbour.

The Committee did make a number of recommendations where we did not think that the Nuclear Visiting Ships Panel (Nuclear) had seen through the detail of some of the consequences of its reference accident. Some of the things that should have been done were not done. The report listed these, with one exception which has been mentioned by my colleague Senator Teague-the position of Hobart hospital. All of them can be remedied by fairly simple action by the authorities. With that done, all the ports which are presently listed as nuclear berths, with the exception of the berth alongside Hobart, are suitable.

I would like to come to something which worried me: the quality of the evidence presented to the Committee by vehement opponents of the visits by nuclear powered or possibly nuclear armed ships. Senator Vallentine has presented some evidence today, as she did to the Committee, and I will read out a section of the report that deals with this evidence. It is from page 196 of the Committee report. It reads:
Senator Vallentine told the Committee that, according to a 1973 United States Navy reactor disaster control plan, the `Navy found the melt-down'-
this is the nuclear reactor-

`go right down through the ship spilling hot radioactive materials to the bottom of the harbour . . .' When the Committee tried to obtain a copy of the plan, it became clear that Senator Vallentine had not seen the plan that she purported to quote from. She was in fact quoting from a booklet authored by a New York peace activist. It would seem that this author had not seen the plan either but was relying on an account in a Honolulu newspaper. The journalist who wrote this account did not purport to have seen the plan . . .

So it goes on. People quoting each other and building up a totally spurious case is, in my view, one of the more disturbing aspects of dealing with matters which are highly emotional. We like to rely more on facts than prejudices. One other witness worried me very much. He came out as an expert witness to the Committee but he gave the most sweeping statements which, on probing, he had no basis for at all. For instance, he said:
Any United States warship in an Australian port would be targeted by Soviet strategic missile forces.

I can well believe that any ship capable of strategic strike itself might be targeted, but the idea that any ship would be targeted is an idea that I have seen no responsible strategic analyst suggest and the particular witness who made that sweeping statement gave no evidence for it all, he just said he knew it. Before he gave his evidence to the Committee-he did not have the courtesy to come before the Committee first-he gave an account to Sydney newspapers showing the devastating affects of a nuclear reactor accident in Sydney. For one thing, his assessment was wrong, but quite apart from that he was unaware that there are no berths for nuclear-powered ships in Sydney Harbour. Yet he was giving this lurid account of what the consequences would be. Then he purported to examine the consequences of a nuclear weapons accident. The accident he examined involved five kilograms of plutonium burning uncontained on the upper deck of a ship for three hours. He did not have the slightest idea of how this could possibly come about or why it would be allowed to continue, but that was the basis on which he gave his evidence. It was highly unsatisfactory and I thought brought great discredit to a man who purported to come before the Committee as an expert witness.

I have dissented from or elaborated on the Committee report in one important area, that is, with regards to the arrangements for the dry-docking of ships that might or might not be nuclear-armed. Contrary to the opinions of Senator Sanders, whose ignorance is almost limitless, ships needing minor external repairs to such things as the rudder or the propellers berth without de-ammunitioning. If no work is to go on anywhere near the magazines, they are docked for minor repairs without de-ammunitioning. But I am worried, not that there is a risk from the point of view of safety, because a ship in dock has all the firefighting arrangements and a ship in dry-dock is exactly as safe as a similar ship alongside, but about the industrial action that might be taken to prevent a ship either being docked, if it is potentially nuclear-armed or, if it is docked, being undocked, which is what upset the possible arrangements for HMS Invincible when she was out here some years ago.

You will remember, Mr Acting Deputy President, that not too long ago the berthing of a British ship was prevented by striking tug crews. I think we have got to have a system whereby our dry docks are under proper naval control. They are an essential part of the operational availability of a fleet and it is just not acceptable that operational ships, either our own or visiting foreign warships, should be held to ransom by industrial action by unions whose interests are not those of the defence of the country. Now this would not be easy, but the number of people involved is not great and I think the Navy should take over, with uniformed, disciplined people, the operation of its dry docks. We have recently established, both on the west coast and in Sydney, berthing facilities for the operational fleet quite clear of the dockyard area, so uniformed people handle it, so operational ships are not affected by industrial disputes. This would come to a head if we ever tried to dock a ship that might be nuclear-armed. We must have the dry-docking facilities and the sort of disciplined control so that we and our allies can operate our ships effectively in the defence of this country.
Debate (on motion by Senator McKiernan) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 August, on motion by Senator Short:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not interesting that we are now talking about the report entitled Who pays the piper calls the tune? The coalition strongly rejects the base recommendations of this report, which are made for no better reason than for the electoral advantage of the Australian Labor Party. I say that it is interesting because a string of decisions are being made for the electoral advantage of the Labor Party, not the least being the decision leading to the debate we have had in recent times about the stamp allocation. The changes that are recommended for the funding of election campaigns will attack basic freedoms.

SPEECH.PARA: The third recommendation, in paragraph 7.16, requires that all donations to political parties for campaign and non-campaign purposes alike be disclosed. People might suspect that, on the surface, that is very reasonable, but one needs to know the reasoning behind the Government's decision in this matter. In effect, this is a calculated move to deter business and private individuals from making donations to the non-Labor parties. We have seen example after example of people who are known supporters of non-Labor parties being jeopardised in their business procedures by Labor governments. It is cogently pointed out in the dissenting report that, whereas such full disclosure will create a pressure for business to donate equally to both the major parties, the same constraints will not and have never applied to the unions, which will remain the most reliable paymasters and dictators of the Labor Party.
Who would be surprised to find out which union is donating to the Labor Party? No-one. But would people not be interested to know what private enterprise is donating and to what party?

TALK.START.PARA: —Or which union is donating to the Liberal Party.

—Or, as Senator Puplick says, which union may donate to the Liberal Party. The Government members of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, who are avidly pursuing the self-interest of the Labor Party, do not provide any argument to refute the contention made by Sir John Carrick in a report of 1983 that disclosure inevitably is intimidatory. It is certainly worth noting that President Nixon's enemies list, as revealed by Watergate, shows how a vengeful government can misuse the knowledge of private and corporate donations. And let us not forget that the recommendation will affect not merely the large corporations but also smaller businesses, far more vulnerable to intimidation from the trade unions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party has clearly decided to strike at the basic grassroots financial support of its opponents without regard to the violation of liberty and choice that this will clearly involve. Not content with attacking its opponents, who do not rely on the donations of a few massive unions, this Labor Government is intent upon forcing the broadcast media to carry the cost of its political advertising. We are not asking the community or the taxpayer to pay the cost of our advertising; we are saying that we will do it. We are saying that what we do should be private. Why should corporations be maligned by the Labor Party?

The majority on the Committee, and the Government, cannot claim that these recommendations result from extensive public input. What, in effect, the majority is endorsing is nothing more than a thinly argued submission from the Labor Party itself. The Committee has not taken on board the recommendations from other parties, particularly coalition parties; it has simply stuck to its own agenda and that is what we are left with in this report.

The Committee has the gall not only to recommend in paragraph 6.8 that free time be given to the political parties at the expense of the commercial media, but also to say that such free time would constitute a community service announcement. How much more outrageous is this going to get? It is nothing short of an Orwellian concept for members of parliament solemnly to proclaim that election propaganda is some vast exercise in public benefit-a social good like our health services, I suppose.

It is not recommended in this self-serving report-whose authors are determined that the Hawke Labor Government will call the tune as to electoral manipulation-that the amounts of taxpayers' funds already given over to paying for electoral campaigns are to be reduced in proportion to the massive donation of free time that is to be extorted from the commercial media. No such luck! Both the public dollar and the reliable union donations will be diverted into other areas of campaigning where it is evident that Labor strategists see greater benefit in allowing a continuation of an unrestricted free market in campaign advertising.

Whenever a very substantial change to the electoral ground rules is proposed, honourable senators have not only the right but also the duty to ask for evidence of the necessity for change. The majority report of the Committee has failed in this regard. If paid political advertising on the broadcast media is to be banned, where is the concrete evidence of corrupt practices that flourish at present-corrupt practices that obviously do not affect the print media? All we get is the admission in paragraph 8.9 that `there is no firm evidence of corrupt practice in Australian political fundraising'. I also strongly support the contention expressed in the minority report that if we are at risk from corruption, we must look to the massive discretionary powers recommended for the bureaucracy to exercise over political parties and so-called third parties that may engage in public comment, for whatever reason, at election time.

No real evidence is presented in the superficial international comparisons that trot out the hackneyed term `laissez faire' to criticise Australian electoral practice and gloss over the fact that paid political advertising is permitted in those nations whose political culture is closest to that of Australia-for example, the United States of America, Canada, the United Kingdom and New Zealand. Neither is there acknowledgment of the fact that in Britain, where there are no paid political advertisements on broadcast media, the media is far more tightly regulated than in Australia. Nor must we forget that in remote and rural districts the broadcast media is the only effective means of communication for many Australians.

The majority report again glosses over evidence submitted by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations that compulsory free advertising as proposed by the Labor Party would affect the ability of the licensees to recover costs, when licence fees already amount to 6.1 per cent of the gross revenue of commercial television. Paragraph 6.59 sets out the plain truth that the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters rejected the notion that simply because the airwaves are public property, broadcasters should have further burdens placed upon them.

I am very proud that the Opposition had the courage and public spirit to advocate to this shonky inquiry that public funding itself should be replaced with tax deductability for political donations, to a ceiling. The Liberal Party has not forgotten that political parties are voluntary organisations that have no special claim on public money. As a Liberal, I totally reject the `snouts in the trough' mentality that inspires the Labor Party and finds expression in the recommendations of this report.

The apportioning of the free broadcast time is evaded in the majority report which calls for a committee to make this decision. Allocation of time on the basis of support at a previous election, or the number of seats held, would tend to act in favour of incumbent parties-in this case, the Labor Party. The Labor forces would be well served by a ban on broadcast advertising, paid and free, prior to by-elections. An incumbent government has every motive for diminishing political awareness in such unwelcome circumstances. The implementation of these ill-argued, dishonest recommendations would reduce political parties to bureaucratically supervised parasitic organisations, actively discouraging individuals and businesses from involvement with a political process that in the deepest sense would be morally corrupt.
Debate (on motion by Senator McKiernan) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Tax File Numbers System

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 August, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators would be aware, on 3 May 1989 the Senate referred the tax file numbers system, with particular reference to the mass mail-out, to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, of which Senator Coates is the Chairman. During the hearing, persons who appeared before the Committee and gave evidence included Australian Taxation Office representatives and the Privacy Commissioner. Quite a number of persons and organisations made submissions, including the Australian Taxation Office, the Australian People's Representative Council and the Australian Taxpayers Association which are involved in or concerned about tax file numbers going astray in the mail.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee believes that the Taxation Office's decision to mass-mail the unsolicited tax file numbers was reasonable. The Tax Office told the Committee that it had given due regard to privacy considerations. In view of the evidence presented to us both verbally and in writing, I would not doubt that. I was rather overawed by sitting face to face with and eyeballing the Commissioner of Taxation. It was the first time I had done so; I hope it will be the last. I was impressed with the evidence he gave. The Tax Office, in the case it put to us, indicated that it had given due regard to this matter. One of my colleagues in the other place, Donald Cameron, would take a different view. But I believe, given the circumstances, that the Tax Office did the best it could. We must remember that the mass-mailing was done in a hurry. Any faults that came out of the exercise were caused in the main by the pressure the Government applied to the Office to complete the mass-mailings. In my State of Tasmania, because of breakdowns in the system, it was not possible to mass-mail any of the tax file numbers. Consequently, there was a deal of confusion in Tasmania and a lot of people were inconvenienced. It was interesting to note that the Australian Taxpayers Association and the Taxation Institute of Australia were strongly supportive of the Australian Tax Office's decision to mass-mail tax file numbers.

Evidence given at the public hearings and the submissions indicated that the main concern of the public was the computer error that occurred in respect of mass-mailing, particularly in Queensland, the Northern Territory and Western Australia. Even the Taxation Office agreed that the number of incorrect mailings was unacceptably high. The Committee believes that the programming error that occurred in the Australian Taxation Office was most unfortunate and should have been avoided. Even the Commissioner of Taxation himself, Mr Boucher, told the Committee, `The error was indicative of the state of our systems in many respects and why the Government has approved the redesign of our systems'. So as the result of that exercise and the faults that were shown by it it is interesting to note that we have received information from the Commissioner of Taxation that he gave instructions on 15 May to implement a further level of checking on program or system changes before they go into production. I suppose we could say that out of something bad something good always comes and in this case, because of the errors and mistakes that were made and the pressure that was put upon the Taxation Office, at least the Government has realised that the computer based system at the Taxation Office needs upgrading. As a result of this exercise that is exactly what has happened.

I was very impressed with the evidence given by the Privacy Commissioner. He showed concerns, particularly about the inadvertent disclosure of confidential tax information relating to 34 Adelaide taxpayers. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) himself replied to that matter on 9 May in the other place. The Privacy Commissioner, as I said, had one or two concerns. He believed that the actual mail itself could have been sent in a different form. Given all the facts and the time constraints that were evidenced at the time, our Committee believes that the Australian Taxation Office did the best it could under the circumstances but I would hope personally that on any future occasion when something like this happens the pressure that the Government puts on the Australian Taxation Office is not as strong so that it can get its act right first up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take the time of the Senate for too long on this, and I obviously will not have the opportunity to do so, but I felt it was important that somebody from the Australian Democrats spoke on this report. In fact, I was quite staggered when the Opposition took up the question of the operation of the tax file number when, in fact, it was the Australian Democrats in the debate upon passage of that legislation who pointed out the pitfalls into which that system fell. SPEECH.PARA: When the legislation was passed we pointed this out and already the Government has had to move on credit reference agencies.
