DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the conclusion of my remarks earlier in the day I was moved to observe that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill offers no benefits to the Aboriginal community. It offers no benefits to the wider community. In fact, it is a piece of legislation which will plunge us all again into a political imbroglio which will do irreparable damage to the cause of the Aboriginal people and will stunt their growth in terms of development in the whole range of areas which are crying out for improvement. It is a political statement by Mr Hand. It is not a piece of legislation that has the support of the majority of the Aboriginal community. In fact, it is a piece of legislation that has very modest support from any group in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not question Mr Hand's motive. I believe that his motive was altruistic. But there is none so dangerous as he who knows he is right. This Bill does not come into the Parliament, it does not come into this chamber, as the result of the maturation of consultation, cooperation or goodwill, or the manifestation of the aspirations of the Aboriginal community; rather it comes to us as the manifestation of the preconceived obsession of Minister Hand who, well prior to becoming Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, harboured, first of all, uniform land rights, which he was unable to achieve through his own Party, notwithstanding cruel and broken promises made to the Aboriginal community. So he replaced that aspiration, first of all, with the preamble that is in the Bill which tells us that members of the Aboriginal community were the prior owners of Australia in a legal sense. He is saying that Aborigines are entitled to repossession and compensation, but he is unable to achieve that for them, so he is simply stating it as a fact and putting it in the Bill as if to cleanse himself of some of his eastern seaboard middle class guilt. We ultimately have this piece of legislation before us which is a substitute for something he would rather have had. It is the creation of a new political system. It is superimposing on our present social, economic and political structure a new political system which embraces, in the mind of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), economic, political and social reforms. It is a token piece of legislation fraught with enormous dangers in respect of development-the development of the Aboriginal community and Aboriginal people individually.

It does not come to us as the result of consultation. Mr Hand exhorts us to believe that it is the result of consultation. He tells us in his exhortations that no piece of legislation has ever come to the Parliament as the result of more consultation. The difficulty is that Mr Hand does not know the difference between talking to Aboriginal people and talking at them. I have been overwhelmed by Aboriginal groups who have complained about Mr Hand flying into their community, climbing out of his aeroplane, haranguing them about what he believes is good for them, getting back into his aeroplane and flying out again-leaving them confused, frustrated and with an enormous sense of anxiety because they have not been party to discussions. They have been privy only to the aspirations of this Minister.

It seems to be the ongoing sin of this Government that it feels compelled to continue to make political statements rather than arrive at effective achievements for the Aboriginal community. What has it done in respect of health? What does this Bill do in respect of Aboriginal health, Aboriginal education, Aboriginal housing, or the enormous problems confronting a wide section of the Aboriginal community in respect of the abuse of alcohol? What does it do about their frustrations because of their inadequacies in terms of their integration into the communities and towns in which they live and their integration with the towns upon whose outskirts they live in abominable circumstances? Absolutely nothing.

One only has to go to the Kimberley in Western Australia to see graphically, first hand, how this Government has failed to address the fundamental problems affecting the Aboriginal community. The poor, the sick, the suffering, the alcoholics, the kids who sleep in the street and the children suffering from malnutrition-they are not interested in a political statement which gives them ATSIC. They are not interested in a new political structure. They are not interested in a new voting system. They are not interested in a phoney, pretend self-determination. They are interested in immediate needs.

By way of an example, the Kimberley represents 2 per cent of the population of Western Australia. It also represents 50 per cent of recorded incidents of venereal disease in Western Australia. What has this Federal Government done about it? What has it done in respect of funding? One can pick any one of a number of towns, and they are all precise, pristine examples. I turn to Fitzroy Crossing as a good example. It has a school with 386 children. It has not even got a school nurse, yet it has in the classrooms in the junior school kids with venereal disease and hearing and sight problems. The Government can spend millions of dollars launching ATSIC upon them, but cannot address those fundamental problems.

There was a test carried out in the 1987-88 period of 34 contacts who had venereal disease-in fact, they had syphilis. It was found that 75 per cent of them had contracted the end stage, in other words, the stage where the disease affects the brain. That is a modest number to test, but it is symptomatic of the problem that confronts the people in the north-west of Western Australia. The community health sisters are absolutely run off their feet. In the Kimberley region they each have roughly 400 clients. So, of course, there is no environmental health. There is no preventive medicine. There is no counselling. There is no family planning. There is no assistance for pregnant women. There is no counselling support or help for mothers with young babies. But there is lots of money to spend on ideals.

One only has to look at the problems in respect of alcohol. The Kimberley, the Pilbara, the Gascoyne, the Murchison and the Goldfields of Western Australia are not unique. This is a problem across Australia, manifest, I suspect, as a result of the frustrations of the Aboriginal community because of the perception that Aboriginals are offered little hope for the future. How many institutions across Australia are provided to offer assistance for this enormous problem, which is beginning, in many respects, to engulf whole communities? None. This is a problem that spreads throughout the communities. There are children suffering from malnutrition because of a lack of food, never mind nutrition. Young men are dying in their late teens and early twenties simply because of alcoholism, with kidney failure, liver problems and heart attacks. If they were white and living in the metropolitan area they would have the Salvation Army, the Jesus People or the other wonderful voluntary organisations that look after these people, but because they are in isolated areas they receive none of those benefits. This Government, which purports to be caring, compassionate and concerned and gives us this legislation as a manifestation of that, does nothing for them.

What does it do for them in respect of education? Nothing. To demonstrate that we have equality in this country, little Aboriginal children who can barely speak the language are put in grade 1 with white children, whose prerequisite for going to school is to be able to speak English as a first language. They are asked to compete on a daily basis. And we wonder why Aboriginal children spell `emu' as `hemeru'; it is because that is how they say it. They cannot speak the language but each year, in the cause of equality, they are pushed through to grade 2 to grade 3 to grade 4 and leave school at the age of 15 or 16 with absolutely no education because their fundamental problems are not addressed. If they did get an education, where would they find a job? What skills are there for them? What training is there for them? What jobs are they offered? Nothing. One may wonder why one finds all these young men and women hanging around towns and receiving social welfare benefits of some sort, the men permanently drunk and the women permanently pregnant, without any assistance, without any help, without any guidance and, least of all, any support from government agencies.

One may go to almost any hospital in an area which has a large Aboriginal population and one will find the majority of the patients admitted are suffering from causes which are the result of a lack of proper attention. The number of children in these hospitals because they failed to thrive is staggering. They are admitted to hospital, given nourishment and support, sent back out again, and they come back later on. The level of infant mortality is staggering. But is it addressed? Of course, it is not addressed. They are some of the fundamental problems that I would have thought this Government ought to be addressing.

One can go to almost any town in Australia where there is a high Aboriginal population and look at the housing conditions, and without exception one will find that they are absolutely deplorable. There would not be a member of this Government that would live in any of those homes, but they are good enough for other people. Suddenly, to make themselves feel good and comfortable and warm inside, they will build homes, intermingled in the community in these country towns, and put in them Aboriginal people who, but perhaps two or three decades ago, lived in their primitive tribal circumstances and expect them to suddenly flourish and to live side by side and to be accepted as part of the social fabric of the community. When they are rejected and they turn to alcohol and violence and all those sorts of things as a manifestation of their deprived circumstances, we wonder why, we set up committees, we have reports and we have government findings. But never do we address the fundamental problems.

Mr Acting Deputy President, in the few moments I have got left, let me simply say this about this Bill: it purports to replace the Department of Aboriginal Affairs-as I say, it is simply a political statement-but it bears no relationship to the geographic or the demographic distribution of the Aboriginal people. As Senator Peter Baume observed to me this morning, when the various boundaries for the regions and the zones were drawn, kin and skin were divided: there seems to be just no common feature, except that the draftsman has purported to find lines that for some reason have a commonality. I do not know what it is, because it is not skin, it is not kin, it is not language, it is not culture, it is not clan, and it is not groupings. The people who are put into these regions-put in, I might say, by the arbitrary lines of the Minister-bear no common relationship with each other. As the zones are drawn and the commissions are appointed, they will represent everybody but really represent nobody because of the arbitrary way that the Government and the Minister have drafted the legislation.

This legislation really does not in any way give self-determination. It ought to be called the Aboriginal protection legislation, because the Minister can do anything from appointing commissioners to deciding whether or not a ballot has been effective. He is the one that decides these things. I have to say that the legislation is a fraud; it is a failure; it is a blight on this Government. In my view, it will only cause chaos, turmoil, disillusionment, disappointment, and ultimately absolute frustration for the Aboriginal community who are having it foisted upon them as a result of the ideological bigotry of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who in his ambition might be altruistic but who in his manifestation is totally incompetent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission-ATSIC-is unjustified, unnecessary and culturally inappropriate. The detailed proposal that has emerged in the Bill is faulty and unsafe.
—That is good prose.

—I am coming to that, Senator Baume. If pursued, it will operate to the detriment of the very people it is designed allegedly to serve. It is likely to lead to worse outcomes than those produced by the bodies it is to replace; to worse services for Aboriginal and Islander people; to less accountability of the Commission and its servants to the Aboriginal and Islander people; and to less accountability to all Australians. There is not a clearer or more accurate description of the legislation that we have before us today than those remarks, which were written in the dissenting report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs by Senators Peter Baume and Ron Boswell. I am happy to see that Senator Peter Baume is in the chamber with us here this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year we celebrated Australia's Bicentenary. There was much noise and hype from the Government that we were all Australians working together. With the beautiful and rich diversity of nationalities that make up our nation, we were all celebrating together. And I am sure we can all recall very many instances during last year when we had this opportunity of celebrating the bicentenary of our nation. We were all to work together and celebrate together-and `together', I believe, is the crucial word-not as blacks opposed to whites, as opposed to Asians and other nationalities.

Now we see that what the Government is in reality proposing to do with this legislation that we are debating here this evening is to honour that togetherness by setting one people against another in Australia. That, I feel, is what this legislation is all about. It is about two Australias-one white and one black. I suppose that, in the light of recent reports that our Asian population will be substantially increased by early next century, there could also be the possibility of looking at creating another commission-one indeed for all the Asian Australians.

This legislation officially sets the Aborigines apart from other Australians. The Government already encourages such action when it allows the Department of Aboriginal Affairs here in Canberra to fly the Aboriginal land rights flag instead of the Australian flag. The Aboriginal flag was designed to become the flag of a foreign state, an Aboriginal state to be carved out of Australia. It did it again when it allowed its Minister, Hon. Gerry Hand, to boycott Australian bicentennial celebrations last year. I consider that the effect of such actions is indeed divisive. As a nation, we say that we are repulsed by the apartheid system in South Africa. Yet if this legislation passes, we are about to let slip through what I believe to be quite simply the establishment of a similar system in this country.

We are at the crucial turning point in our history. Either we can adopt this legislation, with its focus on separate development for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders apart from the wide Australian community, or we can concentrate on ensuring that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are encouraged to take their place as equal, responsible and independent Australians alongside-not separate from-the rest of the community.

Blacks and whites have much to offer each other. We have to realise that we belong to each other and collectively to Australia. `Aboriginal people have the power to help unite this nation and give it a real reason for being'-these are the words of a former Aboriginal Affairs Department Secretary, Charles Perkins. Yet I suppose that these words have fallen on deaf ears in the Government. This Government is trying to achieve the impossible, to rectify what it sees as past wrongs, and in the process is creating even further wrongs and injustices. It is an extremely worrying tendency which is happening more frequently in bureaucratic circles throughout this country. I believe it is attempting to single out the Aborigines for reasons of race and deny them their fundamental rights as equal, responsible Australian citizens. I want to quote from one of Australia's leading Aboriginals on the subject, Bob Liddle-a well-known and successful Northern Territory Aboriginal businessman. He said:
When it comes to policy, regret is pointless and atonement gives satisfaction only to the atoner-not to the one who would have been offended.

Again let me quote from one of the leading spokesmen for Aborigines in the Kimberley region of Western Australia. I listened with very great interest to Senator Crichton-Browne as he was telling us about some of the problems of the Aboriginal people in that area. A spokesman for the Aboriginals there said:

The real aborigines of Australia have forgiven the white men of yesteryear for their cruelty towards Aboriginal tribal ancestors. The present day Aboriginal majority does not hold today's white population responsible for past massacres. In the outback, Aborigines and whites work together, play sport together, live side by side in towns and respect each other . . . White Australians must be careful not to don yokes of guilt, concerning events that happened in a bygone era, which the land rights activists are so determined to place upon them. The past is forgiven.

I would like to point out during this debate that, in Queensland, the Government of which my husband was Premier at the time adopted the system of a deed of grant in trust for the Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland. I believe that that was very good for the people in our State.

TALK.START.PARA: —You played a part in those negotiations, senator.

—I certainly did. I had the opportunity of helping to make sure that my husband was on Darnley Island when this deed of grant in trust was handed to the people, when George Mye was present. We had a most marvellous evening. This action gave the Islander people a feeling of belonging to the State of Queensland and to Australia. These people were allowed to make their own decisions. I think this is very important. I just hope that this ATSIC legislation does not mean that these opportunities that have been given to the Queensland Islanders and Aboriginal people are to be taken away from them.
—It does. They will get swapped for numbers.

—That is unfortunate. I believe it will be a sad and sorry day for our Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland. I look at Aboriginal settlements in our State that have been given deeds of grant in trust. Indeed, I have visited Cherbourg, which is just outside Murgon, a town about 28 or 30 miles away from my home, on many occasions. There is an Aboriginal council in Cherbourg. All the Aboriginal settlements in Queensland have their own Aboriginal councils run by the the Aboriginals themselves. Those councils are in many cases-certainly it is the case at Cherbourg-part of the local community. The children attending high school go to the Murgon High School. The Aboriginal and white people are working together; they are living together. I think that is something that is very important.

SPEECH.PARA: In the early days, before I was married and went to live at Kingaroy, Aboriginals were employed by my husband and his family to work on their farm property. They were treated as part of the family. In fact, Joh told a story about one of the Aboriginals who went into the house, looked at the kerosene refrigerator and could not quite understand why a light and the heat underneath the refrigerator made it cold. I suppose we have gone past those days now and many of the Aboriginals have their own refrigerators. I feel very sad to think that it is quite possible that this deed of grant in trust that has helped the Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland is to be replaced by the ATSIC legislation.

Senator Ron Boswell informed me only today that there are about 15 communities in northern Queensland that are not in any of the zones that have been created. Perhaps those communities will comprise some of the fortunate people who will be able to live without being subject to this legislation. I have a funny feeling that in the meantime the Government might do something to remedy that situation.

The Bill aims to set up what Senator Boswell called `a white man's bureaucracy', thrust it on the black communities of Australia and then call itself self-determination. The Bill establishes an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission that incorporates under the one banner the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Aboriginal Development Corporation and Aboriginal Hostels Ltd. This will be done by establishing 60 regional councils electing 1,200 councillors. In turn, these councils will elect 17 zonal commissioners who in Canberra will make virtually every decision concerning Aboriginals. They will be joined by another three commissioners appointed by the Minister.

I feel very sad at the arbitrary way in which the Minister has planned the zones. The elected representatives will control the 230,000 Aboriginals and the 25,000 or 30,000 Islanders. In essence this means that the Government's answer to solving the Aboriginals' many problems in Australia is setting up a black parliament with 1,200 elected members, dividing Australia into black and white, setting up apartheid in Australia and developing Australia along split racial lines. It is a very sad situation as I see it.

But I believe that the Government has a trick in these proposals. The Minister asserts that a new structure is necessary to enable better outcomes to be achieved for Aboriginal people. There is nothing in these arrangements that logically or necessarily gives promise of any better outcomes. The Minister then asserts that self-determination by Aboriginals is essential for the outcomes of Aboriginal people to improve. That is his version of self-determination. That is his concept of what it means.

The Minister has promised the Aboriginal people power over decisions affecting them. Yet the regional councils will have little or no power. All power will rest with the zonal commissioners-the 17 people sitting in Canberra who get their instructions from the ministerially appointed chairman of ATSIC and his two appointed offsiders. The Minister has promised the commissioners money to put the decisions into effect. He has promised the commissioners support for the decisions that they take. In fact and in law they will not receive those things. I believe it is a cruel and cynical trick.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a vicious hoax.

—Senator Boswell should know all about that because he has been working and helping the Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland for many years since he got into Parliament, and probably even before that. Aboriginal power over decisions will remain in important respects subject to ministerial veto. What does that mean? It means that the Minister has total power.
—It is white supremacy.

—That is what the honourable senator believes. In Queensland, the Aboriginal and Islander people were able to make their own decisions. They had the deed of grant in trust given to them by the Queensland Government. As I said, I was very happy to be on Darnley Island. Senator Boswell was there, too. It was a very great occasion. The people of Darnley Island were delighted to know that they were, more or less, being given their own land to look after in their own way. Under this legislation this power is being taken away from them.
—They made you grandmother of the islands.
—As a matter of fact, they did. I was very proud of that. I hope that they think very kindly of me, even today.

SPEECH.PARA: Funding will remain subject to the normal processes and constraints of the Government and the Budget. That is right and proper. But the Minister has deliberately failed to make that clear to the people. Instead, he has attempted to perpetuate the illusion that total self-control is being granted to Aborigines. This extraordinary state of affairs has been described by my colleague Senator Peter Baume as like putting to the Australian public and to veterans organisations a proposition that all decisions on veterans' affairs and all public funds for veterans' affairs are to be placed under the veterans' control, independent of the general community or of the normal mechanisms of accountability to the Parliament and to the public which provides the cash. He went on to say:

Such a proposal . . . would be seen as a fraud; it would be seen as being inconsistent with constitutional proprieties; it would be seen as being inconsistent with the administrative or financial realities and imperatives.

What surprises me most about this legislation is that there are many members of the Government who claim that they have a special affinity with the Aboriginal communities, that they know what the Aborigines truly want. I ask honourable senators opposite-there are not too many of them here tonight, listening to the debate on this very important subject-whether they agree that most Aborigines in 1989 share the same aspirations of their children, for jobs and a higher standard of living in line with other Australian parents.

They want effective and productive education, greater Aboriginal longevity, more people housed, better housing, better employment opportunities and fewer drug and alcohol problems. We heard about some of those problems earlier this evening from Senator Crichton-Browne. These are the aspirations of many parents across this country, whether they be black, white or Asian.

There are some Aborigines who have already achieved prominence, as Australians first, and surely there must be others to follow. I mention former Senator Neville Bonner, who was still serving as a senator when I first came to this place; Eric Deeral, the National Party State member in my own State of Queensland; Bob Liddle from the Northern Territory and Ernie Bridge from Western Australia, who became a Minister in a Western Australian Labor government. They all made the effort to work in our one Australia, to strive for their achievements equal with and alongside other nationalities. All we do by such legislation is take away from these people, and others, the worth of their achievements.

This proposal is more likely to remove Aboriginal Australians from the mainstream of Australian life, to emphasise Aboriginal separateness, to require Aboriginal people to operate in a system differently from other Australians and to make them into welfare recipients forever. If this legislation proceeds we are sending Aborigines back into the dark ages of colonialism.
The peak body of Aboriginal councils in Queensland, the Aboriginal Coordinating Council, said:

It is the same old Government policy that was used during colonisation. Black people against black people . . . It is painfully obvious that at the end of the day it is party politics and Government priorities that are the real issues and not Aboriginal development.

Just over 20 years ago Australians voted on an historic referendum which overwhelmingly welcomed Aborigines as fully-fledged Australians. The majority of Australians supported that referendum when more than 90 per cent elected to change the Constitution to enable Aborigines to be counted in the census and to give the Federal Government power to legislate regarding them. That was a hallmark in our history. It is vital that we recognise that fact 22 years later and do not undo what strides we have already made, that we recognise that Aborigines played a part in developing Australia. Aboriginal troopers and soldiers defended it. They want to share in Australia's future. That is something we should remember.

I urge honourable senators to reject this Bill because it is unjust, unnecessary and culturally inappropriate and serves to further sectionalise the Australian community. The Bill must not be allowed to proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to add my contribution to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989. The first Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, the 1988 Bill, was tabled on 24 August 1988 and was subsequently referred to the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. In February 1989, the report of the Senate Select Committee was tabled, advocating several amendments to the Bill, and the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on 4 May 1989. On 24 May the Bill was passed by the House of Representatives and it was introduced into the Senate on 27 May. This means that we have now had some 2 1/2 months to examine the reviewed legislation before entering the debate at this stage. A great number of amendments to the legislation have been put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: It appears that the Government has acceded to the majority of the amendments advocated by the Senate Select Committee. All too often legislation goes through the parliamentary process far too fast. In the case of this Bill there has been some time for further consultation. On a personal basis, I would have appreciated more time to consult with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people on these matters. On the other hand, there certainly are a number of very serious issues, as far as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are concerned, which need addressing right now. Some of those issues were enunciated earlier by honourable senators, including Senator Crichton-Browne.

A year ago, on 5 August 1988, there emerged a United Nations report by Professor Erica Daes, chairperson of the United Nations working group. The report was on the indigenous population of Australia. It said:
The Aborigines are living in poverty, misery and extreme frustration and do not have the self-determination and social status enjoyed by other Australians.

On 24 August 1988, a report by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission entitled `Report on the Problems and Needs of Aboriginals Living on the New South Wales-Queensland Border', the Toomelah report, also emerged. Some issues were brought forward in those reports which certainly need to be addressed urgently. The explanatory memorandum to the legislation states:
The purpose of this Bill is to ensure maximum participation of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders in the formulation and implementation of government policies which affect them.

The central proposal that would be implemented by the Bill is the establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission . . . The twenty Commissioners comprising the Commission would all be Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, of whom 17 would be the elected representatives of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community. Special provision would be made to protect the position of the Torres Strait Islander people. The Commission would supersede the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission.

One of the basic problems with this legislation is that it is a contradiction in terms. The Bill aims at self-management and self-determination for the Aboriginal people, yet the very act of the Australian Parliament in passing the Government's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation involves determination and management by the Parliament. That is the system that we have at present and is, therefore, the kernel of the whole problem.

The Aboriginal people of Australia-that is the original people of this land and I guess after some 40,000 years of habitation they may be defined as such-have had in past years various pieces of legislation, systems and plans heaped upon them, almost always with the best of intentions. `It seemed like a good idea at the time' would be an appropriate motto. The paternalistic approach was tried. This involved some children being removed from their families to be brought up on mission stations and reserves. They were sometimes found jobs with Europeans far from the tribal lands of their families. Tied with this were strict apartheid-type rules which banned Aboriginal people from urban areas at certain times unless they had a special pass or certificate. A referendum of the non-Aboriginal population of Australia set this to right just over 20 years ago when those of Aboriginal descent were accorded Aboriginal right of citizenship. Unfortunately, that right in itself has not been a magic wand. The inequities, the injustices and some terrible statistics remain. There have been more recent advances. We have had the National Aboriginal Council, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA), the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, the Institute of Aboriginal Studies, the Aboriginal Legal Service and the Aboriginal Medical Service.

Despite some improvements, the inequities, the injustices and the terrible statistics are still with us today. The average life expectancy is some 15 to 20 years less for people of Aboriginal descent. Aboriginal infant mortality is three times the rate of non-Aboriginal Australians. Aboriginal people have poorer health in general than the rest of the community. In fact, Aboriginal health is not improving overall at present. We see a high incidence of diseases such as diabetes and hepatitis. There are other health problems such as heart attacks. The unemployment rate among Aboriginal people is six times that of the national average. On average, Aboriginal people earn half the income of other Australians. Their imprisonment rate is some 14 times higher. In Western Australia, for example, the Aboriginal population is 2.5 per cent of the population as a whole, yet the prison population runs about level-pegging-50 per cent Aboriginal and 50 per cent non-Aboriginal. Since 1981 deaths in custody in Western Australia have also been on that scale-approximately 50 per cent Aboriginal and 50 per cent non-Aboriginal. Those deaths reflect the gaol population rather than the population at large. In a juvenile detention centre in Perth which I visited earlier this year the proportion of young Aboriginal offenders was 84 per cent. So the present system is not working. When we add to the statistics the sub-standard housing figures and the poor retention rates in high schools, it is easy to understand that there is an urgent need for vast improvement. What is to be done? Do we carry on business as usual? Do we have more of the same and just try to make it better? Unfortunately, the `we' I am talking about comprises all of us here in this chamber and our colleagues in the other place. As far as I know, not one of us is of acknowledged Aboriginal descent. Is this legislation a good idea at this time? If it is not, what is a better idea?

The principles in this Bill, as I have said, are exemplary. The objects are: to ensure the maximum participation of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders in the formulation and implementation of Government policies; to promote the development of self-management and self-sufficiency among Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders; to further the economic, social and cultural development of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders; and to ensure coordination in the formulation and implementation of policies affecting Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders of the Commonwealth, State, Territory and local governments without detracting from the responsibilities of State, Territory and local governments to provide services to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander residents. Will the legislation deliver these particular goods? Like a lot of legislation it has its strengths and weaknesses. As far as I am concerned and as far as the Australian Democrats are concerned the strengths are contained in those clauses in the legislation which allow all people of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander descent to elect their own councillors to represent them throughout 60 regions in Australia. Those regions will be responsible for local affairs and will also be able to advise the Commission on matters affecting local affairs. In Western Australia we are looking at some 15 regions. The functions of those regional councils include to formulate and revise from time to time a regional plan for improving the economic, social and cultural status of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander residents of its region; to receive and to pass on to the Commission the views of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders about the activities in the region of the Commission and other Commonwealth bodies under State, Territory and local government bodies-at long last there is some liaison between these various bodies-and to represent Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander residents of the region and to act as an advocate of their interests.

Other aspects of the legislation are commended by the Australian Democrats. For example, the Aboriginal people themselves will be involved in the decision-making process to the extent that this process will affect their daily lives and their destinies. With the new amendments, Aboriginal people will be able to make changes to legislation. In other words, they will not be bound by councils, by councillors, or by a particular electoral system. There are other aspects too. At least on this occasion it will be the elected representatives of the Aboriginal people who will be making those decisions. In other words, the legislation will allow Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to change the legislation if it is not what they want, or if it does not work in the way intended. Those are the fundamental strengths of the legislation as viewed by the Australian Democrats.

What are the weaknesses in the legislation? These include a preamble which has no force in law and is misleading, and which has in fact already misled a lot of people. The Australian Democrats have sought to change this and not to have the preamble at the start of the legislation in the present format. Also, the Australian Democrats object very strongly-and I quote Senator John Coulter when he spoke earlier in this debate-to the:

. . . payment of dividends and taxes on the capital fund of what is now the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) but which will become a capital fund within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Development Corporation . . . That capital fund was established when the Opposition established the ADC as a compensatory fund. It was established in recognition of Aboriginal dispossession and all that flowed from that. For that reason, it is quite wrong that the Government should seek to levy dividends and tax on earnings from that capital fund.

Another unsatisfactory aspect will be the appointment initially of five commissioners for 12 months before elections can be held. It is quite correct that the coalition Opposition should object to that. However, I would remind the Senate that the present ADC's 12 councillors are all at present appointed by the Minister.

Another flaw as seen by the Australian Democrats is the fact that there will be no electoral rolls when elections are held. I think that this is something that will have to be addressed as time passes. The crucial questions are: Do the Aboriginal people understand the legislation? Have they been sufficiently consulted? Do they want the legislation? Is it acceptable to non-Aboriginal people? And what are the alternatives?

I have tried to judge this issue from a Western Australian perspective. In Western Australia the population currently is close to 1 1/2 million. The Aboriginal population is estimated at nearly 38,000, that is, some 2.5 per cent of the population. There is also a Torres Strait Islander population in Western Australia of close to 700 people, located for the most part in the Broome area. In the past year I have talked about the proposed legislation with as many people as possible, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal. Since the present Bill was tabled in the Senate, I have put out a mailing of close to 400 to Aboriginal individuals, Aboriginal communities and Aboriginal groups, and to non-Aboriginal communities and groups who expressed interest.

I have an analysis of that mailing here. In no way can I say this is a conclusive piece of research. I have not had a response from all those to whom I wrote, although I have had quite a number of responses by mail, by fax machine and also by telephone. I asked how many people the various community leaders and organisers of groups reckoned they represented, and the figure came to some 21,000 in favour of the legislation. I got responses from Broome, Derby, Kununurra, Halls Creek, Port Hedland, Wyndham and Kalgoorlie. One of the responses from Kalgoorlie was a representation from 24 communities which actually had had a meeting about the subject. I also got responses from Albany, the Bunbury area, Geraldton, Carnarvon, the wheat belt area, and the Perth metropolitan area. The organisations represented there were Aboriginal communities, Aboriginal land councils, the Aboriginal Legal Service, the Aboriginal Medical Service, the Aboriginal Outpost Radio, the Aboriginal Media Association, an Aboriginal progress association, some Aboriginal corporations, the Catholic Aboriginal Ministry, and the Quaker Race Relations Committee in Western Australia, who stated that on balance the legislation is better than the present situation. As I said before, that cannot be regarded as comprehensive. I regard it as indicative only.

The replies against the legislation came from Broome, again. Quite a few came from the metropolitan area, representing, as well as individuals, the Aboriginal Women's Congress and Professional Women's Association, and the One Australia Movement. From Kalgoorlie and Eyre they came from the Citizens Electoral Council and from some Aboriginal communities in the metropolitan area and in the country. The leader of one of these Aboriginal communities stated, `We like the horse, but we are not confident about the jockey', meaning, I suppose, the Minister. Some wanted the legislation further delayed-just a few, I might add. This came from the Citizens Initiative Referendum Group, from the community of Torres Strait Islanders in Western Australia, and from a Catholic institution which has a high percentage of Aboriginal students. A few also wanted a referendum. I must say that I think it would have been a good idea to have had some kind of referendum on this issue earlier. Those who wanted the referendum were the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Women's Association, some individuals, and an Aboriginal childminding and resource centre. In fact, I would like to quote what was said on the front of the submission from that particular centre:
Due to the past historical factors of Aboriginal/European relationships, ATSIC isn't the solution as it doesn't change the scene to that extent for Aboriginal advancement and development.

The administrative area on Aboriginal affairs hasn't functioned to the advantage of a people who have survived within their own societal system for 40,000 years or more, who are now self destructive, because they remain a non entity in a land which they recognise as their own, who are willing to share, but are being disregarded, ignored and forgotten to survive in an environment in which they are not wanted.

The ATSIC project with all good intentions, can't function until acceptance of Aboriginal people in their own identity, is fulfilled and they are acknowledged as such, as a basic human right, and therefore entitled to be treated according to the code of ethics as stated by the human rights covenant.

That was from the group that advocated a referendum. I had some other responses. A couple said they were happy to trust my judgment. One was most derogatory about anything the Parliament could achieve for Aboriginal people, whether the ATSIC legislation was passed or not. I had two offensive telephone calls. I say `offensive' because they had very strong racist overtones. I also had a very interesting response from the Country Shire Councils Association, which advocated a greater role for local government as far as Aboriginal affairs are concerned.

I have been very encouraged by the tone of the responses, both for and against. The views were put rationally. In fact, I would like it on record that this has been the tone of the discussion and the debates which I have been having for over a year now. There have been differing views, and that cannot be denied. But what has come through very strongly to me, especially since the tabling of the report by the Senate Select Committee, is that, if the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander legislation is to pass, people want it monitored very carefully. I believe that, having had this taste of consultation and having already seen changes through the acceptance of amendments recommended by the Senate Select Committee, Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people will take a keen interest not only in this legislation but also in its implementation at all stages, especially now that everybody is aware that changes can be made.

The legislation is an imposition, but at least it genuinely provides access to self-management and self-determination. It is not perfect legislation as it stands, although, of course, we do not know at this stage exactly how it will stand and will not know until we have proceeded with the committee stage and know what further amendments will go through.

In conclusion, the present situation is untenable and there must be change. No other alternatives have been put forward. Despite its shortcomings, the Australian Democrats are prepared to support this piece of government legislation. I am in full support of the Democrats stance. Most of the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people who have asked me either to support or not to support this legislation have also asked that the Democrats fight on and continue to monitor the progress of the setting up of the Commission and the councils and all that that entails.

It appears that the Aboriginal people will have the chance to have some control over their own destiny and some control over decision making instead of the present situation. With the best of intentions, the DAA and ADC get on with their work but, nonetheless, there is that feeling that matters are imposed upon the Aboriginal people and not through their own elected representatives.

It is inevitable, of course, that some mistakes will be made. When that happens, these matters will need to be addressed. A solution has not been found so far to correct inequities and to solve the health problems and so on by imposition. Therefore, we must be sensitive to mistakes that may be made in the initial stages.

It has been made very clear to me in talking to Aboriginal people on visits that I have been able to make to the more remote areas in Western Australia that although there are systems which have been set up which should, in theory, improve the health and housing of Aboriginal people, they do not, because the Aboriginal people themselves have not been involved at the basic decision making stage. I commend this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate very long in this debate tonight on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill. The reason is that I think I have said as much as I can about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) both in this chamber and in the recorded proceedings of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. Despite vicious rumours to the contrary, I do not believe in speaking simply for the sake of speaking.
—Oh, no!
—I know that Senator Cook finds that hard to believe. I could accept that criticism from a lot of people but not from Senator Cook.
—I accept your assurance.

—Right. As usual, the most thoughtful, constructive and useful contribution to this debate from the Opposition came from Senator Peter Baume. I have either read or listened to every contribution to this debate, and I found it so difficult to sort out any wheat at all from the chaff of the contributions made by members of the Opposition, apart from the contribution from Senator Peter Baume, that I gave up. I started off, having read Senator Boswell's speech, writing rebuttals and responses to some of the nonsense and after filling 35 pages I realised I would need a long extension of time to canvass them. So I thought, rather than try to do justice to just a few of the bits of nonsense that the Opposition has raised in this debate, I would deal with none of them.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I wish to refer to something the previous speaker, Senator Jenkins, has just said about the deficiencies in this legislation. I have no doubt at all that they are numerous. I am sure that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) would also concede that the Bill has deficiencies, in that there are problems with the legislation of which no-one at this point in time, with the best will in the world, is aware. As I have said before in relation to this legislation, if there are not changes made to how ATSIC operates after it begins its operations, ATSIC will probably be judged to be a failure. I have no doubt at all that the organisation itself will determine, after it has been in operation for some time, that changes will be required into how it should operate. I have no doubt that the organisation will make representations to the Government on the subject. I have no doubt that the Government, after it considers the changes that ATSIC wants to make to its own operations, will respond positively or negatively as it sees fit at the time.

No body which has been created up to this point in time by this Parliament has been faultless in its operations in respect of Aboriginal affairs. I cannot see any particular reason why ATSIC should be dramatically different in that respect. As I have said in this Parliament on a previous occasion in debating this matter, it is the latest attempt by a Commonwealth government, and hopefully the most successful attempt, at providing a real role for Aboriginal people in making decisions about the administration of their own affairs. There is no need to canvass the history of the National Aboriginal Consultative Committee and the National Aboriginal Conference again. I confess that at the moment I am talked out on the subject. I also confess that at the moment I am probably not psychologically tuned in to ATSIC anyway when what I overwhelmingly want to do is go out and kick a few airline pilots to death, like a lot of other people in this country do. That is much on my mind, having spent most of today trying to assist people in the Northern Territory who are being profoundly affected by the strike and, I regret to say, failing to assist them.

I have just had to tell a bunch of 22 schoolchildren from the poor end of town who have been planning since the beginning of this school year to come to Canberra and who were supposed to arrive here next week that they will not be able to come. I was also in the unfortunate position of having to cope with the problem that half of the $25,000 that they have raised for the trip is going to have to be expended anyway on the non-travel costs because the tourist operators are not prepared to waive the money. Not only have they spent an entire year fund-raising for this bunch of kids from the poor end of town to come down here, and they will now not get their trip, but they will also have to pay for the privilege as well. So I confess that the airline dispute is very much on my mind at the moment.

Having diverted to that extent, I also have no doubt that I will probably have to speak for about 10 hours during the committee stage of this debate; so there is simply no need to go over the same ground that I have gone over before. But I do want to say that this legislation is a genuine and honest attempt by the Government, as flawed as it may be in operation. I think it has got a real chance of being successful, provided the Government is prepared to listen to the changes the organisation itself wants to make in the fullness of time and respond positively to them.

I believe the major difficulty that ATSIC will have in its first year of operations will not be copping flak from Senator Tambling or copping flak from the non-Aboriginal community at large but, based on my previous experience of the two organisations that preceded it, copping the criticism it will undoubtedly receive from the Aboriginal community in Australia. Indeed, in terms of the public relations of ATSIC, one of its most important tasks will be its internal public relations rather than its external public relations. It will be necessary for ATSIC to take professional steps to ensure that the far-flung and remote Aboriginal communities are aware of what the organisation is doing around Australia, so that when their tractor does not arrive, their house does not get built or their local community store does not get refurbished they will know that it is because ATSIC is busily occupied doing positive and productive things somewhere else.

The difficulty is that, by the very creation of ATSIC, the expectations of the Aboriginal community that I serve-and it is the only one on which I can speak with any authority at all-have undoubtedly been raised. They have not been raised because of any false promises being held out by the Government. They have been raised by the new and exciting concept in the creation of an Aboriginal body which will not only be a politically representative body for Aboriginal people-it will certainly have that role and I imagine it will pursue that role aggressively-but it will actually administer the Department, as it now is, of Aboriginal Affairs. It is not surprising that people's expectations are going to be raised by the very creation of the body. So I believe that a very difficult task for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission commissioners in the initial stages of the operations of this organisation will be to explain to the Aboriginal community why everything is not instantly fixed. There is no question at all that the people at the receiving end of the services delivered by ATSIC are likely to be far more critical about the organisation than people who are standing on the sidelines like ourselves.

I have my own personal views about funding for Aboriginal affairs which I have also expressed many times on the public record. My own view about funding for Aboriginal affairs is that the lion's share of that funding should, in fact, be non-discretionary. Bodies such as ATSIC or, indeed, any other bodies that are created should have no discretion to determine how it is spent at all because, in my view, the lion's share of funding for Aboriginal affairs has to be spent directly on improving the desperate living conditions of many of these people who, without doubt, are the most deprived group of people still existing in the Australian community. In my view when we are providing houses for people who do not have them and health services for people who do not have them and schools for people who do not have them the only way to do that is to do it on a fair and equitable basis which allows no discretion whatsoever.

Having said that, there should be a discretionary area of funding provided for Aboriginal affairs-that is where ATSIC will play its most important role-in determining how the cream on the cake, if such an analogy is a proper one and I do not think it is, should be spent. Also, there will undoubtedly be many benchmarks established to judge the success or failure of ATSIC. Every one will be an outstanding success, a dismal failure or some point in between. I have no hesitation in saying-and I do not believe this would be the view of all Aboriginal people in Australia or perhaps even most Aboriginal people in Australia-that the benchmark that will be used to judge the success or failure of ATSIC by the Aboriginal people whom I represent in this Parliament will be whether their standard of living improves. It will be whether the delivery of services on the ground from government gets better as a result of the establishment of ATSIC and if ATSIC does not tangibly deliver a better degree and a more efficient degree of essential services which, after all, is the role of government, it will be judged by the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory as a failure.

I will expand on that a little. The proper people in my view to be involved-and the only people to be involved directly-in the preservation and enrichment of Aboriginal culture are Aboriginal people themselves. Government does have a role to play through the funding of organisations such as the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation which does an excellent job of running dance festivals.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not given them much funding this year.

—In the area of Aboriginal affairs the same thing happens, unfortunately, as in the area of non-Aboriginal affairs. The arts always tend to be screwed down a little bit tighter when things are bad than in most other areas of the economy and that is the way it will always be whichever government is in power.
—That is why we want separate funding, like the Institute.

—The Institute of Aboriginal Affairs has, in fact, retained its autonomy. As the honourable senator knows, that was a matter of considerable debate on the Committee. But, as I said before, the right people to be involved in the role of safeguarding and preserving Aboriginal culture and ensuring that it remains as viable as it currently is in many parts of Australia are the Aboriginal people themselves and that is how they see it. The role for Government, so far as Aboriginal people see it, is in providing essential services. It will be on the more efficient delivery of those services that the organisation itself will be judged by the Aboriginal community in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope, along with every member of the Government who is supporting this legislation, that that will be the end result. If it is not, I have no doubt that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will say, as he has said already on numerous occasions in the Parliament, that ATSIC was established in order to benefit Aboriginal people and improve their services and if it turns out to have flaws and failings they will be corrected. I think Gerry Hand himself has been the last person to put the view in this Parliament that ATSIC would be an instant and guaranteed success in solving all the problems of the Aboriginal community in Australia. In fact he has said quite the opposite on a number of occasions. It is a good and honest attempt by this Government to provide real teeth to Aboriginal administration in Australia that it has never had before.

Of course, as Senator Baume knows full well, the major failings of the National Aboriginal Conference (NAC) and the National Aboriginal Consultative Committee (NACC) were that those bodies had no teeth at all and their recommendations were largely ignored by governments of both political persuasions. They were seen in the Aboriginal community as being impotent and useless bodies and that is why there was the profound disinterest in them and their operations and elections that took place in the Northern Territory. I believe that the very feature of the enhanced role of ATSIC in providing hands-on involvement of Aboriginal people in determining how the money is spent will assist ATSIC to be a success.

Having said that, I acknowledge again that it is a feature of democratic life in this country that whatever we do in the area of Aboriginal affairs is seen by someone as being wrong and misguided and it would be foolish indeed to think that this organisation, with the best will in the world, will escape that sort of criticism. Whatever it does will be seen by some people, not only in this country but inevitably in this Parliament, as being wrong and misguided. What I hope, therefore, is that people will allow ATSIC to operate for at least a year before they start conducting any witchhunts. They should give it a reasonable go. They should not start jumping on its back in this Parliament five minutes after it leaves the starting gate. In the fullness of time, if that is justified, no doubt the opportunities will present themselves, as they always do in Aboriginal affairs, to do that.

I must explain to the Senate that I have done the very best I can, as someone who got to his feet this evening not intending to say very much, to oblige Senator Tambling in providing the opportunity for Senator Chaney to speak in this debate. With that huge hint, Mr Acting Deputy President, to ensure that you adjourn the Senate at the due time, I say in conclusion that I look forward to the detailed examination of the Bill itself-which is why I did not see fit to canvass it now-that will occur in what will be very prolonged sessions of the committee stage of this debate. I understand that the Opposition has some 20 packages of amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have about 111 amendments. We have put them in 20 packages.

—Therefore, I have no doubt that there will be ample opportunity to canvass the detail of the legislation. I conclude by saying that I at least wish ATSIC well in its start and will give it my full support in ensuring that it is a successful operation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 26 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government received representations from Tasmanian fishermen expressing concern at the evidence of various organisms being released in Tasmanian waters by Northern Hemisphere vessels.
(2) What measures does the Government take to monitor foreign vessels in ballast entering Australian waters.
(3) What supervision are they subject to and what penalties are imposed on operators failing to maintain the requirements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Both I and the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) have received representations from a range of agencies and organisations in Tasmania and mainland Australia expressing concern at the situation.

(2) A program of ballast sediment sampling by Quarantine staff from overseas vessels entering a number of ports around the mainland of Australia has been introduced. This supplements the sediment sampling from woodchip carriers entering Triabunna in Tasmania which has underpinned work by the CSIRO Marine Laboratories into possible introduction of exotic species into south-east Tasmania waters.

(3) The Quarantine Act 1908 sets penalties of $50,000 or imprisonment for 10 years or both for a natural person, or $200,000 for a body corporate for the knowing introduction of harmful organisms. The challenge involved in developing effective controls on ballast water under the Quarantine Act is a substantial one given the estimated 60 million tonnes of discharge annually in Australia and the need to minimise disruption to industries which rely on shipping for bulk commodity exports. A range of control approaches is under development, in consultation with concerned authorities and industry to limit the introduction and spread of organisms toxic to humans. It is intended that these controls be introduced as soon as practicable arrangements are finalised. Additionally, a program of research into the broader problems posed by ballast water discharge, including possible control approaches, is being developed. The Government's concerns in this area and its commitment to action were highlighted in the Prime Minister's Environment Statements in July.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 9 June 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the RAAF base at Richmond been considered as a possible site for Sydney's second international airport with RAAF facilities relocated further north, perhaps to Newcastle.
(2) What consideration has been given to this option and what objections have been raised.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The possible use of the RAAF Base Richmond as Sydney's second airport was examined in the Second Sydney Airport (SSA) Site Selection Program (1983-85).
(2) Several impediments to the development of Richmond as a major civil aviation facility were identified.

First, the Base was assessed as lying too close to the Blue Mountains for normal civil operations to occur on the present east-west runway alignment. Such operations, if they were to occur, would also cause considerable noise nuisance to residents of Richmond and Windsor.

Secondly, the present airport was considered to be too small for further development and the only direction available for its extension (ie to the south) would impinge on both built up areas and flood prone land.
Thirdly, the development of the base as a second major civil aviation airport would require the existing RAAF operations to be relocated.

In the light of these factors, Richmond was not included in the final ten sites which were subjected to a further detailed comparative evaluation, although two of the sites, Londonderry and Scheyville, were within 10 kilometres of Richmond.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence Force: Liquor and Licensing Laws

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 July 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are members of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) exempt from the provisions of State and Territory licensing laws.
(2) Are members of the ADF who are under the age of 18 years permitted to consume alcohol on Defence Force properties.
(3) Is there a weekly alcohol allowance for all members of the Defence Force, regardless of age.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Members of the ADF do not have any general exemption from the provisions of State and Territory liquor licensing laws. Such laws apply according to their terms to members of the ADF in their private capacity or when they are away from ADF establishments.

However, section 123a of the Defence Act 1903 does exclude the application of State and Territory liquor licensing laws to the possession, sale or consumption of alcohol by members of the ADF at ADF establishments, camps, units, messes and canteens. The main effect of this provision is that ADF messes, clubs etc do not require licences under State and Territory laws and are not regulated by such laws in their operation.

(2) Pursuant to section 123a of the Defence Act 1903 determinations made by both the Chief of Naval Staff and the Chief of Air Staff expressly forbid the sale or provision of intoxicating liquor to a person who has not attained the age of 18 years. Current Army policy is that members who have attained the age of 17 years are permitted to consume alcohol in the appropriate messes or canteens on Defence Force properties. However, this policy is to be reviewed in light of the Army's drug and alcohol policy and is likely to be removed.
(3) There is no weekly alcohol allowance for members of the Defence Force.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 May 1989 (Hansard page 3114), Senator Watson asked me a question, without notice, concerning the Tasmanian parliamentary accord and its implications for the future of mining in that State.

ANSWER.PARA: The following is the answer to the honourable senator's question:

It is not appropriate for me to speculate on what effect, if any, the Accord will have on the mining industry. With the exception of a number of specific areas identified in the Accord, such as Denison Spires, Hartz Mountains National Park and Little Fisher Valley, the boundaries of any additional areas for gazettal as national park or nomination for World Heritage listing are not defined and are matters which have yet to be considered by the Tasmanian Government.

It is certainly true that as the currently producing mines are depleted, the mining industry will increasingly depend on new mineral discoveries to remain viable. It is evident from discussions I have had with the Tasmanian Premier, Mr Field, that he is well aware of this. I would expect that in addressing this issue, the Tasmanian Government will strike an appropriate balance between conservation of Tasmania's unique natural heritage and the identification and development of its undoubted mineral resource potential.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Patterson asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice, on 10 May 1988:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister inform the Senate whether it is the intention of the Australian Bureau of Statistics to include questions on the nature and hours of unpaid work in the home and in the community in the 1991 Census? If it is not intended to include this work, which economists estimate to be worth half as much as officially measured gross domestic product, can the Minister explain why?
The Acting Treasurer has provided the following information:

It is not intended to include questions on the nature and hours of unpaid work in the home and in the community in the 1991 Census. The collection of reliable information on this topic would be a complex exercise involving a series of inter-related questions to which satisfactory answers could be obtained only through the medium of a specially designed sample survey using trained interviewers. The topic would not be suitable for inclusion in a collection such as the population census which uses self-enumeration methods. Apart from this consideration, it has been necessary to limit the number of questions to be asked in the 1991 Census both for reason of cost and respondent load.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics conducted a pilot time use survey in Sydney in 1987 which produced some data relevant to this topic. The results were published in Time Use Pilot Survey, Sydney, May-June 1987 (Catalogue No. 4111.1).
